PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: The Acting Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Education
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition from parents representing the government schools in New South Wales respectfully showeth that:
1. They call on the Federal Government to re-affirm publicly that its primary obligation is to government schools.
2. They support the Federal Government's policy decisions which have reduced funding to wealthy private schools and which have broken the nexus between government and non-government school costs.
3. They endorse the Federal Government's opposition to the provision of a 'base grant' to all non-government schools.
4. They ask that the Federal Government create a general recurrent resource base which is adequate for government schools through the provision of increased recurrent funding.

5. They call upon the Federal Government to negotiate agreements with State/ Territory Governments which will ensure a planned program of improvements in governments schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Marriage Act 1961.
Bill presented by Senator Gareth Evans, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The principal purpose of this Bill is to give legislative effect in Australia to the Convention on Celebration and Recognition of the Validity of Marriages signed by Australia in July 1980. The Bill represents a significant step for Australia in that it is the first of the Hague conventions Australia has signed and will be the first to which Australia has given effect. In addition, the Bill proposes certain other amendments to the Marriage Act 1961 with which I will deal at a later stage.

I turn to the first category of amendments-those implementing the Hague Convention on Celebration and Recognition of the Validity of Marriages. The purpose of the Convention is to assist in making more uniform provision between nations in relation to the recognition of marriages celebrated abroad.
The Hague Convention

Problems of recognition of marriages celebrated abroad have arisen in a number of countries which insist that, when their citizens marry abroad, they do so in conformity with their own laws. The placing of limitations on the grounds on which countries may refuse recognition to marriages celebrated abroad would be of general benefit to all, and particularly to those whose personal affairs involve several countries. As Australia has a greater number of such individuals than most countries, anything that helps to reduce the incidence of 'limping marriages'-marriages which are recognised as valid in one country but not in another country-will be to the benefit of this country.

It is hoped that ratification of the Convention by Australia will encourage other countries to do likewise. This will, in turn, encourage greater recognition abroad of marriages celebrated in Australia. Ratification by Australia will also be of benefit in relation to Australia's participation in the Hague Conference on Private International Law. So far, the common law members of the Hague Conference, including Australia, have not ratified many conventions and this has been the subject of criticism from the civil law countries. As section 43 of the Family Law Act 1975 states, the family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society. This Convention, which deals with marriage, the legal foundation of the family, is an appropriate one with which to commence Australia's implementation of conventions arising out of the Hague Conference.
Celebration of Marriages

Chapter I of the Convention deals with the celebration of marriages. It is a response to the difficulties often facing persons seeking to be married in a country of which they are neither nationals nor domiciliaries. The Convention imposes an obligation on the states who are parties to it to allow the celebration of a marriage between people who meet certain requirements. A significant difficulty for Australia to date on the question of the celebration of marriage has been that marriage celebrants do not have the resources to check whether parties have capacity to marry each other under a foreign law. The Bill proposes to deal with this problem by recognising the position which, as a matter of practice, has existed in Australia for many years, namely, that marriage celebrants in Australia marry persons in Australia-whether or not they are foreigners-by reference only to Australian law.

To enable Australia to comply with chapter I of the Convention, the application of Part III of the Marriage Act-dealing with void marriages-is varied by clauses 10 to 13 of the Bill so that the rules of that Part will apply to all marriages solemnised in Australia or outside Australia under Australian law. This amounts to a variation of Australia's 'choice of law rules'-that is, those rules of law which determine, where the laws of more than one country are relevant to a topic , which country's laws will be applied. However, it represents a considerable simplification of the present position and will allow Australia to accede to chapter I of the Convention, as Australian law will require each of the parties to a marriage to meet the requirements of Australian law only before they may marry under that law.

To give an example of the way this will assist parties: Australian law at the moment would declare a marriage entered into in Australia between two people domiciled overseas to be invalid if those parties did not have legal capacity to marry under foreign law. Under these amendments, the marriage would be valid if the parties had capacity under Australian law.
Recognition of the Validity of Marriage

Chapter II of the Convention imposes upon states that are parties to the Convention an obligation to recognise marriages that are validly celebrated under the law of the state of celebration, subject to certain basic exceptions. This obligation will involve recognition being given to some marriages which would not be considered valid under the common law rules of private international law.

The Bill provides, in addition, in new section 88D, that these common law rules will remain in operation to a limited extent, so that if a marriage would not be recognised as valid under the Convention it will nevertheless be recognised as valid if the common law rules so provide. Essentially, the Convention operates as a gloss upon the common law, as it will provide an additional basis upon which the recognition of validity of foreign marriages may be afforded.

The Convention rules are contained in a new Part-Part VA-to be inserted in the Marriage Act. Part VA is to apply to all marriages whether solemnised before or after the Convention comes into force for Australia. The Government has taken the view that it is desirable that the Convention should have the widest possible application. This will, however, mean that some marriages will now be recognised as valid which were previously not recognised as valid in Australia. It is regarded as undesirable that a marriage entered into in good faith in the belief that it would be valid should be rendered invalid by operation of the Convention. Accordingly, there is a saving provision in sub-section 88C (7) so that a marriage regarded as void before the Convention enters into force for Australia shall continue to be regarded as void, whether or not it would be valid under the Convention rules, if a party to that void marriage has subsequently remarried.

Under Part VA a marriage solemnised in a country outside Australia, other than under Part V, is to be recognised as valid throughout Australia if the marriage was, at the time it was solemnised, recognised as valid by the law of the country where it was solemnised or, alternatively, if the marriage is recognised as valid under that law at the time its validity falls to be determined- paragraphs 88B (1) (a) and 88B (2) (a). Analogous provisions will apply to marriages solemnised overseas by foreign diplomatic or consular officers.

These rules of recognition will, however, be subject to a number of exceptions permitted by Article II of the Convention. A marriage solemnised in a country outside Australia will not be required to be recognised as valid under the Convention rules in a number of circumstances. First, it will not be recognised where either party was at the time of the marriage already married to some other person. Secondly, where one of the parties was at the time of the marriage domiciled in Australia it will not be recognised if either of the parties was not of marriageable age. Thirdly, where neither was domiciled in Australia at the time of the marriage, it will not be recognised while the parties are below the minimum age at which a person can with permission marry in Australia-that is , 16 years for males, and 14 years for females. Finally, the marriage will not be recognised where the parties are within the prohibited relationship or where the consent of either of the parties was not a real consent.

Another provision of Part VA, section 88E, provides, in accordance with the policy expressed in Article 12 of the Convention, that the determination of the question of validity of a marriage which is incidental to the determination of another matter, such as inheritence, shall be resolved in accordance with the Convention rules. A further provision of the new Part, section 88F, provides a prima facie method of proof of a marriage alleged to have been solemnised in a foreign country.
Legitimacy of children

Two sets of amendments relate to Part VI of the Act, which deals with the legitimacy of certain children. The major amendment, in clause 22, inserts new sections 91A and 91B into the Act. These sections deal with the legitimacy of children born to a married couple as a result of artificial insemination by donor or in vitro fertilisation. They do not themselves make provision in relation to the parentage of these children; they merely ensure that, if State or Territory law does so provide, then the operation of the legitimation provisions of the Act will extend to those children. Various States have indicated, in the course of discussions in the Standing Committee of Attorneys- General, their intention to deem a child born in this way to be the child of the married couple, and to sever the biological link with sperm or ovum donors.

Section 91A deals with three separate cases-sperm donation alone-sub-section (1 )-ovum donation alone-sub-section (2)-and donation of both sperm and ovum-sub- section (3). In respect of each of these procedures, where a law of a State or Territory requires the resulting child to be treated as a child of the man and the woman, or either of them, the child will be deemed to be legitimate. A related provision is inserted by clause 20 into section 89, to ensure that where an unmarried couple have a child by these procedures, and subsequently marry, the child will be legitimated by virtue of that subsequent marriage, if they are deemed to be the parents by State or Territory law.

The other amendment to Part VI, in clause 21, involves the extension of the operation of section 90 of the Act, which deals with legitimation by virtue of a foreign marriage, to situations where the foreign country involved does not recognise the status of illegitimacy. Israel is one such country. The opportunity has also been taken to amend the application provisions of sections 89 and 90 so that they operate on the domicile of either parent, rather than simply on that of the child's father. This change is in line with the general policy of the Government to remove unwarranted distinctions based on sex.
Notice of Intended Marriage

Minor amendments are made to section 42 of the Act by clause 16, to improve the operation of the provisions dealing with notices of intended marriage. The most important, contained in clause 16 (a), is the extension of the maximum period prior to the date of the marriage within which the notice can be filed, from three months to six months. Extension of this time will allow celebrants and parties greater flexibility in making arrangements. The Family Law Council has considered this proposal, which has been put by civil celebrant groups, and sees no objection to it. Clause 18 is a consequential amendment to the overseas marriage provisions of the Act. Clause 16 (b) adds Australian diplomatic officials to the list of those who may witness a notice of intended marriage. This will make the necessary paperwork easier for those who have to come from outside Australia to marry in Australia.

Sub-section 42 (5) of the Act allows a prescribed authority to effectivelty waive the minimum requirement of one month's notice, if he is satisfied that the circumstances of the particular case justify his so doing. Clause 16 (c) of the Bill inserts a new provision designed to prevent a party who has been refused this waiver by one authority, simply seeking permission from another authority without disclosing the previous refusal. The suggestion for this amendment arises out of representations to the Ombudsman on this matter.
Fees for Civil Celebrants

Clause 24 of the Bill makes it an offence for a civil marriage celebrant to charge a fee higher than that prescribed by the regulations for the solemnisation of a marriage. While the present legal position is that the prescribed fees are the legal maximum that can be charged for solemnisation, it seems desirable, in light of the particularly vulnerable position of parties about to be married, that there be a clear legislative statement to this effect, for the protection of both parties and celebrants. It is not intended by this provision to affect the ability of celebrants to charge for other matters ancillary to the actual solemnisation, such as flowers or music. I should also point out that the Government is keeping under close review the level of fees to ensure, consistently with overall economic restraint, that the fees represent an adequate remuneration for this important service. Earlier this year the fees payable were significantly increased in light of these principles.
Provision of 'Marriage Education'

As a continuing part of the Government's response to recommendation 61 of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act, that 'education for marriage and family life be further supported', the concept of pre-marital education in Part 1A of the Act is broadened by clauses 5-9 of the Bill to that of marriage education. Organisations working in the area of pre-marital education have often indicated that one of the most useful times to engage in education for marriage is in that period shortly after the marriage has been entered into. Grants made for the purposes of marriage education will thus complement the activities of marriage counselling organizations under the recently amended definition of marriage counselling in the Family Law Act 1975.
Miscellaneous amendments

A number of amendments will rationalise the operation of the Act or correct minor errors. Amendments to the definition of ''Judge'' (clause 3 (a)) and to section 99 (clause 23) are in this latter class. Clause 14 removes an unnecessary provision concerning the constitution of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for certain purposes, and clause 15 brings the criterion for appointment of celebrants under section 39 into line with the policy expressed in section 33 in relation to ministers of religion of recognised denominations. Other formal amendments are made by the Schedule.

Last year this Parliament enacted long-needed changes to the laws governing the termination of marriage. This Bill represents the other facet of the Government' s commitment to resolving the problems faced by ordinary men and women in Australia in that most personal areas of their lives. In extending the grounds for recognition of marriages entered into overseas, in ensuring the legitimacy of children, in broadening the scope of education for married life and easing procedural restrictions on entry into marriage, this Bill is an affirmative statement of the importance of marriage as a fundamental and enduring institution. The Bill has no financial implications. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS (PROHIBITION OF IMPORTATION OF NUCLEAR HARDWARE) BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Chipp) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to prohibit the importation of nuclear hardware, and for purposes connected therewith.
Bill presented by Senator Chipp, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Australian Democrats want to highlight the role Australia plays in supporting the nuclear arms race, and the role Australia can and should play in bringing an end to the nuclear arms race. This Bill deals with one aspect of that overall picture. It provides for a prohibition on the importation of nuclear hardware that would be essential for the establishment of nuclear power reactors, uranium enrichment plants or nuclear waste reprocessing facilities. None of these facilities exist in Australia at present, except for research facilities run by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission.

This Bill would prevent the establishment of any other elements of the nuclear fuel cycle in Australia. One exception to the absolute prohibition of imports of nuclear hardware is provided. This would operate where imports would be necessary for the Atomic Energy Commission to maintain its present capacity to produce medical and industrial isotopes. The Bill provides for substantial parliamentary scrutiny to ensure that if nuclear hardware is imported, as provided for in the exception, there can be no abuse.

The Democrats believe that there are overwhelming arguments-relating to both energy policy and nuclear weapons non-proliferation policy-that show the nuclear industry is of no benefit to the well-being of humanity. The energy problem that the nuclear industry is supposed to solve is not a simple search for new sources of energy at any price. Solving the energy problem has to relate consumer demand to energy sources that are economic. There is no demand for coal, electricity or nuclear power per se. The demand that exists in the community is for light, comfort and heat, which can be provided in a number of ways. Coal, electricity or nuclear power are simply means to an end, they are some of the ways of providing light, comfort or heat. The task of energy planners is to seek the best way to provide for the real needs of consumers. The end use of energy has to be examined and the best means to provide it has to be employed. The cornerstone of the 'soft-path' energy strategy that the Democrats endorse is that given the choice people will choose the cheaper form of energy supply. This will rule out nuclear power instantly. When the costs of every aspect of establishing and running a nuclear reactor are added up, the total is more than any reasonable person could afford.

In November 1983, the capital cost for a nuclear reactor to deliver a kilowatt of electricity was $9,020 per kilowatt. Let me give an example as to what that figure means. Heating a house involves about 10 kilowatts of electricity. If a consumer is using nuclear generated electricity it is costing the electricity authority over $90,000 to provide that electricity. Thus the cost of providing the electricity to heat the house will, in many cases, exceed the total cost of the house itself!

Official industry projections of the cost of nuclear power are well below the figures I cite. Those with an interest in promoting nuclear power have left out the costs of waste management, decommissioning nuclear plants, the low capacity factor of reactors and the grid loss of electricity in their estimates. They have deliberately left out these factors to depress their costs, to deceive the public. The extent of the economic lunacy that is nuclear power is evident in the fact that it is collapsing despite massive government support. The United States Government has provided between $40 billion and $100 billion in subsidies to the nuclear industry over the last 40 years. Not even those enormous subsidies have been able to shield the realities of consumer choice.
Why then, if the technology is as uneconomic as experience clearly shows, are we introducing legislation to prevent its establishment in Australia?

Despite suffering savage attacks from market forces, the nuclear industry is being supported by some governments because of the power of vested interests and the fact that a nuclear industry is indispensable to the continued production of nuclear weapons. The continuation of the nuclear industry in the Western world provides an example of the worst kind to developing nations. Combined with the aggressive policy of the nuclear club to sell this technology at greatly reduced costs, the Western world is providing the example and the means for nuclear weapons proliferation. To alter this situation requires that the appropriate nations repudiate the nuclear option and demonstrate that energy security can be achieved more fully, at a faster rate and at less cost than through the nuclear option. That is the rationale for this legislation. Nations such as Australia need to publicly repudiate the nuclear option. Unless we do, we can expect more and more nations to develop the capability to produce nuclear bombs.

Vietnam plans to proceed with nuclear power. The Philippines is ready to start up its first nuclear reactor. God help us! Indonesia has expanded its nuclear research centre and it may develop a civil nuclear power program. These nations, among others, rationalise their foray into nuclear technology by citing the promotion of nuclear technology by the industrialised nations as evidence of nuclear power's benefits. If this false illusion of benefits is not removed more countries will follow blindly a path that is expensive, grossly inefficient and the driving force behind nuclear weapons proliferation.

The publication of 'The Strategic Basis of Australian Defence Policy' on 30 March 1984 by the National Times has provided stark evidence that Australia needs this legislation. While the Government denies that it has endorsed the development of nuclear weapons if our neighbours do so, it has not denied that Australia is actively monitoring nuclear weapons developments 'to ensure that the lead time for Australia could be matched to developments in other countries should the Government so decide'. The only way to ensure that Australia does not develop nuclear weapons is to ensure that there are no facilities to produce the materials needed for nuclear weapons in Australia. This legislation, which the Democrats are introducing, will provide that assurance.

There are many alternatives to centralised energy sources such as nuclear power . Energy efficiency improvements such as insulation and retrofitting can save so much energy that new sources are all but unnecessary. As the next option, renewable energy sources must be pursued. Solar power, wind power and boigas fuels, amongst others, are the cheapest and most benign energy sources now available. They are not a pipedream of the future. They are the cheapest and best buys now. Private power utilities in the United States are opting for renewable energy resources now because of their economic benefits. Any continuation of the nuclear industry will absorb funds that would be more effectively and efficiently used in the technologies I have outlined. Every dollar spent on nuclear power will retard the implementation of the economic and efficient energy resources.
The Labor Party in its platform has made statements, as have its Ministers, that should lead it to support this legislation. The ALP platform on nuclear power states that Labor in Government will:
Prohibit the establishment in Australia of nuclear power plants and all other stages of the nuclear fuel cycle.
That is crystal clear in its meaning. The then Acting Prime Minister, Mr Lionel Bowen in a letter to my colleague Senator Mason on 3 February 1984, stated:

. . . the Government has withdrawn support from a private sector study of the feasibility of an enrichment industry in Australia and we consider that there is no propect of the nuclear option for power generation being utilised in Australia.
The Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) wrote to me just this week on 2 April 1984 , and stated:
The Government does not have the slightest intention of interesting itself in acquiring any nuclear weapons capability.

These statements are in accord with ALP policy and should ensure by logic this legislation is supported by the Labor Party and therefore passes both Houses of Parliament. I will be happy to negotiate with the Government and consider amendments so long as the essence of the legislation, opposition to all elements of the nuclear industry, is in no way weakened.

The passage of this Bill would provide a clear, unequivocal and unambiguous signal to the world. It would make it clear that Australia sees no benefits accruing to anyone from nuclear power. It would substantially reinforce our international nuclear non-proliferation concerns by stating that we take those concerns so seriously we are willing to make them part of our domestic policy. With our house in order our international concerns will be received with a force and clarity that will make them difficult to ignore. Australia will then, and only then, be a working example of a non-nuclear nation that others can emulate. Australia will then be making its greatest contribution by showing the way to nuclear non-proliferation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1983 No. 331 and made under the Customs Act 1901, be disallowed.

The Australian Democrats' object in seeking the disallowance of these two regulations and an Australian Capital Territory ordinance is to permit a re- examination of the whole issue of the widespread sale and hiring in Australia of film and videotape material of a violent, sadistic and cruel nature, often also with sexual elements, and which also is gratuitous; in other words, if there is no reason for that material to be included because of the plot or storyline of that particular videotape, but that violence, sadism or cruelty is being portrayed purely for its own sake.

It is important to establish at this stage, certainly not for honourable senators, but for anybody in the public who may be listening to this, that a great deal of law is delegated. In other words, the Government is empowered by certain legislation to make other regulations and ordinances as it wishes. Those matters are not debated and voted on in this House or the other place; such regulations and ordinances are merely brought down. Either House of the Parliament subsequently can look at them and decide what it wants to do about them. In most cases, because of the volume and routine nature of this material, it passes through without being disturbed. All of those ordinances and regulations are subject to a sanction by either House of the Parliament, and very properly so since it is a major concession to the Government of the day that it can use this mechanism in the democratic process. Hence a majority vote of this House can disallow a regulation or ordinance. My object is to seek a disallowance by that means.

Since I first raised this matter publicly some three weeks ago very many representations have been made to me from a large variety of people and organisations. The overall weight of such representations has been, almost without exception, to express alarm at the prospect of this kind of extreme material becoming prospectively available even if it is given an X rating. It is important to establish, and perhaps we should establish it again and again in this debate, that we are talking about video tapes that go beyond showing explicit sex to showing cruelty, violence and sadism with sexual association. Such material typically uses the humiliation, the degradation and even the torture of women as its central theme.

The three motions I will be moving seek to disallow the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations (Amendment) as contained in Statutory Rules 1983 No. 331, the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations (Amendment) as contained in Statutory Rule 1983 No. 332, and the Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 as contained in Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 59 of 1983. I shall speak first to the ordinance, which the Australian Democrats regard as inadequate in two basic and important areas. The first of those areas is, I think, more important than the second. The Australian Democrats believe that the censorship of all video tapes and discs should be mandatory, not voluntary. The ordinance that deals with that matter is a very important one because it has been used as a model by all States. Therefore it is proposed that it will have application throughout the Commonwealth. I think it already has application in some States. The governments of New South Wales and Victoria already are examining the extent to which they should censor this material.

I understand a meeting of State Attorneys-General and the Federal Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) is to be held on Friday of this week, during which a complete review will be conducted of this whole question. The Australian Democrats support such a review. The fact that we have not deferred bringing forward the motions of which I have given notice is indicative of our desire that this debate be held to ascertain the views of the Senate before that meeting takes place on Friday. That is a very important point of principle to be established. I am well aware of the gravity of the action of the Senate in obstructing these regulations into which a great deal of work has gone. In some respects-indeed, possibly one could say in most respects-they are perfectly satisfactory and are an improvement on those already in existence. However, I believe that the Senate must look at them and, if possible, ensure that the community view on them is accommodated. The Senate should examine whether the Government might not have gone further on a point of principle, which is a very respectable course to take, than it might otherwise have done.

I shall deal later with this important point of principle, namely, whether one should censor to the extent that would prevent people from having the right to see what they like in the privacy of their own homes. In substance my view is that it is perfectly acceptable that people have that right provided that the exercise of individual freedom does not impinge upon the common good. Of course, that is a fundamental and basic point of common law. It would be extremely naive of anybody to suggest that in this one area of X rated video tapes there should be unfettered and untrammelled freedom where there may be evidence that there is harm to the community. In all other areas of law-one could cite the traffic laws as a prime example; we are not allowed to go out and drive our cars at 120 kilometres an hour anywhere-we give up that freedom voluntarily because it is for the common good. That is the basic point of principle which I commend to honourable senators in trying to obtain their support for this motion.

The Ordinance is inadequate in that first particular that censorship is mandatory. We think that it expresses a degree of trust in the industry and the importers of these things which is bordering dangerously on the naive. We believe that if it were known that this material were subject to mandatory censorship and classification there would be much less incentive to try to get it into the country and sell it through established video outlets. Some of this material is of appalling nature. I repeat that we are talking of very extreme violence, sadism and degradation of human beings. I do not think that anybody in the Senate would argue that there is any virtue in this material other than the basic virtue, the view that if people want to do something, if possible, they should.

The Ordinance also has another inadequacy in section 25. A difference is set down between the definition of an R-rated or X-rated film and the definition of a film which must be refused classification. We think that section should be tightened up considerably. When I say film, I should say that film within these regulations does include video tapes. Again, I think they are the main point at issue. The Ordinance compels the censor to allow distribution of material under an R or X rating which, to quote the actual terms of the Ordinance, 'deals with matters of sex, drug misuse or addiction, crime, cruelty, violence or revolting or abhorrent phenomena in a manner that is likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult person'. I stress those last words 'offence to a reasonable adult person' because the Ordinance goes on to say that the censors are authorised to refuse even X classifications to video tapes which deal-then similar words appear-with
sex, drug misuse or addiction, crime, cruelty, violence or revolting or abhorrent phenomena in such a manner-
the words here are slightly different-
that it offends against the standards of morality, decency and propriety generally accepted by reasonable adult persons . . .

I do not believe any real difference has been given. To contrast that with what is likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult person I suggest that this presents the classifiers with an impossible task in the community interests to try to make a distinction in that kind of area. The Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations (Amendment) forbids entry into Australia of material which gratuitously depicts extreme violence or cruelty, especially when combined with a sexual element. The point here is: How wide do we intend to make the mesh of the net? We think that the net of the mesh is far too wide. We do not regard the regulation as a minor point. I believe it is a basic point of the most crucial importance. On this single word hinges whether or not we will allow into this country a flood of material which, in fact is gratuitous material and is, to a demonstrable extent, violent and cruel, has sexual associations but is in no way extreme. At this point I wish to examine the meaning and consequence of the word 'extreme'. Extreme is not, after all, any kind of grey area. Extreme is the worst possible thing one can get. That is what extreme means. If we look at this in its purest element it means that if one can produce a piece of videotape which is in some way worse than one wants to import, even on a minor particular- one has to produce only one and say 'That is extreme; ours is not extreme because that is further out than ours'-the censors are compelled to allow that material to come in under an X classification and on that basis it would come into the shops, be distributed and sold.

This matter may well come up later for debate. I hope it does. But anybody who considered any definition of 'extreme' as different from that is deluding himself. That is what 'extreme' means. That is the word used in the regulation. We would like to see that word 'extreme' removed when these regulations are finally brought back since we can see no reason for a regulation which in effect states that it is acceptable to import and distribute into Australia material which is to demonstrable extent gratuitously violent and cruel with sexual associations. I am sure that the regulation was not intended to be that way but that is its purport. It depends a great deal on the word 'extreme'. If that is removed, the regulation becomes completely different in its purport. It becomes a very different kettle of fish altogether.

On that basis, of course, it would be perfectly proper for the Attorney-General to bring back to the Senate whenever he wished the regulations with that word removed. He would then bring in something substantially different from what had been done before, even though it involved only a single word. That single word determines entirely the scope of entry into this country of the material which the regulation is intended to control. On that basis I see no reason for any kind of problem. As far as the ordinance is concerned also, to make the censorship mandatory rather than voluntary is such a substantial change that the Attorney should have no difficulty in bringing it back in, resubmitting it to the Senate and putting it through the normal processes for a new regulation or ordinance. On that basis I hope that the Attorney-General will not stand up later and say that this will ruin things because nothing can happen for six months under the terms of Standing Orders. We will not accept that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you not move for the deletion of that one word rather than disallowance of the whole ordinance?

—I take the Attorney's interjection. I think I made that point plain at the beginning of what I was saying. As I understand it, this is the view on this side of the House, and the view communicated to us by so many members of the public. We believe our view ought to be communicated to the meeting which is to be held this week, to the Attorney-General and to the Government so that it can be looked at. I have made the point that there is nothing to prevent the Government bringing in another regulation. There is no reason for any delay provided those points are met. If the Government is not prepared to meet those points, the point of view being pushed from this side of the House must be maintained.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations (Amendment) which exempts from classification any videos imported into this country for private use. I must stress that the earlier one was concerned with those for hire, sale or distribution to the public generally. In this regulation there is a reliance entirely on the ordinances of individual States for the classification of private videos. As the only ordinance which exists and which covers this classification is the Australian Capital Territory ordinance, that with which we are now concerned, which we are debating and saying is not satisfactory, this exemption has obviously been made prematurely. While no mechanism exists for classifying films in an individual State or Territory, classification should be mandatory at the point of entry of the film into the country.

To go from those technical points to what I might call the philosophical background to this, which I think is important, the Australian Democrats strongly support the principle of minimum censorship. I make that absolutely plain. We believe that there is no right for people to come in and change the habits of what people do in private, provided there is no harm to other people or to the community. That is the issue that is very strongly at point. Of course , I agree that it is a controversial area, defining what might or might not be good for the community. It is a grey area. I suggest to the Attorney and the Government that, because of that alone, they should regard the Senate attitude towards these two regulations and any ordinance with some consideration. This is a matter on which the consensus of this House would eventually have to be arrived at.

I am not attempting to canvass or predict the vote of the Senate, but let us assume that these are disallowed today. I suggest to the Attorney and the Government that if they were brought back there would still need to be an area of discussion, perhaps of compromise, on the form that the new ones would take in order to be acceptable to the majority of the Senate.

I would like to use a sort of reductio ad absurdum argument at this point-one that I hinted at earlier. It would be absurd for even the most ardent civil libertarian to suggest that we ought to be able to drive on whatever side of the road we prefer. We could not just go out and drive on the right hand side of the road if we wanted because we believed in civil liberties. It is a matter of civil liberties. We have restricted our liberties by introducing a law to drive on a certain side of the road. The argument could be put that, for many centuries, road traffic proceeded how it liked, and it was obligatory for people to get out of the road of other people. However, we all not recognise that it is a matter of habit that we do not do those things. We limit our freedoms in many respects when it is in the common good.

As I said, it would be similarly naive to advocate that any and all pornographic material should be available to adults in our society and apparently exempt that area, for no reason, from the general principles of the rule of law that apply in other areas. Even the Government, of course, has not gone that far in these regulations. Sometimes one hears people who take virtually a nihilist view that there should be absolutely no restrictions on liberties whatsoever. That is absolute nonsense in any community of human beings . It is nonsense even in a family situation. It is nonsense when one human being and another are at the same place at the same time.

My next task in this matter is to persuade the Senate that as these regulations and the ordinance stand at present they allow for a harmful effect. The first point to be considered is that the combined audio visual media has a very potent effect on the entire society. I think a case can be made for the fact that the effect of the audio visual media is far stronger than the effect of the print media and far more difficult to control. One of the reasons for this is that people cannot read books, certainly books of any sophistication, until they reach a reasonable age and are able to form some judgment. However, even very small children can watch television and be influenced by it. There has been considerable research into the fact that when exposed, very young children perhaps even inadvertently, to some kind of material which is deleterious to them, find the effects of this audio visual material very strong. It is also much more difficult to control. People might be looking at a video tape on their television and would not even know that a child had entered the room. There are probably people in this society, though probably not many, who have this sort of material in their homes and are indifferent about whether their children watch it. I would not negate that situation occurring either. The effects of the dangers and the enormous impact of the audio visual media must be recognised and legislated for.

A principal effect of the audio visual media is that it has hardened the community to suffering. It is interesting that, in our research on this, we found that when our earliest silent movie, the Story of the Kelly Gang, was first shown in 1906 in Australia, the audience was so horrified by the scenes of violence such as shooting-it was merely a pop from a gun and somebody falling on his back-that some people in the audience fainted. I think they then had a very proper appreciation of the significance of what was happening. There was the depiction of somebody being killed. That instinct in 1906 was a very real, proper, genuine and human instinct.

What has happened now? We have been hardened to the extent that every day we see things on our television screens and in films where violence, dead bodies and injuries are shown. In fact, society has become almost blase about violence. We must recognise that this is a dangerous trend. It must be recognised, whether it can be proven or not, that it has an effect on the crime rates. I can remember in my childhood-I think most honourable senators would recollect this- that a child could wander around his or her home town without much fear. That is no longer the case in our society. In fact, parents are terrified of what happens to their children and are worried about their children being away from their homes for even a few hours. School girls in Sydney were held up and dragged into a black van and raped. That is not uncommon. That situation would have been inconceivable in the past. Where did these ideas come from? I think that that is something which society has now got to ask itself. I think we in this place have to take the responsibility in that area.

To a large extent we accept that we have come, as a society, to accept that level of violence. We have accepted the level of violence that occurs on our roads. Violent death which occurs on our roads has become acceptable. I have spoken to television journalists about stations showing films which depict road violence. It is terribly hard to find film that is bad enough or that shows bad enough injuries to impress people. That is a terrible indictment of any society that that has to be said. We see so much of the starving, diseased, hopeless children in Third World countries that our outrage and horror at the sight is lessened and consequently we do not feel the same urgency about alleviating their suffering. This has led to the same attitude for the people in our own communities who are suffering, such as the unemployed.

This growing indifference to the afflicted and the disadvantaged is certainly not to our credit. We cannot condone the same occurring with our attitude to sexual violence or cruelty. Here, I think, we are hitting on a point which is of the utmost importance to our society. As I said, the enormous majority, 99.9 per cent, of the submissions made to me on this matter over the last three weeks have agreed with that point. Those submissions have come from people who have said to me that they do not agree with censorship and that they hate censorship. However, they have said: 'In this case, you are right'. I think that is the view of this society.

This material is freely available even if it is sold in brown paper wrapping, is not advertised and is sold only to adults. Of course it is still freely available. Anybody can get it. If they wanted to show it to a child nothing could stop them. If they wanted to see it themselves nothing would stop them. The possibility exists for some sick person to act out an example of the appalling violence that he saw in the material. I am sure many honourable senators will recall an instance in the United States a few years ago when a gruesome murder bore a remarkable resemblance to the episode of Kojak which had been screened the week before. That is not unique. I agree that this effect cannot be proven; but I do think that it has to be proven. I think the mere fact that it is possible ought to be enough for society to take some heed of it and consider it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you ban the Beatles because of the Charles Manson murders after listening to Helter Skelter? That is the logic of that kind of approach.

—A point was made in one of the newspapers last week about Shakespeare's plays. The Attorney-General can read my reply to that article in this morning's Australian. I will not waste the time of the Senate discussing that matter any more. I think it is ridiculous and, I suggest, not worthy of the Attorney to raise that point in view of the importance of the matters that are at issue in this debate. It is obvious from the Attorney's comments that he is not aware of the degree of concern that exists in the community about this matter. I think he ought to be, since he is the Attorney-General.

SPEECH.PARA: It is obvious that these video tapes and discs do not merely affect the adults who buy and view them. The victims of the violence inspired by sadistic and cruel pornography are almost always those who are physically weaker in the society. I suggest that the Attorney-General bears that in mind. They are usually women and children; they are the innocent victims. They have a right to be protected against even the possibility of that kind of assault. As I said before, these tapes are almost exclusively degrading and offensive to women. I have had submissions from most of the feminist movements. They are in favour of rescinding the new X rating altogether so that the R-rated movies would again be the most explicit allowed. That may surprise the Attorney, but that is a fact.

Adults who buy or hire these videos are not the only ones who are exposed to them. I return to the recent British study which determined that 60 per cent of children had seen a pornographic video tape or disc. Of course, these children did not buy or hire the videos themselves. Most of them were watching tapes bought by their parents which were never intended to be seen by them. Of course, if something of this nature is forbidden to children they will always try to seek it out. That is in the nature of human beings. If they do find and view violently deviant material, what effect will this have on an immature psychological character because that is what a child is? Does anybody in the Senate agree that this is an attractive or desirable influence on the education or future of the next generation? If they disagree with that then they will support this motion. Here I am speaking to Government members as well because I think this is a matter which transcends politics. It is a matter of great community interest. I will be very distressed to see a vote take place on party lines on this matter. If a vote on party lines were taken it would have a very important and significant lesson to carry for the public about what the Government thinks about the sorts of things I have been talking about.

A feature article in last Friday's Melbourne Age quoted what was said by Mr Alan Tibbitts, the product manager for a series of X-rated videos. I am depending on that newspaper's account. I do not know of my own knowledge that Mr Tibbitts said these things. But he was quoted by the Age, and as far as I know he has not denied it, as saying that his organisation's first collection of X- rated videos does not include tapes dealing with sexual violence. He is reported as saying:
There are cassettes we've looked at with bondage and we've looked at introducing them, but at this stage we're sticking mostly to the heterosexual accepted areas.

However, this does not preclude future supplies of these videos including those with a strong element of sexual violence. When asked if in future sexual violence would be included, Mr Tibbitts's answer was quoted as:

When it's really been proved to us that there's a market for it . . . as a company the answer is yes . . . We can put out a lovely 'Love Story'-type movie and it does small numbers. We put out a horror-cum-R-rated movie and the figures go through the roof; so if we don't do it somebody else certainly will.

He was referring there, of course, to the X-rated material. I am sure everybody here realises that the material we are discussing is not just erotic pornography . On 29 February this year New South Wales parliamentarians were able to see film and video clips of material which was classified as R or X and some of which was refused classification. My colleague in the New South Wales Legislative Council, the Hon. Elizabeth Kirkby, wrote to me the day after this screening, expressing her absolute horror at all the material which was shown. I have raised this matter because she wrote that letter to me. In her letter she said:

I cannot attempt to describe the revolting nature of the material demonstrated to us. It is vicious, sado-masochist material showing violence against both men and women . . . . such depictions of cruelty brutality and vicious assault have no merit at any level. As a civilised nation, how can we allow our citizens to be exposed to such material and still condemn the excesses of cruelty and terror in other nations? How can any such material have a place in a society that attempts to condemn and outlaw vicious and cruel behaviour? We cannot prevent such material being manufactured, but we can prevent financial profits to accrue to people who will attempt to import and disseminate such material.

Anybody who knows Elizabeth Kirkby would have no hesitation in describing her as an eminently reasonable adult person. She is not easily shocked but it is quite apparent that she was not only shocked but also absolutely horrified by the material shown to the New South Wales parliamentarians.

The Chief Commonwealth Film Censor, Mrs Janet Strickland, maintains that one of the scenes of 'really gross physical violence' which was shown could not possibly have been simulated. The thought of people, especially children, being exposed to graphically depicted, well simulated, gross physical violence, especially with a sexual element, is appalling enough; the thought that somebody has actually suffered from that violence is absolutely horrendous. The Attorney- General has said that he does not believe that 'snuff' movies, that is, movies where a person is actually murdered before the camera, exist. I do not think it matters whether or not they do in fact exist; the mere possibility that they may exist and that there are regulations which may encourage their depiction cannot be condoned.

An article in the New York Daily News of 7 August 1983 indicates that in the United States of America at least there are those who are sick enough to be prepared to make a 'snuff' film. An article headed 'Two Girls Murdered for '' Snuff'' Film', states:

Two teenage girls, who thought they were getting $500.00 to appear in a porno movie, were apparently murdered for a 'snuff'-type film. Their skeletons were found on March 3, 1983, 7 months after their disappearance.

No bail-arrest warrants were issued for Fred Berre Douglas 55 and Richard Hernandez 38 both of Garden Grove, California. One of the suspects had already been sentenced for planning a torture film. Investigators seized more than 100 pictures allegedly taken by Douglas.
Detective Larry Johnson said of the victims: Beth Jones 19 and Margaret Kruger 16: 'They were just two girls who didn't have jobs and needed money'.

It is obvious, I am sure, that the regulations and the ordinance that we are now considering are inadequate. I hope that the Government will agree to make the changes. I hope that the Government will see some sense and reason in the fact that we have brought forward the motion. I think that subsequent speakers will do that. I commend the motion to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —This week is a very important week for the health, sanity and happiness of Australia. We have before us a motion to disallow a package which has been devised after discussions between the Federal Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and his State counterparts in response to the video problem in particular and objectionable publications in general. The community has suddenly become alarmed that the video boom is out of control. The purveyors of pornography and violence are exploiting the boom and making their millions at the expense of the community. I do not have time to give the details of these millions, but they are available.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole issue now is fairly and squarely before the Federal Parliament. The Mahony Review of Customs Administration and Procedures in New South Wales has identified where the rot set in. I draw the attention of the Senate to pages 99 to 105 of the report of Mr Mahony in his review of Customs administration procedures in New South Wales. I seek leave to have the appropriate pages incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The pages read as follows-
5.56 The Attorney-General has administrative responsibility for this regulation which provides:

''4A. (1) This regulation applies to goods that, whether of their own nature or having regard to any literary or other work or matter that is embodied, recorded or reproduced in, or can be reproduced from, the goods-
(a) are blasphemous, indecent or obscene; or
(b) unduly emphasize matters of sex, horror, violence or crime, or are likely to encourage depravity,
and to advertising matter related to such goods.

(2) The importation of goods to which this regulation applies is prohibited unless a permission, in writing, to import the goods has, after the Attorney- General has obtained a report from the person or persons for the time being authorized by the Attorney-General to give such a report for the purposes of this regulation, been granted by the Attorney-General.

(2A) The Attorney-General may, by writing under his hand, after consultation with the Ministers of State of the States with responsibility for censorship, authorize a person or persons to give reports for the purposes of this regulation.

(3) A permission under this regulation shall be subject to such conditions imposing requirements or prohibitions on the person to whom the permission is granted with respect to the custody, use, reproduction, disposal or destruction of the goods, or with respect to accounting for the goods, as the Attorney- General thinks necessary to ensure that the goods are not used otherwise than for the purpose for which he grants the permission.''
5.57 On 15 June 1973, the Department of Customs and Excise issued a memorandum which set out the policy and procedures to be followed in relation to the operation of regulation 4A.
''LITERATURE CENSORSHIP

The operation of the arrangements contained in memorandum of 21/3/73 and previous memoranda have been reviewed in consultation with officers of the Attorney-General's Department. This review has been undertaken having particular regard to the practical experience gained in implementing the Government's announced policy in relation to censorship, viz;
* it shall be a person's right to be free to read or view whatever he may wish, and
* persons (and those in their care) be not exposed to unsolicited material offensive to them.

It is visualised that the Government's policy will eventually be implemented by controls at the point of sale and display. These controls will probably be complemented by strengthened legislation in relation to matter which may be despatched through the post. In short the Customs role in censorship matters will, in the future, progressively diminish.

However, until such time as the necessary legislation has been introduced which will enable the policy to be implemented along the lines mentioned above, there remains a need to retain Regulation 4A of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations in order that the second component of the policy can be given legal effect.

For the time being at least, Customs resources engaged in screening imported goods should be primarily concerned with the detection of prohibited imports other than material which offends Regulation 4A. However, Customs will continue to seize privately imported pornography:
* if it comes to notice because a passenger blatantly but unsuccessfully attempts to conceal it;
* if it is deliberately brought to the attention of an officer;
* if it comes to notice in the course of examination for other Customs purposes; and
* if imported by first class mail, the material is known before examination to be unsolicited.
For the time being there are to be no prosecutions under the Customs Act for offences involving pornography.
Where seizures are made the importer is to be acquainted with the provisions of Sections 205/7 of the Customs Act.
Where, because of a seizure, an importer questions the implementation of the Government's censorship policy he is to be informed-
* the full implementation of that policy must await changes in legislation, and
* while the Regulation 4A provisions exist they cannot be ignored by officers of this Department.''

5.58 Successive responsible Ministers since 1973 have agreed that their Government's policy was that it was an individual's right to be free to read or view whatever he might wish provided that other individuals were not exposed to unsolicited material offensive to them.
5.59 As to the manner in which regulation 4A is applied at present, the Collector said:

''The general approach that Customs officers have worked on is based on instructions we have received that it is the Government's intention that people should be able to read, see and hear as they wish and if an individual coming through the airport had in his possession a small quantity of goods that may be subject to the provisions of that regulation the likelihood would be that those goods would not be detained from that person.

If, on the other hand, a person came in with substantial quantities of goods that we believed may be subject to the provisions of regulation 4A the practice should be that those goods would be referred to the censorship office for determination as to their classification under regulation 4A provisions.''

5.60 Submissions were received from the Chief Censor, Film Censorship Board and from the Australian Festival of Light and Community Standards Organisation ( Queensland). The ACOA and the COA commented on the operation of this regulation. Mr A. Watson, Honorary Secretary of the Council for Civil Liberties in NSW made an oral submission.

5.61 The Chief Censor was critical of standards of Customs control procedures relating to importations of films and videotapes and their movement and storage prior to either registration or rejection by the Board established under the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations.

5.62 Regulations 11 and 12 of those regulations prohibit the delivery of films from Customs control until registered or, in the case of related advertising matter, passed by the Board. Regulation 13 provides that films shall not be registered if they are:
(a) blasphemous, indecent or obscene;
(b) likely to be injurious to morality or to encourage or incite to crime;
(c) likely to be offensive to the people of a friendly nation or to the people of a part of the Queen's dominions; or
(d) depict any matter, the exhibition of which is undesirable in the public interest.

5.63 The Chief Censor stressed the need for all films and videotapes, regardless of quantity to remain under Customs control until censorship formalities have been completed. It was stated that movement of these goods on continuing permission under section 40AA inhibited desirable levels of Customs checks and eroded controls generally. There was a perceived need to improve Customs supervision of these transactions to ensure that goods are not released by Customs prior to registration by the Film Censorship Board.
5.64 In his response, the Collector stated:

(a) current section 40AA arrangements for delivery of films and videotapes for commercial purposes were introduced in 1975 following a practice which relies on obligations placed on an importer who avails himself of concessions granted under the provisions of the Act in relation to storage and control of goods;
(b) there were only two incidents in recent years referred to Customs by the Film Censor's Office which suggested breaches of screening;
(c) for this reason and because the goods were generally free of duty, follow- up of these controls attracted a low Customs priority;
(d) the control procedures were introduced in 1975 in consultation with the Chief Censor's Office; and
(e) general censorship policy and controls are presently under review by Customs Central Office and the Attorney-General's Department.

5.65 Submissions from the Australian Festival of Light and Community Standards Organisation (Queensland) drew comparison between regulation 4A which the organisation described as 'clear and precise' and the current policies of non- enforcement of these provisions by Customs. The submissions sought from this Review a recommendation that regulation 4A as it applies to prohibition of importation of indecent or obscene goods be again enforced using the definitions of 'indecent' and 'obscene' in the decision of the High court in Crowe v. Graham and Others (41 A.L.J.R. 408).
5.66 In response, the Collector stated that:

(a) Customs application of regulation 4A is in accordance with instructions issued nationally following a Ministerial direction in 1973 that resources engaged in screening imported goods should be primarily concerned with the detention of prohibited goods other than material subject to regulation 4A;
(b) conflict between legislation and departmental instructions was highlighted in a report by a Task Force enquiry into allegations about the Customs Service in New South Wales in March 1981; and

(c) discussions between the Attorney-General's Department and Customs Central Office are in progress with a view to putting to Government, options for legislative and/or procedural amendments in relation to regulation 4A.

5.67 I have concluded that I should not make the recommendation sought by this organisation on the grounds that the regulation applies nationally whereas the Review is concerned primarily with Customs administration and procedures in N.S. W., and that the subject matter of the regulation is for Government to determine .
5.68 The ACOA submitted:
(a) if the application of regulation 4A is to be changed, the legislation should be amended to give effect to that change;
(b) if there is to be a direction about how a law is to be applied, the direction should be a matter of public record so that the public understands that there has been a direction.
5.69 The COA which was critical of the administration of regulation 4A, made a number of submissions including:

(a) '. . . the law of the land, as enacted by Parliament, is ignored by bureaucrats on the grounds that pornography is too hot for governments to handle . Customs officers are forced to contend with this spurious situation, despite the findings of the Task Force and undertakings that the conflict between the law and government policy would be resolved. Huge profits made by persons trading in pornography are used to finance smuggling of drugs.'

(b) '. . . there are issues for instance on the regulation 4A material which are not clear and, if we are going to vigorously pursue Customs regulations, breaches of them, I think the exceptions need to be identified.'

(c) '. . . nor does there seem to be anything done about people who have child pornography in their possession, if it is a small quantity. I think it is suggested . . . that we currently have a practice that we are using and quite honestly there is no practice that we really are aware of that is being used consistently.'

5.70 The COA submitted further that officers are not clearly directed that they will not be pursuing matters of pornography and that if an officer had an hour to spare a short jaunt around Sydney would disclose plenty of opportunities for him to investigate illegal importations of pornography.
5.71 The COA expressed disappointment that the Chief Film Censor did not appear at a public hearing so that the COA could raise issues.
5.72 Mr Watson of the Council for Civil Liberties submitted:
(a) the Council supported the view that there should not be a conflict between regulation 4A and a direction that it should not be enforced in the case of material for personal consumption;
(b) the conflict should be resolved clearly in favour of the status quo practice rather than in favour of enforcing the existing regulation;
(c) if regulation 4A is to stand rather than the existing practice, the regulation is not efficient, and it cannot be impartially applied;
(d) Customs officers were not appropriate for the job of making decisions whether material, which may offend against the regulation, should be seized;
(e) the initial decision to seize goods under regulation 4A was highly subjective and basically partial on the part of particular Customs officers;
(f) where the law falls outside the line of practice and community standards, there is potential for corruption;

(g) because of difficulties arising out of differing censorship laws of the State and the Commonwealth, the Customs direction tried to make the role of the Customs officer in relation to regulation 4A feasible, practical and rational in line with community standards while refusing to change the regulation. Clearly the gap should be resolved;
(h) the regulation is unenforceable as it now stands because it is so far outside community expectations and standards and the present practice is unfair to Customs officers; and

(i) it is inefficient and dangerous for the notion of impartiality to allow the situation to remain in its present form but equally dangerous to revert to the situation that the film censors and others say it should be.
5.73 The Task Force dealt at some length with the problems arising out of regulation 4A and stated:

'The Task Force is of the view that the administrative difficulties caused by the inconsistent policy and treatment of pornography should be remedied by the issue of clear and precise instructions to officers. It is the Task Force's view that the only instruction that could be issued consistently with present legislation is one to the effect that officers should detain any goods coming to their notice which appear to them to fall within the terms of the regulations, for referral to Attorney-General's Department.
Discussions currently are underway between senior officers of BACA and the Attorney-General's Department with a view to resolving these problems.'

5.74 The submissions and views mentioned show clearly that neither regulation 4A nor the Customs direction is being administered effectively. The direction placed Customs officers in a difficult position in requiring them to apply a regulation only in the manner provided in the direction when they are expected to deal with passengers and goods according to law. The Attorney-General's Department stated in January 1983 that regulation 4A had been the subject of discussion between officers of that Department and the Department of Industry and Commerce and that action is proceeding.

5.75 In my view it is quite improper that the responsibility place on Customs officers by the direction should continue. I recommend that the conflict between regulation 4A and the Customs direction be resolved without delay.

5.76 From the material made available to me, I doubt whether the arrangements made to move goods subject to regulation 4A under the provisions of section 40AA can be said to be operating effectively. I recommend that:

(a) the requirements specified by the Collector under section 40AA (3) should be tailored specifically to cope with the special problems associated with the movement of those goods and that the Chief Film Censor should be consulted before these requirement are determined by the Collector; and

(b) the Chief Film Censor should inform the Collector in writing when any breach or suspected breach of the section 40AA requirements is detected. This would ensure that the Collector would be in a position to administer effectively section 40AA in relation to goods subject to regulation 4A.

TALK.START.PARA: —According to that report, in 1973 the then Attorney-General and Minister for Customs and Excise, Senator Lionel Murphy, issued a ministerial direction tantamount to asking Customs officers to turn a blind eye to blatant breaches of relevant Customs regulations concerning films and prohibited imports . Following up the directive, the Department of Customs and Excise issued a letter dated 15 June 1973. The letter is detailed in the Mahony report and states inter alia:

SPEECH.PARA: For the time being at least, Customs resources engaged in screening imported goods should be primarily concerned with the detection of prohibited imports other than material which offends Regulation 4A.
Then the directive continues:
For the time being there are to be no prosecutions under the Customs Act for offences involving pornography.

That deliberate direction to breach the law, to turn a blind eye, was at the behest of the then Attorney-General, Senator Lionel Murphy. The result has been that a trickle of pornography, violence and obscenity has now become a flood, and has been aided by advances in technology and copying techniques. Obviously there are problems in preventing obscene and objectionable publications and films from coming into the country, but those problems were exacerbated-indeed further problems were created-by the deliberate instruction of the then Attorney -General to Customs officers to ignore the law.

I ask the Senate to bear in mind what the Willett Task Force Report into Allegations about the Customs Service in New South Wales said on this matter. That report on page 23 cited a case involving a Commonwealth driver who offered a bribe to a Customs officer stationed at Sydney. The Customs officer reported the attempted bribe and, after a good deal of toing and froing, concern was expressed. The Willett report stated:
Later the DCS advised that there was insufficient evidence to support a prima facie against X--
a businessman who in the first place proffered the bribe-

in respect of the attempted bribery and requested that further evidence be supplied before deciding whether there was a prima facie case against X in respect of the importation. Some of that further evidence previously had been in the possession of departmental officers in respect of an unrelated matter--
and here is the point-
but it had been returned to one of X's enterprises--
that is, one of the business enterprises-
on the understanding that the Department did not prosecute for the importation of pornographic material.
The understanding was based on a departmental instruction to that effect. The report goes on to detail problems which have emerged in respect of the direction .

That is where the rot set in. Successive Federal Attorneys-General and some State Ministers responsible for controls over the exhibition of films and the advertising, display and sale of all publications and videotapes or discs are also to blame for the mess we are in. Warnings have been given by many well- informed citizens, including the Chief Censor, Mrs Janet Strickland. I refer to a letter written by Mrs Strickland to the Mahony inquiry dated 18 June, 1982. I seek leave to have that letter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
FILM CENSORSHIP BOARD
ATTORNEY-GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT
Telephone 267-2711
7th Floor,
Piccadilly Court,
222 Pitt Street,
SYDNEY, N.S.W. 2000
In reply please quote No. B80/92
The Secretary,
Review of Customs Administration
and Procedures, 18 June 1982. G.P.O. Box 3569,
SYDNEY, N.S.W. 2000
Dear Sir,
Further to my letter of 11 June 1982, I hereby offer the following general comments regarding the importation of films and videotapes with which the Film Censorship Board is vitally concerned.
The Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations, which are made under the Customs Act, provide for the establishment of the Film Censorship Board.

The Regulations provide that films and videotapes shall not be delivered from the control of the Customs until they have been registered by the Board and that they shall not be registered if, in the opinion of the Board, they are:-
(a) Blasphemous, indecent or obscene.
(b) Likely to be injurious to morality or to encourage or incite to crime.
(c) Likely to be offensive to the people of a friendly nation or to the people of a part of the Queen's dominions, or
(d) Depict any matter, the exhibition of which is undesirable in the public interest.

It is essential that all films and videotapes (regardless of quantity) remain under Customs control until censorship formalities have been completed. Currently, the storage and movement of such goods is allowed under continuing permissions granted by Customs under Section 40AA of the Customs Act-after the Film Censorship Board indicates that it has no objection to such permissions being granted.

When these 40AA permissions were introduced, the Bureau of Customs undertook to supervise and carry out physical spot checks to ensure that the provisions of the permissions were being observed. However, it would appear that Customs has been unable to carry out more than a very occasional check and consequently little or no control is exercised over these goods.

It is suggested that the movement of films and videotapes, whilst Customs control, could be improved if (i) licensed Customs Agents were directly supervised, and (ii) if all goods delivered to the Film Censorship were sealed with a Customs seal-thereby making it apparent if goods were interfered with.

Unfortunately, Customs officers often clear films and videotapes which have not been registered, irrespective of the legal requirement for registration prior to the release of the goods. Although it is realised that many films and videotapes are imported through Parcels Post or in passenger baggage (and are therefore difficult to intercept), on the rare occasions that they are intercepted, it is considered that they should be dealt with by Customs in accordance with the Regulations.
I would be pleased to furnish any further information you may require.
Yours faithfully,
(signed)
(Mrs) Janet Strickland,
CHIEF CENSOR

TALK.START.PARA: —In the final paragraph of that letter the Chief Censor, Mrs Janet Strickland, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, Customs officers often clear films and videotapes which have not been registered, irrespective of the legal requirement for registration prior to release of the goods.
