Although it is realised that many films and videotapes are imported through Parcels Post or in passenger baggage (and are therefore difficult to intercept), on the rare occasions that they are intercepted, it is considered that they should be dealt with by Customs in accordance with the Regulations.

What we will be told by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) is that if we disallow these regulations it will be open slather for more and more pornography. Is that not what he will tell us? Will he not tell us that if we disallow this package, it will mean open slather for more and more pornography?

TALK.START.PARA: —The flood gates will well and truly open!

—That is what he will say to us. The answer is: Why does he not enforce the law as it is? If he does so, we should not be facing the present situation in the Australian Capital Territory or in respect of the importation of much of this material. We already have the Objectionable Publications Ordinance of the Australian Capital Territory. I have the document in my hand. It would enable action to be taken against those who breach the law, those purveyors of hard core pornography and violence in the Australian Capital Territory. This is the law; it is all here.
—No point of sale; not one.

—It is all here. The only reason it is not enforced is that the Attorney-General will not approve of charges being laid under the legislation. He can say that there is no point of sale specifically in here, but that is not the essential problem.
—It is unworkable.

—It is unworkable only because the Attorney-General does not ensure its enforcement. The Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulation and the Customs (Prohibitive Imports) Regulations are unworkable only because the Attorney-General says they are, and because the Attorney-General of the day, namely Senator Lionel Murphy, told Customs officers to ignore the regulations. That is the only reason and it has become a self-fulfilling prophecy. The legislation seeks, and what we are here to discuss is to entrench the viewpoint that was used by the then Attorney-General to undermine the law. What was that viewpoint? It was expressed by the then Senator Murphy in the Senate Hansard of 8 March 1973, at page 266, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . adults shall be entitled to read, hear and view what they wish in private or in public, and persons and those in their care shall not be exposed to unsolicited material which is offensive to them.

Now the two parts of that proposition are mutually contradictory. There may have been some cause for concern at the time as to the strictness of the interpretation of the Customs regulations. It may well be-although I cannot concede that this is possible-that Senator Murphy did not foresee the explosion in the video scene. But how can anyone now say that that proposition is valid today? If one does as is proposed in the Ordinance, that is to say, institutionalise the importation, production and sale of hard core pornography, how can one say how one will control that? How is one going to honour what the latter part of that proposition says, that is to say, that persons and those in their care should not be exposed to unsolicited material which is offensive to them? Let me tell honourable senators what Mrs Janet Strickland, the Chief Censor, said to a meeting of the National Council of Women of New South Wales in Sydney in June last year. The report states:
Mrs . . . Strickland, the chief censor with the Film Censorship Board, expressed concern at the accessibility to children of undesirable video tapes.
Mrs Strickland said that under the present system, the Board does not classify videotapes for hire or sale.
They are not required to be classified unless exhibited in public.
'Defining ''public exhibition'' is somewhat of a problem, as technological advances have raced ahead of legislative change', she said.
The video tape revolution is undoubtedly an exciting technical phenomenon, and one which greatly expands the individual's range of educational and entertainment choices.
'However, like all revolutions it has potentially destructive and negative aspects which, until recently, have not been given serious consideration.
'It is anticipated that within the next couple of years, 70 per cent of Australian homes will own a videotape recorder.
'Videotapes can be bought from a variety of outlets, including newsagents, supermarkets and even delicatessens.
'Video libraries are becoming big business.
'Anybody, of any age, can buy or hire a videotape-providing they can pay'.
This is something that people ought to understand:
'Unlike books, videotapes are usually viewed in a communal situation-among family and friends.
'Sections of the tape can be freeze-framed, played in slow motion or double time, and screened dozens of times.
'The playback facility on cassette recorders is simple to operate, and there can be few children over the age of 10 who are incapable of mastering it.

'Moreover, because a videotape is a physical entity, it may lie on a shelf or in a cupboard for a considerable period of time to be discovered one day by a growing child whose presence was unforeseen when the videotape was acquired.
'The legitimate tastes of adults may run to material which, on reflection, they would prefer their children not to see.
'But the problem of controlling a child's access to adult video is a continuing one.

'For that reason parents have a right to expect the clearest possible warning of material which may be damaging to children, and the education of adults in this new age of electronic information may come to seem just as important as the education of children.
'I would emphasise that our greatest concern is to protect children from possible harm, as well as to ensure that women are not portrayed as easily accessible and exciting objects of sexual violence.
'We are concerned that women and children do not become the innocent victims of the video revolution' . . .

That is a statement by Mrs Janet Strickland who, by the way-the Attorney-General knows this, and so do the States Attorneys-General-is concerned that this regulation is not adequate in that it does not provide for compulsory classifications. I will come to that in a moment. So we have had the trickle of obscenity which has now become a flood, aided and abetted by the advances in technology and copying techniques. Warnings, such as Mrs Strickland's, have been issued time and time again. At last on 13 July last year the Federal and State Attorneys-General met in Brisbane and decided on a package proposal for new controls. It was not a unanimous decision. Tasmania and Queensland have in certain ways reserved their decisions. Tasmania would not agree to a situation which would not include a compulsory classification system. The proposed controls that are now before us from the Attorney-General, allegedly with the unanimous support-which is not so-of the States, reflects the naive Murphy view which was repeated by Senator Gareth Evans, who claimed that the Australian Labor Party was elected to government with a commitment to that policy. It certainly was not. Nowhere in Bob Hawke's policy speech is there any statement which says what Murphy said and what was then the view and policy of the Labor Party. It may well be that part of it is in the platform, but certainly the Government was not elected with that mandate.

To provide a model for the States to follow, Senator Evans has now tabled this package, which is the Classification of Publications Ordinance for the Australian Capital Territory; amendments to the Customs regulations concerning films and prohibited imports-namely, the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations (Amendment) and the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations ( Amendment). Let me say quite deliberately that amongst other things an analysis of this package will do these things: By introducing a new X rating the package will institutionalise the importation, production and trafficking in hard core pornography. Let us not have any doubt about that. It also makes the Attorney- General, through his appointees and through his right to approve or not of prosecutions, the arbiter of public morals in the Australian Capital Territory. It naively relies on the voluntary co-operation of merchants in the business by not insisting on compulsory classifications. It allows imported video tapes or discs for non-commercial use to be no longer subject to compulsory registration by the Film Censorship Board. Finally, it entrenches in the Classification of Publications Ordinance the very words of the Murphy view which been the cause of the problems we face today. It institutionalises the importation, production and trafficking of hard core pornography. The new X rating has been established and honourable senators will be aware of what types of material go into that new rating. Not one senator here would say that that material is not obscene-not one . Not one senator would say that the material to be classified as X rated is not degrading and dehumanising. Not one senator would say that to a certain extent it is not calculated to make out womanhood as an object and in certain cases as being in bondage to other human beings.

I have the details here of the classifications made since the ordinance came in . Do not forget that it has been in since 1 February. They contain the list of films given an X rating, some of which of course include bondage. This is where I take a different tack from what Senator Mason said. The deletion of the word ' extreme' will not fix the problem at all. This document indicates that since 1 February no fewer than 171 films have been given the X rating. No film has been refused classification by the Film Censorship Board. One need only go through the reasons for the X ratings, which involve in the main matters of sex which are 'frequent, high and gratuitous'-and, as I said, in some cases involving bondage.

I wonder where the Office of Youth Affairs and the Office of the Status of Women are. What are they doing about it? I am conscious of the fact that there is a real concern amongst people with whom I do not share a great many views, such as the radical feminists. I understand that they do have a concern, though from a different point of view from me. Their point of view is that all men consider that women should be their slaves in any event, and this is just a manifestation of that in society. My concern is that to a certain extent it is the manifestation of those who engage in the production, distribution and sale of this material and it ought to be wiped out. It should not exist. One of the problems is that these regulations and the ordinance do not cover the production of this material in Australia or go to that particular problem in the Australian Capital Territory. If consideration were given to creating offences for the making of this sort of film obscenity, we might go some way towards solving this matter.

As my time has nearly expired, I come to another aspect of classifications. Nothing in these regulations gives the ordinary public the right to say what they think ought to go in the other classifications-for instance, what ought to go into the G or unrestricted classification, the PG, the M or the R classifications. This is a matter of concern to me because the document I have shows that a number of films classified M, as being suitable for persons over the age of 15 years, ought not to be. I, as a parent, have to ask myself whether this legislation, these regulations and the ordinance before us, would give sufficient protection to my children. They would not, and I believe that no parent would say they would. Because of technological advances, particularly videos, we have the situation where persons are invited to parties and after a couple of hours this sort of material is shown, unsolicited. Another aspect is that frequently PG video tapes are hired by parents, they sit down with their families and half way through there is a trailer for an R video. This is one of the real problems that many people complain about, and that problem can be overcome only by amendments to this legislation or by a new ordinance to cover it. I ask the Attorney-General to address his mind to that problem as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am doing so on Friday, Senator, if you don't disallow them.
—The Attorney might end up doing so on Friday but he has not done it yet.
—The answer is that it cannot be done; as a practical matter you have to rely on good comment.

—Of course it can be done, and I will tell the Attorney how to do it. However, I cannot do it now, in half a minute. The fact is that it is not enough. The Federal Government has a responsibility to enforce existing laws and then enact the further measures needed to protect Australians from this attack on society as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a motion to disallow the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations (Amendment) and the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations (Amendment), made under the Customs Act, and also to disallow the Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance. The main subject of the regulations and the ordinance which we have before us is the problem presented by the great upsurge of video material, either video tapes or, in its newer form, video discs; although most people are probably more familiar with video tapes at present. This problem has loomed for some time and has been the subject of a good deal of concern and attention by members of the public as well as by governments in Australia. The State and Federal Ministers responsible for censorship have had the matter under consideration for at least a couple of years. In July last year agreements was thought to have been reached by Federal and State Ministers--
—It wasn't.

—I said that it was thought to have been reached. This agreement by Federal and State Ministers was to have complimentary Federal and State legislation to govern this material so that throughout Australia there would be a uniform system, uniform laws, and to a large extent uniform administration of those laws. That is not to say that there are not already existing laws in relation to this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the old Customs film regulations video film was included under the definition of film and had to be registered by the Film Censorship Board before it could be legally imported. What that Board did not have the power to do was to give any classification to video films. It gives a classification to films for public viewing in cinemas. But that power was provided by State legislation. There was no similar State legislation in relation to video material.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could it refuse to register?

—Yes. The only power the Board had was to refuse registration. The film thereby became an illegal import. The regulation presented difficulties not so much in its content but in its administration. Senator Harradine dealt at some length with instructions that have been given to Customs officers about this sort of material and I do not propose to say anything more about that. Nevertheless, no matter how assiduous Customs officers may be or are encouraged to be in relation to this sort of material the fact is that it is very easily imported undetected. Once the disc or tape is brought in unlimited copies of it can be made. The material can also be made in Australia, in which case the Federal power relating to prohibition of imports of the material does not apply. Thus it has been felt for some time that the most satisfactory way of coping with this problem is to deal with it at the point of sale or distribution rather than at the point of importation.
—It could have been. They could have stopped the lot.

—I would like to be able to finish my argument. I did not interrupt Senator Harradine. As I was saying, the most satisfactory way is to have State laws and State administration of this matter at the point of sale or distribution. That is not to say that there should not be Federal laws in relation to the matter. There ought to be sound Federal laws prohibiting the importation of such material. The problem is to find the more effective way of administration of those laws. They are more efficiently administered at the point of sale or distribution, or even at the point of possession of such material. We have a problem in out Federal system in that responsibilities are divided between the Commonwealth and States. That is very hard for the public to understand but it is a problem that we in this Parliament have to try to understand when we pass laws in relation to these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, in July last year the Federal and State Ministers appeared to have reached an agreement for complementary State and Federal legislation in this matter. I fully support the notion that it is desirable that we should have such complementary Federal and State legislation. In a way I suppose uniformity of legislation throughout Australia may not be so important, although I think it is desirable. In this day and age Australians do not readily accept the notion that the legislation should be different in different States. That is the basis of the classification system for films for public viewing. What is important is that there should be uniform State laws governing the sale and distribution of this material. Again, that does not mean that there are no State laws in existence. There are State laws and depending upon the policies that are pursued by the States or by the police in various States quite successful action has been taken in some States against this sort of material. There are laws in the Australian Capital Territory as well.

Let us not look at this matter as though it is a choice of this legislation or nothing. It is simply that this proposed legislation is presented as part and parcel of a new scheme replacing existing laws which have been difficult to administer and about which there is some criticism as to their content. However, the new scheme to which the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) apparently has agreed has not yet been given effect by any legislature in Australia. The first step in the law-making in this area is by way of the regulations and the ordinance which is before us today. Those regulations were made by the Federal Government on 21 December and they came into effect as regulations and an ordinance on 1 February. But this is the first opportunity that the Parliament has had to express any views in relation to them. I think it is important that the Parliament has this opportunity today in relation to the motion before us to disallow these regulations.

The Opposition's view is that disallowance of the regulations and the ordinance is justified. We will support the motion to achieve that purpose, not because we do not believe that there should be complementary Federal and State legislation, but because we believe that the regulations and the ordinance have been made prematurely and that they really should be part and parcel of an Australia-wide scheme. At this stage it looks as though that scheme is in very considerable doubt if not in shambles. It is true that Commonwealth and State Ministers will meet on Friday to review the matter. Perhaps they will come to a better and more effective agreement than they seem to have come to last July.

The fact of the matter is that the Attorney-General and the Federal Government have rushed in and passed Federal regulations. The criticism that the Opposition has at this stage is that the Federal Government has rushed in and passed regulations at the Federal level before any complementary State legislation is in place and being effectively administered. The only complementary legislation is in the Australian Capital Territory with its Classification of Publications Ordinance. But in all the States either some interim legislation may have been passed or introduced or no changes have been made to the existing legislation. On 28 March the Attorney-General gave an answer to Senator Childs on this matter , in the course of which he said:
That system is now in place in the Australian Capital Territory domestically. It is imminent in Victoria, Western Australia and the Northern Territory, and it is in place in South Australia.
It is my understanding that South Australia has in place only interim legislation. In fact, the complementary legislation was rejected by the Upper House of the South Australian Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not so.
—I understand that to be the case. The Attorney-General went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The system is under active government consideration in New South Wales and Queensland.

The attitude of Tasmania is not stated. Perhaps Senator Bjelke-Petersen can tell us what Queensland intends to do in relation to this matter. It is doubtful that Queensland will pass similar legislation. New South Wales is an interesting case because in the course of the New South Wales election campaign, Premier Wran expressed considerable doubts about the way in which this matter would be dealt with. I would think that the participation of New South Wales in such a scheme would be very doubtful indeed. The Attorney-General says that South Australia has passed appropriate legislation. If that is the case, it is the only State that has complementary legislation in place. I do not know whether South Australia has in place any effective administration of that legislation.

The Opposition is very concerned at what has happened. The Federal Government has made substantial changes to the laws relating to the importation of this sort of material, resulting in its flooding into the country in much greater volume apparently than has occurred in the past. No State has enacted satisfactory legislation to deal with this situation; there is no State administration to deal with it either. The States have not even agreed that the classification of video tapes will be carried out by the Film Censorship Board. Apparently there is a possibility that the States will go their own way in classifying this material. So the whole situation is a real shambles. When the State and Federal Attorneys-General meet on Friday they should sort out the mess that has arisen, on the one hand, by the excessive zeal on the part of the Federal Government in introducing premature legislation and, on the other hand, by the complete disarray, as far as I can see, caused by the inaction of most of the States in expressing their attitudes and intentions in relation to this scheme.

For those reasons alone the Opposition believes that these Federal regulations are premature and should be withdrawn or disallowed. It believes that whatever scheme is finally agreed upon should be introduced at the Federal and State level at the same time. Once the laws are in place, effective administration of those laws will occur. That is not the case at present. Quite honestly, it does not look as though that position will be achieved for some time yet, if ever.

I shall now deal with some other concerns that have arisen in relation to the scheme. Although the principle of having complementary State and Federal legislation is a sound one, the scheme seeks to make some major changes in the approach to censorship. One of the scheme's failings is that it does not provide for compulsory classification of this sort of material. Some material is banned completely from importation, and there- fore would not be available for sale or distribution. Material that is not banned from importation is not required to be submitted by the distributors for classification. Regardless of whether one agrees with the system of having an X certificate, material of that sort is not compulsorily classified. The Opposition's view is that that is another major weakness in the scheme and is an aspect that the Attorneys-General should reconsider when they meet on Friday. At present distributors can take their chances under the old laws of obscenity. Once a distributor gets a classification he can use that as a shield against being prosecuted under the censorship laws. If he does not seek a classification the old laws of obscenity apply, and he takes his chances under those laws. It is undesirable that that situation should persist if a new code is to be brought into being. The Attorney -General says that the reason that situation applies is that the Government has not wanted to impose unnecessary administrative requirements and costs because there is no need for films such as Donald Duck and others of that nature to be classified.

TALK.START.PARA: —Reducing public expenditure; have you considered that?
—That is a very important aspect that I have considered, but I understand that very little extra cost would be involved.

—Yes, it is peanuts. But the difficulty is, of course, that much of this sort of material that might carry the title 'Donald Duck' is in fact pornographic. Anyway, there is still the desirability of providing guidance to those who buy this material. I think the small public expenditure that would be involved in having compulsory classification would be well justified.

SPEECH.PARA: No doubt the matters referred to by Senator Mason in his speech will be the subject of further debate today. He dealt with the new Customs regulations that replace those that have been in existence for many years and that provide for the material that is to be banned. Material that is prohibited by these regulations becomes an illegal import. That principle is to be carried through to State legislation so that such material will not be able to be classified and thereby become available for sale or distribution under the scheme. The new regulations change considerably the old rules that have been administered successfully for many years by the Film Censorship Board. The Board has been attuned to changes in community standards. As the High Court has said, in censorship matters, community standards can govern the meaning of words. To some people some words may seem to be old fashioned. The Attorney-General has a great desire at all times to be with it and to change legislation for the sake of change. It is my view that in this case such changes are unnecessary because the old regulations have been administered sensibly and in accordance with the powers that the High Court has said are available.

The new regulations have given rise to considerable concern and doubt, and Senator Mason has drawn attention to one of the major concerns. However, other concerns have been expressed about the new regulations. I do not believe for one minute that if Senator Mason's criticism were met by an amendment that would solve the problem. Certainly the sort of amendment that could be adopted by this chamber would not solve the problem because it would simply have the effect of amending a regulation. As I understand it, that is not possible under the Acts Interpretation Act.
The regulations say that certain publications are banned. Banned publications include those which, in the opinion of the Attorney-General or a person authorised by him:
depict in pictorial form a child, whether engaged in sexual activity or otherwise . . . that is likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult person.

Clearly, child pornography is banned. Secondly, publications include those which 'promote, incite or encourage terrorism'. Clearly, such material is banned. Thirdly, banned publications include those which:
gratuitously depict in pictorial form extreme violence or cruelty, especially when combined with any sexual element, to the extent they should not be imported ;

That is really a muddle, a jumble and a mish-mash if ever there were one. It is quite impossible to understand what the words 'to the extent they should not be imported' mean. It seems to mean that there has to be extreme violence before material which is of a sexually violent nature can be banned. I do not know whether that is the intention. Certainly, sexual violence itself, whether it is extreme or not, should be banned. There needs to be a redrafting of this section to make at least that point perfectly clear. I do not think that it will be perfectly clear by taking out the word 'extreme'. In fact, by taking out the word 'extreme' we will probably ban some material which is violent, but which does not involve sexual violence, is going a lot further than the censorship laws have gone in relation to violence in recent years. Whether one likes it or not, there are a number of violent scenes in films which have R or even M certificates. I do not think this problem can be overcome by taking out the word 'extreme' before 'violence'. I believe the whole section needs to be recast. The section has to emphasise clearly that material which portrays sexual violence in any form should be banned. As I have said, the Senate does not have the power to amend the regulations to do that here and now. The matter will have to be rethought and discussed by the Ministers when they meet on Friday.

There are other problems with these regulations. I believe there needs to be more clearly expressed the provision relating to the banning of material which may incite people to take or misuse drugs. I do not think that subject is adequately dealt with.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is already in the current regulations.

—Yes. If these regulations are dissallowed the old regulations will be revived and the Film Censorship Board will retain its powers which it has exercised in a very responsible and sensible manner for many years. The situation will improve if these regulations are disallowed because the Board will be able to make judgments, as I said, in the reasonable way it has in the past in relation to both video material and material for public viewing.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other matters which could be the subject of discussion, in this debate, and no doubt they will be. When a country has a classification system there is always debate as to what should be given an R rating or an M rating. If a country has an X rating there is debate about what ought to be put in an X rating. The most important question of all is what material will be completely banned. It should be said, in fairness to the new scheme where an X rating is available, that it does not mean there is a completely open slather. As I said, a large amount of material will be banned completely. Much of the material about which people are concerned will never get an X rating, much less an R rating or an M rating.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been none so far.

—I was interested in what the honourable senator said. I have seen material which the Film Censorship Board has said it would ban or has banned. It is clear that if it is left to the Film Censorship Board a great deal of material will be banned. I do not know what will happen in the States. A lot of the material-in fact, most of the material-about which people are worried will not be classified. When I say 'will not be classified', I indicate that if the material escapes the importation net it may still circulate because people may take a chance, under a voluntary scheme of classification, that they will not be caught or successfully prosecuted under the obscenity laws. For all those reasons the Opposition believes these regulations are premature. The regulations require further consideration and amendment. When the Ministers meet on Friday-I do not think they will solve the matter in one meeting-they should proceed to get their own act together before Federal legislation is put in place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the occurrence of this debate. Obviously there has been a significant and mounting degree of public interest in the whole question of censorship. Equally, there has been a lot of misapprehension and misunderstanding about what is involved in the new scheme. There has been misunderstanding about what is happening and a degree of confusion as to the appropriate principles which are being applied and which should be applied. This debate does give us an opportunity-it gives the Government an opportunity-perhaps to untangle some of those misapprehensions and misunderstandings.

SPEECH.PARA: What I want to do is four things: First of all, to explain the nature of the problem as it was confronted by governments around the country when we sat down to thrash this out last year; secondly, to describe the solution which we agreed to in principle at the meeting of Ministers responsible for censorship last July and to describe the way in which these regulations, which are the subject of disallowance motions today, fit within that total package; thirdly, to respond to some of the particular criticisms that have been made in the course of this debate and the particular proposals for amendment in due course of the regulations in question; and, finally, to express the view that at the conclusion of the debate today we should adjourn the debate rather than put the disallowance motions to a vote so that the views expressed by the Senate today can be taken into account at the ministerial council meeting which is due to be held for the first time in nearly a year this coming Friday and so that I can bring back on behalf of the Government to the Senate, before the expiry of the present disallowance period-there are another 11 parliamentary sitting days within which these motions can be considered-a considered response to the particular criticisms and queries that have been raised here today and can do so in an environment in which we are not hamstrung by the operation, as I will explain, of the Acts Interpretation Act which does, I believe, place a very considerable constraint on getting a rational system into place.

I return to the beginning: What was the nature of the problem as we experienced it and as we confronted it when the Ministers from all around the country met last year? I think that the starting point which has been, if not universally accepted certainly accepted by the Australian Labor Party, the Australian Democrats and the Liberals in their stated public policy, and from which principles I would hate to see us retreating here today, is as follows: It is generally accepted that adults should be entitled to read, hear and see what they wish and in public subject to two things: First, adequate provisions to ensure that persons will not be exposed to unsolicited material offensive to them and, second, by adequate provisions to prevent conduct which will exploit or which is detrimental to the interests of children.

It is probably fair to say that in addition to those basic principles, which have been articulated by all the major parties and have been generally accepted ever since Senator Chipp made his contributions to the enlightenment of our censorship laws in the late 1960s, there are a couple of additional principles that now weigh heavily and did weigh heavily in our perception of what needed to be done when we discussed this last year.

Those two principles are these: The consumer protection principle that as much guidance as possible ought to be given to consumers about what they are buying or hiring in this particular area and, secondly, but a little more difficult to articulate, there is a general view that quite apart from the situation of children there is in principle something extremely offensive, and justifying bans in particular cases, about material which is exploitative in a highly significant way or involves the brutalisation of adults, be they men or women, apart from children. There is a general feeling that there is an additional category of legitimate restraint bearing upon that area. I will come back to that.

We were confronting a situation in which Australia has moved out of the Dark Ages of intolerance of the 1960s where generally through the 1970s, censorship had pretty much ceased to be an issue in this country, with a broadly uniform response by legislatures and governments around the country about the way in which the system as it had evolved was being administered. Certainly this was true and has continued to be true so far as written and pictorial material in the form of paper publications are concerned. With some exceptions, there has continued to be a pretty broad consensus about the approach to be adopted in this respect, with the task really remaining only to complete the process of the rationalisation of administration, the clarification of classification standards and, as a further problem, to bring the law and practice into line particularly so far as Customs officers and Customs practice were concerned. Without going into any more detail than that, there was not really seen to be, nor has there been from anything said in the debate so far-I have no doubt Senator Walters and others will want to canvass this area also-any significant problem now with regard to the operation of point of sale controls and classification controls for literature, printed and pictorial matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a lot of problems with that.

—There may be some problems but we think we are close to resolving them in a satisfactory way by the 'Category 1' and 'Category 2' censorship system which I will describe in a moment as being the currently agreed solution. So far as videotapes are concerned, undoubtedly there is a problem, or there was a problem as we perceived it last year and which was acknowledged as such in public debate generally. That problem is of a different order of magnitude. It had become clear by the middle of last year that the pre- existing controls that operate in the kind of legislation which will be restored to life if this disallowance motion is passed here today, governing both the importation of this material and controlling it at point of sale or hire, were in practice not operating as controls at all. Everyone in the governmental arena was saying that it was everyone else's business. Neither the law nor the practical on-the-ground administration was responding. As a result an absolute flood of this material, of varying degrees of salaciousness, unattractiveness and unacceptability, was circulating in the country and rapidly exploding with the rapid explosion in the use of video cassettes.

SPEECH.PARA: So far as importation was concerned there were notional controls in the pre- existing Regulation 4A of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations but these were very obviously easy to beat. What we are talking about here is not the delivery to Australia of container loads of taped material, but tapes coming in in ones and twos, often in the luggage of individuals entering the country in the ordinary way as passengers and as a result not subject to any systematic scrutiny by Customs officers, even if they had been so minded to do so for what they would perceive to be personal material. As a result those tapes were then able to be used as master tapes to sire the multiplicity of copies which were then put into distribution networks in Australia. The barrier controls were simply not working under the pre-existing rules, nor are they ever likely to work given the nature of the technology involved in this area.

Equally, so far as the compulsory registration of film material coming in was concerned, a system that was essentially designed for films for public screening was also being technically made applicable to films that were solely for home use. But the distributors of the material for home use were simply refusing to submit this kind of material for classification in the knowledge that the Film Censorship Board, armed as it was with its previous powers, without any capacity to certify an X category but simply limited to public distribution criteria, would not be able to allow the material through.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not Janet Strickland's view.

—Under the existing rules there is no way in which the public exhibition criteria can accommodate X rating, let alone the more extreme categories about which we all agree. As such, if we accept, as the majority of people in this chamber seem to do, the desirability of there being for home use, for private use, for non-public screening an X rated category for the harder material but that which is not out of court completely, we have to acknowledge that the pre-existing import and registration regulations were not good enough to accommodate that practical desire. As a result, the market and the community being what it is, the law was treated, and will no doubt go on being treated if it re-establishes itself as the law, with complete irreverence. Nobody was taking any notice of it. The police forces around the country, which had the further opportunity to apply the law on the ground and using the usual obscenity provisions, were simply not prepared in any jurisdiction to take that step because they acknowledged that community standards and attitudes had changed to the point where people wanted that kind of X rated material to be available for home use.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that that is not a universally accepted view and that Senator Walters, Senator Harradine and others, the Festival of Light and, it also seems, the militant ends of the feminist movement, do not accept those sorts of arguments about the legitimacy of even an X-rated category. But, to the extent that most people in the community seem to have accepted that as they have with literature and other pictoral material, we had a community problem that was not being solved by the existing regulations and nor can it be. I do not understand the Australian Democrats to be dissenting from that appreciation of the situation.

Equally, so far as the point of sale or hire controls under the pre-existing situation were concerned, there was nothing of the kind in existence anywhere. There was no requirement for separate areas for keeping this material, no requirement for under-the-counter sale and no effective limitations on its sale to minors. We simply had a de facto open slather system operating. It is true that there was the capacity for obscenity laws to be wheeled in and used in a particular case, but in a framework that had not been properly thought through to accommodate the kind of material that was in fact flooding the community. Without going into any more detail, we had a real problem with the necessity for some kind of sensible regulated solution which was put in place in accordance with the criteria that I have identified as being those until now have enjoyed general if not universal acceptance.

What then was the solution agreed to by the censorship Ministers? I say 'agreed to' in the knowledge that we had the agreement in principle of those Ministers attending. In some instances it was made clear that this was only an agreement to take the matter back to the governments concerned and that what was said and agreed at that meeting could not be regarded as necessarily binding completely of all the governments concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —When was that?

—That was the meeting in July last year, following which the scheme was announced. Some governments have continued to reserve their rights on it-Tasmania in particular, as Senator Harradine or Senator Durack said . They had reservations about the compulsory systems concerned. Queensland certainly had all sorts of reservations. But no government, either then or subsequently, has rejected outright the uniform approach that was adopted and agreed to in principle at that time. The process since then has been one of putting in place, inevitably in a gradual and piecemeal fashion, the substance of that agreement. Indeed, that process is working out very well. The meeting that is being held on Friday is to review where we are all at and to thrash out some problems which manifestly still remain.

SPEECH.PARA: The primary rationale of the agreed solution was this: To acknowledge the difficulty, indeed impossibility, of import controls in relation to this material and to devise a system in which the real controls operated effectively at the point of sale using only the import powers to deal with or to exclude, in those circumstances where it was detected, which it is acknowledged would not be all that often, the really extreme and utterly unconscionable material. So what we had was agreement to the amendment of the two import regulations now before the Senate. The system of regulation of film material is to be confined in future to films for public screening. It has always been the case that there needs to be a compulsory classification of this material. So be it; that will continue. But everything else-video tapes and all other forms of publications- was to be treated in the same way, essentially, in principle at the Customs barrier. The material was to be allowed in on the assumption that the real controls would operate domestically and the only controls that would operate at the barrier were those three basic categories of really extreme and unconscionable material which has been referred to in debate; namely, child pornography, material which incites to terrorism or material which comes into the third category about which there is this controversy and about which I will say something more in a moment-that is, gratuitously depicting extreme violence or cruelty, particularly in circumstances involving a sexual element.

In relation to the domestic package of legislation, it was agreed that there ought to be a nationally uniform classification system with the Commonwealth running that system through its departmental officers in relation to literature with some regional or State variations as has always been the case and, in relation to video material, the Film Censorship Board doing the classification according to, so far as possible, nationally agreed uniform classification standards with the further element in the package being that each State would legislate to establish appropriate point of sale controls for each category of material; namely, no controls at all for the unrestricted material, with a system of controls governing sale to minors and non-access to public display and so on, with those controls increasing as we move up through the scale with, finally, a category of refused classification altogether which would be the subject of prosecution under obscenity laws if material which was refused classification was nonetheless put on sale or hired out.

So far as legislation was concerned, the categories established for literature were to be four-fold: Unrestricted, Category 1-which is Australian Playboy type of material-Category 2, which is hard core material manifestly unacceptable to many Australians and of a kind which certainly ought not to be on public display or sold to minors but which, nonetheless, ought not to be, under these principles, restricted altogether; and, finally, the category of material Refused Classification, which would essentially be back to our descriptions of child pornography, terrorism and other really extreme material of that kind, although with a rather looser catch-all definition so far as literature is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can change all of that.

—I will use the expression 'unconscionable' rather than ' extreme' in order to convey the flavour of what I am saying. I am really indicating what the nature of the solution was and what the agreement of Ministers has been. The agreement in relation to videos was essentially to adopt legislation in each jurisdiction with the Commonwealth, through the Australian Capital Territory, leading the way in conjunction with South Australia, whose views are already well advanced in this respect, and that the system of classification for video material would go through the different categories from category G, to PG-or parental guidance-to M, to R, which roughly corresponds with the cinema classifications with which we are all familiar, with the additional categorisation of X for the harder core material which is roughly equivalent to Category 2 in relation to literature. That would apply to material that would never be certified for public screening under existing ground rules but which arguably is appropriate in the privacy of people's own homes if they wish to see it. The final category would then be the 'refused' category, which takes us back to child pornography, terrorism and other utterly unconscionable material in some residual third category, particularly that involving overt violence and brutalisation of a kind which is simply unacceptable. That is the scheme as it has been adopted.

SPEECH.PARA: The classification were to be voluntary rather than compulsory. That has been much misunderstood around the place. I still believe that the voluntary system is a workable one on the basis, as Senator Durack, I think, described it, that if the material, be it literature or videos, is classified and it is given a classification, be it Category 2 or R or X as the case may be, then the distributor of that material is immune from prosecution under obscenity laws.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the record, do you mind defining 'voluntary'?

—It is voluntary in the sense that a person would not be subject to a penalty if he did not submit the material for classification and if it is found in his shop without the appropriate stamp on it. It is voluntary in the sense that there is no obligation upon that person. However, the idea as it would operate in practice is that there would be a massive incentive to classify that material which is at the hard end of the spectrum and within the potential zone of prosecution for obscenity. If it is classified and it gets an R or an X or, in the case of literature, it gets a category 2 classification, one is immune from prosecution. If it is submitted for classification and it is refused a classification because it is in that end zone of impossibly unconscionable material and one then put it on display, then one is exposed to prosecution.
—Do you not see a massive incentive there not to submit?

—That has not been the experience so far. However, let met come quickly to the point: To the extent that people do not submit their material for classification and put stuff on display which perhaps would be classified as X but they have not gone through the process, they are still exposing themselves to the risk of prosecution. That was the scheme. I emphasise what it is about in order that it be understood that this is not some sort of totally light weight attempt to avoid really doing anything serious about the enforcement of this law on the ground. The intention was to have the law being enforced and operating very effectively on the ground. It was just the belief that it was not necessary for every video tape or every piece of literature to be classified, particularly the stuff at the general exhibition end of the scale , in order to impose the kind of controls which people thought, understandably, were necessary. It just was not necessary to classify everything in order to secure the result of the material not being put on display at the hard end of the scale.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a lot of debate in South Australia and in every other jurisdiction since that decision was made last July. Neville Wran and others have made it clear that they believe that perhaps something more rigorous than that needs to be done, not only from the point of view of satisfying a community demand for the appearance of action, rather than just the fact of action, but also with a view to giving-this is a perfectly understandable proposition-better consumer guidance to parents at the lower end of the scale as well. The argument is that consumers, parents in particular, want guidance between the G and the parental guidance, PG category, and the M category which would not be the sort of thing likely-

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the trailers?

—The question of trailers can be accommodated better under a compulsory system as well. I readily acknowledge that. With all those thoughts in mind-the desire for better consumer guidance, and the desire to be seen to be operating effectively against the harder core end of the spectrum even if in practice it would not make much difference-I think there has been a move since last July towards the compulsory system. I undertake to take to the ministerial council meeting on Friday what I perceive to be the clear majority view of this Senate in favour of a compulsory classification system. I think, probably, that is now the majority view among the States. Certainly, having looked at the question myself much more carefully and thought of the ways in which the compulsory system might operate, I see a number of advantages in it which I was less persuaded about in the middle of last year. So on that basis I simply indicate that that is the way I think the debate is going, that is the way the legislation I think is likely to be amended as part of a national scheme. I am not in a position to give any firm undertaking about that now because it is something that I need to discuss and debate with my fellow Ministers on Friday. But I give that signal.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me respond to some of the other matters that have been raised in argument and are clearly giving rise to concern. I have responded already to the compulsory versus voluntary argument and I think there is little more I can say about that. Let me, however, say something about Senator Mason's and the Australian Democrats' desire to remove the expression 'extreme' from Customs regulation 4A. I make it clear at the outset that I share, and I am sure everyone in this chamber would share, that distaste which Senator Mason has expressed towards that gratuitous peculiarly nasty mindless form of violence which has become quite endemic in the context of video tapes and clearly, in the context of video tapes, is of much greater impact than similar sorts of things being depicted in pictorial form in magazines ever was. Anyone who has seen films, as I have, at the Film Censorship Board's office like Maniac, Texas Chain Saw Massacre or some of these other bits of nastiness could find no redeeming social virtue in that material and, indeed, there are all sorts of reasons for supposing that no community could tolerate the circulation of that material in any form. So I make it clear that I am with those who acknowledge the existence of a category of material which is brutalising and without any redeeming social justification. I have no doubt that such a category--

TALK.START.PARA: —'Gratuitous' in a word.
—More than gratuitous because gratuitous violence can occur in a context where it is fleeting, insubstantial--
—How does that fit with your view about seeing and reading what you like?

—If the honourable senator were listening very carefully to what I was saying instead of just drafting his next contribution to this debate he would have heard me say that seeing and reading what one likes has traditionally, in the views of the parties, been qualified by two principles-one , non-exposure involuntarily to material that one finds offensive and, secondly, a concern about exploitation of children. I said that in addition to that there were two further considerations which clearly were being, although not addressed in the parties' policies, taken into account and which I acknowledge the force of. One of those extra things was the consumer protection concept and the second one was this notion of an unconscionable category of exploitative material which is not directed against children but against adults but which is no less impossible to accept for that reason.
—How did the X rated fit in?

—I am coming to that in a moment, if the honourable senator will allow me to, because that is his argument. I am dealing at the moment with the way in which the description of material which should be refused classification should be addressed. What Senator Mason says is that the word ' extreme' should come out of the formula that appears in Customs regulation 4A so that it simply talks in terms of violence rather than extreme violence. So the regulation would be worded something like: 'Gratuitously depict in pictorial forms violence or cruelty, especially when combined with any sexual element to the extent that the material should not be imported'. I do not see any particular difficulty about accepting that. If the concept of 'extremeness' is thought to be pushing the matter too far and that there ought to be a greater room for the exercise of discretion in a particular case in this area, I acknowledge the force of that proposition. I appreciate the weight of the views that have been expressed. I have discussed this with the Customs people who have to administer this regulation. It is generally accepted that the word 'extreme' does not add anything significant to the flavour that is sought to be addressed here and may indeed take something away from it. I give a clear undertaking to the Senate that I will post haste secure an amendment of the regulation in order to accommodate that concern.
—Post haste?
—There may be other better ways of expressing it. One formula that has been suggested--
—Can you get that up today or tomorrow?

—I think that is possible. I would prefer to wait until the meeting on Friday if it is possible because there may be some better formula. I am certainly prepared to do it by tomorrow if that is the price of buying the honourable senator's lousy vote, with respect. But there is a more rational and adult way in which we can approach this. I take into account the sort of thing that was said by Senator Durack. It may be that there is a better way of expressing the whole formula rather than just removing one word to better get at what Senator Mason and I are concerned to get at. An example is the formula suggested by Janet Strickland which she puts in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Detailed and gratuitous depictions of acts of significant cruelty; explicit depictions of sexual violence against non-consenting persons.

It may be that that kind of language gets at better what we are all about than the existing formula with the removal of the word 'extreme'. I would like just a little more opportunity to consider what the appropriate form of words might be. But I certainly undertake that if the existing formula were maintained we would move quickly to remove from it the word 'extreme'.
In the two minutes available to me I did want to say something more--

TALK.START.PARA: —I will move an extension for you.
—Well, I would appreciate that.
—Would you clarify that point, Minister? Something could be done about it today or tomorrow perhaps.

—Well, I am happy to do it by tomorrow as an interim solution to the extent that it can logistically be done to get rid of the word ' extreme', but I would have thought it was in all our interests to allow the matter to be debated on Friday and have the matter before the Senate--
—This is really to secure a lousy vote.
—You will do anything for the Democrats but not for us.
—I will come to reasons why we should not disallow these motions later on.
—This is real sincerity!

—This is the legislative process at work, as sordid as Senator Walters may find it from her position on the back bench. Regrettably, that is what it is all about and that is what we ought to acknowledge.
—What is wrong with what he has done? He is being reasonable.

—I am trying to accommodate the concern which I understand because I am familiar with that category of material which I believe ought not to be acceptable in any system of classification. I am trying to get agreement about the best way of expressing that and to indicate the way in which I am prepared to move. I hope on further thought and perhaps further discussion outside this chamber we can get some understanding about that. (Extension of time granted) I thank honourable senators, and I will do my best not to go on for longer than is strictly necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think there is any more I can usefully say about the word 'extreme' in that particular formula. What I do want to say something about, however, is the more sweeping objection that has been expressed by Senator Harradine, and no doubt will be expressed by Senator Walters and others, not just to that material which is in the refused classification category but to the whole concept of X ratings of material. As I understand it, there is a very real concern about the X ratings as such and the concept of simply what might be described as hard core pornography. Let us leave out hard core pornography plus violence or that very unconscionable form of violence that we have just been discussing and concentrate on simply hard sexual material of a kind that would not traditionally be allowed to be screened publicly in cinemas and ask ourselves what is the justification for allowing this material to be circulated for viewing by adults in the privacy of their homes and not banned outright as it traditionally has been.

TALK.START.PARA: —Objectionable material.
—Objectionable material which is beyond the traditional R limits so far as cinema classifications are concerned.
—By definition of 'objectionable publication' in your ordinance.

—I accept that. It is material which most people in the community may well find revolting, distasteful, vulgar or unacceptable for one reason or another but in respect of which there has been, up until now, a view, certainly so far as literature is concerned, that it ought to be allowed to be purchased and read in the privacy of the home subject to the qualifications we have been talking about.
—But there is no law that forces people to hire something, take it home and then get shocked out of their cotton pickn' minds, is there?

—There is not, indeed, and that is exactly what we are talking about-the desirability of people being able, in the privacy of their homes, to look at such material however distasteful the rest of us might find that material to be. I think it is important here to appreciate the extent to which personal taste does come into this. The best line in this respect is that quoted by Adele Horin in a splendid article in the National Times last weekend. The article quoted the American feminist writer Ellen Willis to the effect: ' What turns me on is erotic; what turns you on is pornographic'.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been all too much of that kind of rather sanctimonious distinction being drawn in many of the public debates so far. There is an element of what can only be described as a new puritanism abroad when we have seen a rather unholy alliance of the traditional reactionary viewpoint about censorship combined with a much more recent and much more understandable phenomenon. I refer to those people who are particularly concerned with the status of women and who are particularly anxious to ensure that women are not exploited or treated as objects, to use the terminology of Senator Harradine earlier in this debate.

What can be said about that? I think quite a deal. I have not time to say it now, but I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard half a dozen paragraphs from the article by Adele Horin in the National Times.

TALK.START.PARA: —I read it but cannot accept it. It was hopeless.
—You cannot accept incorporation of this article in Hansard ?
—Yes, I can; everybody will then see how ridiculous it is.
—Let me read a paragraph to capture the flavour of it, in order that the substance of it can be accepted, without my wasting the time of the Senate by reading the whole of it:

SPEECH.PARA: For many feminists it has been a quick step from loathing what they see on the video to crying out for the censor. The philosophical problem with censorship is that we entrust a few adults to tell the rest of us what we can see or read.

It goes on to describe the way in which censorship has traditionally been used in many respects against women in the context of information about contraception , and sexual dissidents of various kinds. It points out the philosophical contradictions-this is the traditional libertarian argument-involved in any attempt to ban material simply on the ground that you or I might find that material distasteful or offensive. I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of those few paragraphs in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

For many feminists it has been a quick step from loathing what they see on the video to crying out for the censor. The philosophical problem with censorship is that we entrust a few adults to tell the rest of us what we can see or read.

In the past censorship has been used against women-information about contraception was banned; sexual dissidents-the blighted William Chidley with his mad but harmless ideas and pamphlets was hounded to his death; and free thinkers. Only two years ago our current chief censor Janet Strickland banned the brilliant Brazilian film Pixote, a ruling later overturned. (Now film festivals, attended by the well-to-do, are exempted from normal censorship procedures.)

If films which women find offensive are banned, should not films which Jews or blacks find offensive, or which practising Catholics or animal lovers or pacifists find offensive, be banned also? The Human Rights Commission is already suggesting that writing or uttering a facist remark be an offence, acting on the same dangerous impulse that we punish minorities for what they say, or write, or film, when the measure of a free society is that minorities can think and say what they like.

To ban anything that does not show the world as some of us would like it to be- to ban the depiction of women as ''objects and commodities'', or themes of '' sexual subordination'' for example, which figure in much feminist literature, would be to do away with half the trash on television and in the cinemas, and half the sexist newspapers and magazines. Yet no-one seriously advocates this degree of State interference.

In the US, where the First Amendment to the Constitution guarantees free speech , the Women Against Pornography are more cognisant of the dangers of censorship than their Australian sisters. ''We do not advocate censorship. We respect the First Amendment stricture against imposition of prior restraint on any form of speech,'' their leaflets state.

Feminists here concede that banning pornography will not even begin to attack the reasons why so many men hate and oppress women. And they work on many other fronts to end sexism and violence against women. Yet they still appeal, as the puritans have always appealed, to the censor.

Most pornography is sexist, yet can be a source of erotic pleasure to men and women. Not all pornography, however, is violent. Some 95 per cent of it, according to Janet Strickland, shows both parties getting sexual pleasure. It is the five per cent, where the woman is unwilling and is brutalised to boot that sickens.

To protest that kind of pornography, to raise people's consciousness about sexist sex, to ensure men are punished for assaulting and raping women is one thing. But to define all pornography as the enemy and to ban what adults watch in their homes strikes me as a kneejerk reaction to the perplexing realities of pornography.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other point of view that I think neatly summarises the objections to a particular strand in this debate is that of Anne Brooksbank who, in an issue of Cinema Papers a year or so ago, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Censorship cuts both ways. If you believe that films should not be made about certain subjects, you must, therefore, believe that the people who are to see them are too stupid or deliberately blind or too ill-informed, to make up their own minds about those films. That's the basis of most male dictatorships over the centuries. I don't think the female version is any more attractive.

That is a neat and succinct way of putting a viewpoint that I think sometimes gets lost in this perfectly understandable concern about the way in which pornography of the traditional hard core kind can be regarded as exploitative or degrading in its treatment of women.

There are a lot of issues that need to be addressed in any serious debate about the banning outright of that kind of material. What do the feminists or those concerned with the protection of women against this sort of exploitation say about videos and other materials depicting gay sex? What do they say about hard core pornography-95 per cent of it in Janet Strickland's analysis-which demonstrates both partners having a joyous and pleasurable time as distinct from a brutalising or humiliating time so far as one of the partners is concerned? What is one to say about that? Is that material for that reason, because some of us may nonetheless find it distasteful, to be banned outright?

What is to be said in response to those who would argue about the therapeutic utility of some of this material? What is to be said to those-I have had some moving correspondence on this topic in the last year or so-who are too ugly, too physically unattractive, or ill, or incapable as a result of paraplegia-inducing accidents, or something of that kind, to be able to enjoy normal sexual relations? What is to be said in response to those people who argue-I wish I could find one or two of the letters, because they are quite moving-about the very real utility to them of this kind of material in living out, perhaps in a fantasy kind of way, experiences which are perhaps available to others of us in the community? What kind of a dictatorship are we seeking to impose in relation to those people? This is, of course, what this X category is all about-material which cannot by its very nature be put on public display because people would be involuntarily exposed to it and many offended by it, material which cannot be sold to children for all sorts of obvious and familiar reasons, but material which is nonetheless of a character that it ought to be available to the community, I would argue and many others would argue, on traditional libertarian grounds and also on the other grounds I have mentioned. That is the kind of argument that needs a lot more debate than we have time for now.

Let me finally say a few words as to why I would urge that this debate at the end of the day-I do not want to cut the debate short in any way-should be adjourned rather than be resolved by any number-crunching exercise in disallowance. A whole variety of attitudes, views and particular criticisms have been expressed here today which I believe not only can be taken into account by the Ministers who will be meeting on Friday but also will and should be taken into account. I have already indicated a couple of ways involving the definition of the residual category and the compulsory versus voluntary system aspects of it in which I think there will be real sensitivity to the points of view which have been expressed in this debate.

All I ask is that, given that we have 11 further sitting days in which to resolve these disallowance motions before that option becomes unavailable to the Senate, the Senate should give me the opportunity to take back to the ministerial council meeting on Friday the substance of this debate so that I may obtain a reaction from that Ministerial council to the particular matters here raised with a view to my coming back to the Senate, well before the expiry of the 11 sitting days deadline, with proposals for appropriate amendment to this package of regulations. The difficulty is that if the Senate does not allow me to do that, if it insists on disallowing these regulations here today, there are very real practical difficulties about re-introducing, within a reasonable time, the existing package of legislation, even in a significantly modified form.

There are two kinds of difficulties. One relates to Senate standing order 133 which prohibits a further regulation coming forward which is substantially the same as that which has been disallowed. If there is any significant modification at all of the regulations in issue here, there is unlikely to be difficulty among us in the application of that standing order. But that is not the end of the matter. There is a second barrier which is a much more formidable and much more disconcerting one, and that is the barrier posed by section 49 of the Acts Interpretation Act which says that once a regulation has been disallowed it cannot be brought back unless-

TALK.START.PARA: —Unless.
—Yes, unless. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . no regulation, being the same in substance as the regulation so disallowed . . . shall be made within 6 months . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the 'unless'.
—Read the next bit.
—Yes, unless the Parliament chooses to rescind it, and so on.
—Don't just wipe that off.
—Come on. Don't try to pull the wool over our eyes.

—Before honourable senators go down that particular track, may I remind them of the implications of doing so. There are two sorts of problems. One relates to the Customs side and the other to the Australian Capital Territory side. So far as the Australian Capital Territory is concerned one would throw immediately into doubt the status of the 2,000-odd video tapes which have been classified under the existing system and about which there is no dispute, but as to the status of which tapes there may be very real anxiety. The difficulty as I see it is this: There is a problem about the application of section 49 which is a matter not for us to resolve but for the courts to resolve , and so there must be uncertainty. That leaves the only way of securing certainty-for the rescission motion procedure to be here applied; for the Senate , if satisfied about the amendments I am proposing, to move an appropriate rescission motion in relation to the regulations. The difficulty, in turn, about that, as I understand it-unless people have thought this through better than I have been able to do-is whether it would bounce back into life from the original date of application the particular regulations that we are dealing with here and now. What happens if we disallow these regulations today?
—The old ones are revived.
—The old ones are revived with all their difficulties, and there is no good pretending that they were not giving rise to difficulties.
—Yes, but you did not implement them.

—Nor would the Customs officers implement them, or be able to implement them, because of their extraordinary vagueness. There are many reasons why the old regulations simply were not workable. But beyond the problem about reinstating unworkable Customs regulations and Australian Capital Territory regulations which totally lack any provision for point of sale control , one also has the problem of throwing into doubt the legal status of a whole number of things which have been done during the currency of the present resolution. If our present motion carries and the regulations now before the Senate are disallowed, what will happen is that the previous law will spring back to life and presumably that which has been done under the existing regulation now before the Senate will be put into some kind of limbo zone. If in a week or two, or three or four weeks' time, the disallowance motion now passed today were in turn to be rescinded, there is a rather fascinating question as to what then happens to the regulations that have been operative since 1 February. I do not think this question has ever been addressed, and I would welcome some advice on it. Would it not honestly be fairer and cleaner all round simply to reserve all the options which are now available to honourable senators until we meet again, when the Senate resumes? Honourable senators will have lost nothing in terms of the status of the existing capacity to disallow. They will have lost nothing in that respect.
—We are getting hungry, Gareth.

—Okay. I put the point as clearly as I can. I am happy to respond to any other interjections, but I just finish on this point: The Government will respond to the concerns which have been expressed. We will take them seriously. We will bring back some amendments which I believe will certainly be enough to satisfy the concerns that have been expressed by the Democrats, whether or not they are enough to satisfy the concerns of everybody else. I believe that is the way to go, to put this matter on hold until then, to leave everybody's options open. If a disallowance motion is passed today not only will all the uncertainty, about what the law is, be created for the interim period, but the uncertainty of those events which have transpired over the past few weeks, since this legislation has been in force, will be thrown into real doubt. That is simply not a rational solution.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate in his capacity as both Minister representing the Prime Minister and Minister representing the Minister for Communications.
