—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I ask: Are Australian citizens posted overseas by private employers for extended periods on full pay covered by Medicare while they are overseas? If not, are they still required to pay the Medicare levy? Are Australian public servants serving in overseas posts and their families covered by Medicare and do they pay the Medicare levy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has given me the following brief on this matter. Australian citizens who are posted overseas by private employers for extended periods on full pay are covered by Medicare benefits for the duration of their posting provided that they retain their ties with Australia-for example , ownership of property, the existence of close relatives or children attending school-or that they intend to return to Australia to live at the conclusion of their posting and that they continue to pay Australian income tax on a substantial part of their total taxable income. If any of the above conditions are not met it is probable that they will be judged ineligible for Medicare benefits while overseas because they will no longer be considered to be Australian residents for Medicare purposes. As to payment of the levy, the Australian Taxation Office imposes the levy on Australian residents as defined in the Income Tax Assessment Act. However, if a person is found to be ineligible for Medicare benefits under the Department of Health guidelines, the Minister for Health is empowered to waive obligation to pay the levy in respect of that person.

ANSWER.PARA: Australian public servants serving in overseas posts and their families normally fulfil the eligibility conditions set out in the answer to the first part of the question; therefore, they are eligible for Medicare benefits. It is understood that the Taxation Office normally regards such people to be Australian residents and therefore liable to pay the levy. It should be noted that Medicare benefits payable overseas to Australian residents cover medical benefits only, according to the New South Wales schedule of benefits. There is no provision for the payment of hospital benefits overseas under the Medicare arrangements.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: 'THE STRATEGIC BASIS OF AUSTRALIA'S DEFENCE POLICY'

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. How widely distributed was the document entitled 'The Strategic Basis of Australia's Defence Policy'? Who authorised its distribution, and have investigations by the Australian Federal Police, the Cabinet Office, or the Department of Defence yet identified any likely source of the leak to the National Times?

—There was a document of that title-to acknowledge as much of course is not to acknowledge the accuracy of any purported extracts from that document, whether published in the National Times or anywhere else-circulated last year to Cabinet Ministers in the ordinary way, by ordinary safe hand procedures and with no wider distribution than is normal for a document of this kind. I am not able to give the honourable senator any further information as to its distribution but it was confined to the normal distribution list for a defence document that was to be dealt with by the Cabinet foreign affairs and defence committee and by the Cabinet itself. As to the investigations that have taken place about the source of any possible leak of that document, I am able to say that the Prime Minister has authorised a joint investigation by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and the Australian Federal Police. I do not have to hand any preliminary results as to the efficacy of that inquiry at this stage.
—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I wonder whether the Attorney could help us, then, with the source of the authority for the distribution of the paper to which he referred.

—There was no special authority?

—I have no knowledge of any special authority. In case there is some particular magic associated with the honourable senator's question which I have not fully appreciated, I will ask the Defence Minister whether he has any further comment to make on that particular aspect of the question.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing. Is he aware of the announcement by the Commonwealth Trading Bank and the Westpac Banking Corporation that they will increase their prime interest rates by a half of one per cent and one per cent respectively from next weekend? Is this an indication that deregulation will lead to a resurgence of higher interest rates later this year? What steps will the Government take to keep home loan interest rates from climbing to even more unacceptable levels than we have at present?
—I think it would be more appropriate if my colleague Senator Walsh, who represents the Treasurer, would answer the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first part of the question asks whether the Government is aware of the Commonwealth Trading Bank and Westpac announcement. The answer is yes. In fact, I saw it in the Press. I am not sure that it is an indication that deregulation will lead to a resurgence of higher interest rates later in the year. That is very much a matter for judgment. It is not unusual at this time of the year for there to be some upward pressure on interest rates as taxation payments become due. Almost certainly a seasonal factor is involved. It is possible that other factors, relating to the very much higher growth rate which now seems likely to be achieved in the financial year ending June than had earlier been expected, could have an effect. For example, if the most recent expectation of a 10 per cent June 1984 on June 1983 increase in real gross domestic product is achieved, the increase in nominal GDP, given an implicit price deflator of 7 or 8 per cent, would be something between 17 and 18 per cent . The previously planned monetary growth target, again for June 1984 on June 1983, was 12 per cent. If all those figures should actually be realised, clearly there will have to be an increase in velocity of something between five and six per cent. That would be an extraordinarily high increase in velocity and indeed one which some people might argue was a symptom of the credit squeeze.

ANSWER.PARA: It has always been stated by the Treasurer that the Government's monetary target as stated in the last Budget would be reviewed in light of the economic growth rate and other economic indicators. The economic growth rate is certainly higher than had been anticipated at Budget time. Indeed, there has already been a review of the Government's M3 growth rate target. At the earliest opportunity I will ask the Treasurer whether there are any plans to conduct a further review in view of the now anticipated June-on-June real GDP growth rate being very much higher than had been anticipated in the Budget. Indeed, as far as I am aware it is an all-time record for any 12 months period either as non-farm GDP or as total GDP. Those record growth rates are around 8 per cent and 10 per cent respectively.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to the decision today by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to grant Australian workers a 4.1 per cent wage rise in line with the consumer price index increase. Will the decision handed down by the Commission lead to a continuation of the low level of industrial disputation in Australia? Will it assist the continuing economic recovery in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to this question has been bandied about in the Senate over a long period; it ultimately devolves to being a question of impression and judgment by the Government and by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Government's view has been stated on numerous occasions in this place. Its support for a centralised wage fixation system based on half-yearly indexation has been gone over again and again. The Government's view is that one of the most important elements in economic recovery is ensuring industrial stability in this country. There have been many complaints about that over the years and they have been very valid in terms of the performance of Australian industry. Thus in answer to the first part of the honourable senator's question, we believe that the decision will lead to a continuation of the low level of industrial disputation in Australia. Industrial disputes in this country were last year at their lowest level for 15 years and the decision handed down by the Commission will lead to a continuation of that situation. It will assist the maintenance of the prices and incomes policy.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the question of whether the decision will help economic recovery , there are different views. I have partly answered it from the Government's view. Of course, there will be complaints about wage increases from particular employers who find the increase difficult to bear, but it is infinitely preferable to the sorts of wage increases that came about in this country in 1981 and 1982 and led to enormous disruption in particular industries and enormous unemployment increases. The Government view is that it will assist in terms of the recovery referred to by the honourable senator. It is very important that the policies of the Government in relation to these matters and indeed the views of the Arbitration Commission should reflect contemporary realities. After all, the half-yearly indexation is a matter for decision by the Arbitration Commission on the basis of arguments put to it. In emphasising the importance of contemporary policies I refer to a view which was put in the Sydney Morning Herald editorial this morning about the Opposition's wages policy . The Sydney Morning Herald makes this point:

However, those proposals of which the Opposition seems most proud-the 'radical' provision for individual firms to opt out of the arbitration system, the rejection of 'automatic' full indexation, the legislation to make the Arbitration Commission have greater regard to economic circumstances and so on- are an attempt to deal with the problems of recession. The major problems facing wages policy now are those associated with economic recovery.

Judging by its record, economic recovery is not something the Opposition is good at. As the Sydney Morning Herald article points out by implication, the Opposition was expert in the policies of creating recession. In 1984 this country has to be concerned with the policies of economic recovery both in wages and elsewhere. That is what this Government is concerned about.

—I refer the Minister for Resources and Energy to a report that appears in today's Age newspaper which states that there is a split between the Minister and his Department on the adequacy of existing methods for disposal of radioactive waste from the nuclear fuel cycle. Is this report an accurate account of the Minister's position and that of his Department? Will the Minister give an assurance that the Australian Government is actively involved in the quest for adequate, safe disposal technology?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The quotation in the newspaper report to which Senator Bolkus refers is correct. I might add that the submission made by my Department to the Slatyer inquiry is a public document, so there is nothing untoward about a journalist getting a copy of it, reading it or quoting directly from it. However , the conclusions drawn in the newspaper report are not entirely correct. Indeed , I think they are quite incorrect. The preferred technology referred to in the quotation reproduced by Mr Gill in the Age article refers to the technology of vitrification. That is the technology currently preferred by most nations using atomic power. The reference to the length of time required before that technology can be applied is related to the need for the reactor rods to go through the thermal cooling process, and associated with that thermal cooling process is the decay of the shorter lived radioactive isotopes. If those spent fuel rods were stored in large numbers in a fairly concentrated location without having gone through that cooling process, significant dangers could be associated with the resultant heating of the ambient environment.

ANSWER.PARA: One final point that I should probably make is that an international conference of experts on radioactive waste management was held in Seattle in May last year. That conference concluded that adequate technology exists. The prime task now is the demonstration of that fact by individual countries at specific disposal sites. The conference recognised the importance of non-technological considerations and proper national management of radioactive waste disposal, in particular the political, legal and administrative frameworks of individual countries. I think that is about all I need to say in summary. The quotation published by the Age is correct, but I do not believe that the conclusions it drew from it were correct.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question Senator Robertson poses to me does not represent any great problem. Despite the fact that the Department of Veterans' Affairs has nine hospitals, six of which are general repatriation hospitals, there is no dispute involving doctors operating in those hospitals, whether they be members of the salaried staff or specialists in the Department. In other words, the problem that the Minister for Health is having with the doctors, particularly with the specialists in the public hospital system, does not exist in the repatriation system. I think that is to the everlasting credit of the doctors who operate in my area. Since 1979 salaried specialists have had the right of private practice in the repatriation general hospitals. That contract requires them to charge no more than the schedule fee. They accepted that in 1979 and have done so again in 1984, so there is no problem. In the light of that experience, one wonders why the Minister for Health is having such difficulties with specialists and salaried doctors in the public hospital system.

ANSWER.PARA: It seems clear to me that a significant section of the medical profession is at odds with the industrial position taken by the Australian Medical Association. It is pretty clear that there is a lot of unease in the medical profession about the hard line position that is being taken by the AMA. I give Senator Robertson and the Senate an assurance that entitled veterans and their dependants, war widows and others who receive medical treatment through the repatriation general hospitals, will not suffer as a result of the self-interests of any doctors in the public hospital system who have a conflict with the Minister for Health.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is it correct that the Prime Minister has written to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Paul Everingham, indicating that if the people of Cocos (Keeling) Islands choose on 6 April-that is, in two days time, the day on which they are to decide their future-to integrate with Australia, it is the Federal Government's decision that they will become a part of the Northern Territory? Have the islanders been given an opportunity to indicate with which State or Territory they wish to be integrated? Is it a fact that the people of Cocos (Keeling) Islands have stated that they wish to join with Western Australia, with which they have strong trade and communications links? If there has been no consultation with the Cocos Islanders, and having in mind that the islands are some 3,000 kilometres from the Northern Territory and have no previous association with the Territory, why is it that the Government has chosen to integrate Cocos (Keeling) Islands with the Northern Territory? As this decision has been made against the wishes of the Northern Territory Government, and quite possibly without consultation with the people of Cocos (Keeling) Islands, what then is the future of, say, Christmas Island? Having in mind the Federal Government's current changes in the responsibilities for various islands , is it the Government's intention to return Ashmore and Cartier Islands to the Northern Territory which, prior to gaining responsible self-government in 1978, did include these islands?

—I am aware that the Prime Minister has written to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory about this matter, but I am not privy to the Prime Minister's correspondence with the Chief Minister. Accordingly, I am unable to answer all the interrogatories which have been administered to me about the details of that correspondence. Nor am I in a situation in which I can indulge in speculation of the kind 'if this, then that', and I do not propose to do so. I will ask the Prime Minister for more detailed information about his correspondence with the Chief Minister and provide the honourable senator with an answer as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has there been any response yet from the Tasmanian Government to this Government's very reasonable offer to the State as compensation for the Gordon below Franklin Dam, which offer has been well received within the State and even praised by the media? If not, is it expected that such a response will be received soon so that this long running issue can be finalised?

—I certainly agree with Senator Coates's description about the generosity of the offer made by the Commonwealth Government to the Government of Tasmania. The answer to the question as to whether there has yet been a response is no. I understand there will be a meeting with the Premier of Tasmania on Friday at which, presumably, a response will be articulated.
—There is not meant to be a response before then.
—Order!

—Mr President, Senator Walters is assisting me in answering the question by saying what is meant and what is not meant. The answer is that I believe there will be a response on Friday. The details of that response will then become public and no doubt will be a topic of questions and discussion in the Senate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lajovic Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industry and Commerce whether he has seen an advertisement in Monday's Daily Telegraph addressed to the Prime Minister and all Cabinet members. This advertisement has been authorised by a combined delegates committee of the Vickers Cockatoo Dockyard Pty Ltd, Sydney. Amongst other things it states:

QUESTION.PARA: Given the present workload, Vickers Cockatoo Dockyard will lay off 1,000 workers by 1985 with the first wave of retrenchments commencing on Friday, 6th April, 1984.

A decision not to build a second ship can only mean that this Labor Government has taken a conscious, bloody-minded decision to close down the Shipbuilding/ Ship Repair Industry in the Port of Sydney and add a few thousand more workers to the already overcrowded dole queues of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the honourable senator ask his question?
—I ask the Minister whether he can inform the Senate what action has been taken or is intended to be taken by his Department or the Labor Government to preserve and maintain this industry in Sydney.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Vickers Cockatoo Dockyard is a naval dockyard. Its work is commissioned and performed at the behest of the Department of Defence. Let me come now to the important points in Senator Lajovic's question which concern simply the threat of closure of the Vickers Cockatoo Dockyard, as has been suggested in some quarters, or the threat of redundancies at that dockyard as a result of lack of demand. The lack of demand can occur in two areas. Firstly, it can occur in respect of what is the prime function of the Vickers Cockatoo Dockyard, that is, of building ships for the Royal Australian Navy. Secondly, it can occur if Vickers Cockatoo Dockyard were in a position to attract commercial work as a result of a lack of commercial work. Both those possibilities are a threat to the work load and the work force at the dockyard.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the subject matter of the advertisement, a number of meetings and discussions have taken place under the aegis of the Minister for Defence Support, at which my Department has been represented, with representatives of Vickers Cockatoo and of the work force at Vickers Cockatoo, almost on a week by week basis. Those discussions are continuing.

I add that the Government cannot be in a position to make decisions about the building of ships which it may or may not want on the basis of particular demands. If that precedent were carried throughout industry, of course the Government would be building all sorts of things which it may not require in all sorts of industries. That is the situation.

I make the general comment with regard to shipbuilding generally in Australia that a report was commissioned by my Department into the shipbuilding industry. A shipbuilding task force was established and the demand for ships in the foreseeable future in Australia is extremely poor. The fact is that Australia has an overcapacity of shipbuilding facilities and very little demand in the foreseeable future. Fortunately the projections of the shipbuilding task force have been somewhat alleviated by two orders from State governments-in New South Wales at Carrington Shipways Pty Ltd in Newcastle and at Australian Shipbuilding Industries (W.A.) Pty Ltd in Western Australia. There have been some orders from the Western Australian shipbuilding industry for trawlers which will be exported to various South East Asian countries. That is some light in terms of the general problems of the shipbuilding industry.

The problems of Cockatoo Dockyard are extremely difficult. The advertisement to which the honourable senator referred indicates that. But the Government is in constant discussion with both the company and the unions concerned about that matter. An announcement will be made at an appropriate time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. As the Minister is well aware, there is no compilation on a national basis by the Australian Bureau of Statistics of the number of work days lost due to industrial accidents. Because he will be aware of the difficulties this poses for the development of an effective and coherent national policy on occupational health and safety, does he envisage any moves in the near future to rectify this situation so that the Government may properly arm itself with the necessary statistics to fight against the disastrous effects of industrial accidents in Australia?

—I am not in a position to envisage any moves that might be made either by the Treasurer or the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations in relation to the compilation of industrial accident statistics on a national basis. I offer the comment that it seems tragic and most unfortunate that after many years there is still no such compilation by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. It would seem consistent with the Government's initiatives in relation to the establishment of a health and safety commission that such statistics should be available at a national level. I do not know what steps have been taken in relation to that. I will try to obtain a detailed answer from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and the Treasurer who is the Minister responsible for the Bureau of Statistics.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and refers to the front page story of last Saturday's Brisbane Courier-Mail which stated that the surveillance contracts of two firms are to cease. One of them was responsible for the Great Barrier Reef surveillance using a Nomad aircraft which had a 360-degree radar search. Can the Minister confirm the above? Is it a fact that the Government has done a sweetheart deal with Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd to have it take over the Great Barrier Reef and Northern Territory surveillance? Why was this done without going to public tender?

—As I indicated on Monday in reply to a question from Senator Evans, the question of surveillance referred to by Senator Boswell no longer is under the jurisdiction of the Minister for Transport or the Minister for Aviation whom I represent in this place. It now reposes in the Special Minister of State. The specific details would therefore need to be addressed to the Special Minister of State.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can I direct that question to the Minister representing the Special Minister for State?
—Can the Minister representing the Special Minister for State provide the answer?
—No doubt I would be able to if I had heard the question. I will do my best to respond to Senator Boswell at the conclusion of Question Time .

—Is the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs aware that the education of children in the Torres Strait is the responsibility of the Queensland Department of Aboriginal and Islanders Advancement? Is this situation providing equal opportunity when children are attending state schools supervised by a non-education department? What steps will the Commonwealth Government take to ensure that all Queensland children are eligible to education conducted under the auspices of the appropriate government department?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the educational problems of children living on the Torres Strait Islands. I also believe that those problems stem to a very large extent from the fact, to which Senator Reynolds drew attention in her question, that the education services for the Torres Strait Islands are not under the control of the Queensland Department of Education but of the Department of Aboriginal and Islanders Advancement. What that means is that islander children are the only children in that State who do not have the benefit of a proper educational administration of their educational services.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that at present some 14 schools in the Torres Strait are administered by the Queensland Department of Aboriginal and Islanders Advancement. The Commonwealth Government believes that education services are most properly provided by the professional educational authority in the State, which in this case would be the Queensland Department of Education. There are problems. Assessments show that the achievement levels of islander children are low and that the general educational standard falls short of that on the mainland.

I think there is a clear link between the quality of teaching, the educational outcomes and the teaching personnel available. I understand that the Queensland Government is at present considering the transfer to the Department of Education of responsibility for education in the islands. We would strongly support such a move. If the Queensland Government fails to bring about such an appropriate administrative re-organisation, I believe that we ought to assess whether we, as the Commonwealth Government, will need to become more directly involved in the educational provisions for these children. We cannot resile from our responsibilities to those children and at this stage we do not believe that their educational needs are being properly met.

However, I intend to write shortly to the Queensland Minister for Education, Mr Powell, about this matter. It is also my intention to visit the Torres Strait Islands as soon as time permits so that I can get a first hand assessment of the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I remind him that in answer to my question without notice last Friday about nuclear reactors, he indicated that a program of centrifuge enrichment of uranium was continuing at Lucas Heights and would continue for the next 12 months. I ask the Minister: What is the reason for the continuation of this program? How much enriched uranium has been produced since the program began? How much is expected to be produced by the time the program finishes? To what extent has that uranium been enriched and to what extent is it expected to be enriched by the time the program finishes? Since increasing the enrichment of uranium is simply a matter of how many times it passes through the centrifuges, is it not a fact that the Lucas Heights facility has the potential to produce weapons grade enriched uranium?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason that the program is being continued is to enable completion of a test bed of centifuges which will be used in a research program, in conjunction with the Australian Safeguards Office, into the application of safeguards techniques to centrifuge equipment. Never at any time has the amount of enriched uranium exceeded one half of a kilogram. Once having been enriched- remembering that this is just a research program not a commercial program-the enriched uranium is then remixed with the residual material and run through a second or third time. The level to which it has been enriched is not beyond 4 1/ 2 per cent which, while somewhat higher if I remember correctly than normal power reactor enrichment levels, is very much lower than the level of enrichment required for weapons or for research reactor rod purposes.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, since Australia is a signatory to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, all those relevant activities at Lucas Heights are subject to international supervision. The final question asked by Senator Mason related to whether Lucas Heights has the potential to produce highly enriched uranium. The answer is that it is not designed to produce highly enriched uranium. To do so would require that the facility be redesigned or rebuilt. Even if that were done-there is no plan to do it-the highly enriched uranium would only be produced in very small quantities.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. I have received a number of submissions from women concerned about the winding down of the National Women's Advisory Council. Despite my reassurances that the broader consultative mechanism is being set up, their concern persists, or at least their persistence does. Can the Minister say how far the planning has proceeded and when any announcement about the new committee might be forthcoming?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The planning towards the establishment of the new consultative body is very well advanced. Letters have been sent to a significant number-in excess of 20-of national women's organisations inviting them to submit the names of women who they believe could make an important contribution to this body. When we receive those names we will have to make a decision about the first body, based on considerations of balance of issues, of the ethnic background, geographical spread, of course, which is very important, the differences between country and city women, age and so on. We expect that when we announce the first national women's consultative council we will be announcing a body that will be much more broadly representative than the previous NATWAC was of the interests of women and women's organisations. We will be rotating membership of this body over the years so that different organisations will have an opportunity to make an input in to it.

ANSWER.PARA: When I finally announce the new body I will make it clear that no organisation will have, of right, a permanent place on the Council but, rather, that there will be opportunities, from time to time, for different organisations to participate. This is a necessary approach because the number of women's organisations which would have members able and willing to participate in the national consultative body is very large. Of course, there are financial and administrative limitations on the size of the council. I am waiting right now for the lists of names to come forward from women's organisations. I expect we will be able to make an announcement shortly. When we do I think that all women' s organisations which are interested in government policy and in making an input into government policy will be reassured that the new consultative arrangements are more extensive and more broad based than the previous ones have been.

In conclusion, our decision to broaden the range of views coming to the Government in a consultative capacity through a national women's council is, in no way, a criticism of the women who have served on the NATWAC. On many occasions I have expressed my appreciation of the work of previous advisory councils and, in particular, of the work of individual members and the convenors of those councils. We see this as a development of the work that the NATWAC began but a very practical and constructive development.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to recent articles by Mr Robin Osborne relating to political arrests by the Indonesian Government in the province of Irian Jaya and the imprisonment of Melanesian suspects without formal charges or prompt trials. In the light of an answer given by the Minister in response to my question without notice on 13 September 1983 that the Government 'will keep Parliament advised as appropriate' on human rights abuses of the Melanesian population in Irian Jaya, I ask the Minister: Firstly, what information has the Government received from its various diplomatic missions in respect to the arrest two months ago of 30 alleged supports of the Melanesian underground who included the curator of the Condrawasih University's anthropology museum, Mr Arnold Ap? Secondly, will the Australian Government use its good offices with the Indonesian Government to make inquiries about the safety of Mr Ap and his co-detainees and to make every possible effort to ensure that they all receive proper trials or are released without delay?

—Senator Missen's question is an important one. I do not have a detailed briefing on these matters at the moment. I will draw the matter to the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and get an answer for him as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I refer to recent reports, particularly over the last few days, of incidence of vandalism at the war cemetery at Karakatta in Western Australia. Can the Miniser advise what action he can take to prevent or even to counteract this deplorable behaviour?

—I think there have been about six different cases of vandalism in the Perth war cemetery over the past couple of months including three in the last five days. Whilst there has been no substantial damage it is a concern to the Department, the Government and to citizens generally. The damage that has been done may not be regarded as substantial. Nevertheless, such vandalism is to be deprecated and condemned. We are very concerned at reports that are circulating that headstones in the adjacent civil cemetery have been damaged as recently as last Friday evening. Of course, I am particularly anxious, naturally to see that that does not occur in our war cemetery. I have asked the Department to examine appropriate security measures. Following that there have been consultations between the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the Office of the Australian War Graves and the Returned Services League. The Perth police have mounted regular patrols of the cemetery and the surrounding areas. We hope that this will prove to be effective in respect of our areas as well as in respect of the civil cemetery. If not we will be looking at taking more stringent measures to protect such important areas in Perth.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer to the Minister's reply today on the alleged differences between this Department and him on nuclear waste disposal. Does not this fully confirm the submission of his Department?

The first question was whether any technique other than vitrification is in commercial use. Strictly speaking, I do not think it is correct to say that vitrification is in commercial use, let alone any other technique, because with all of the known possibilities, to my knowledge it is necessary to have a prolonged period of thermal cooling and substantial-
—Except synroc, which is proven.
—Except-

—Mr President, because the Minister has an obvious voice disability I would be very happy to accept a written reply. I think this is a serious subject. To save him any difficulty I suggest that he give me a written reply.
—I think that is sensible in view of the Minister's disability.

—At Question Time on 29 March Senator Foreman asked me a question relating to the Community Employment Program in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. In the course of providing an answer to that question I indicated to Senator Foreman that I may be able to provide an update of the figures provided in relation to South Australia. The figures which I provided on 29 March related to the period until mid-February 1984. I am now able to say that as at 16 March 1984 368 CEP projects were approved in South Australia creating over 2,700 jobs. A total of 903 applications had been received in South Australia to 16 March 1984 involving requests for over $100m of CEP funds and involving also the creation of over 5, 400 jobs.

—On 27 March Senator Coleman asked me a question about United States nuclear weapons policy. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) has provided the following answer: In relation to the first part of Senator Coleman's question, the Minister notes that whereas the Soviet Union has pledged not to be the first to use nuclear weapons, the 16 Western Governments which constitute the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation alliance, including the United States of America, have pledged not to use any weapons, nuclear or conventional, except in response to an attack. It remains part of NATO's strategy of flexible response, however, to leave open the possibility of using nuclear weapons in response to an overwhelming conventional attack by Warsaw Pact forces so as to deter such an attack. As to the second part of Senator Coleman's question, the Minister notes that the statement which she quoted and indeed other sections of the report to which she referred in her question indicate that United States defence strategy does not envisage a pre-emptive nuclear strike or 'first strike'.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Last night when I was speaking during the adjournment debate I noted that Senator Gietzelt came into the chamber and spoke to Senator Grimes. I presumed that he was asking whether I had sought permission to table a document. I would suggest that Senator Grimes said yes. This called to my mind what Senator Gietzelt had to say on the previous night, 2 April, when replying to remarks I had made on the adjournment. He said:

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Chaney proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The threat to the independence of the media posed by the Government's absurd over-reaction to any critical comment.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has brought forward this matter of public importance because it believes that we are getting to a serious point with respect to the present Government's reaction to media comment which could not be considered in any way adverse to the Government. What I wish to put before the Senate was, in a sense, encapsulated this morning by yet another brilliant cartoon from Mr Tandberg in which he showed a cheerful Australian Broadcasting Corporation announcer saying: 'And now at great expense to the management' and then turning to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and saying 'I will ask the Prime Minister a difficult question'. It has been evident from the reports which have been very widely circulated following the Caucus meeting held by the Australian Labor Party yesterday that the Prime Minister has turned the attention that he has given publicly to the media whenever they have dared to criticise him. He displayed his objection before the Caucus along with other senior members of the Labor Party. It is the belief of the Opposition that this matter is serious and should be brought to broader public attention.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the fact that Senator Button took a different stance at Question Time this afternoon from that which has been reported on the part of some of his senior colleagues. I asked Senator Button whether he believes that the ABC is running a consistent line against the Hawke Government. With admirable economy of words Senator Button replied: 'No'. I believe that there would be few, if any , people in Australia who watch the ABC who believe there is a consistent bias against the Government in the ABC. Indeed, I am sure there would be many people who would regard that suggestion with very cynical amusement. It is all very well to have Senator Button dissociating himself from that sort of remark. The fact is that the most powerful people in this Government-and we all know who calls the shots in the Hawke Government-Mr Hawke and Mr Hayden appear to have been extremely critical of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

I am not one who believes that the media should be free from adverse comment from politicians. People who choose to enter the area of public comment are entitled to be differed with and politicians are entitled to defend themselves. But I think we are entitled to look a little more carefully at statements which are made by the Government with respect to the ABC. Of course, the Corporation, while being an independent body which has its own statute, is a creature which is controlled by a board appointed by the Government. Most importantly, it is a body which is financed by appropriations of this Parliament which can be made only if the Government puts them forward. So in fact we are dealing here with a section of the media which is subject to the ultimate government sanction-that is, the restriction or cutting off of funds.

There is a great uniformity in the reports which have flowed out of the Caucus meeting of yesterday. The Age newspaper has Mr Hawke, the Prime Minister, declaring that the ABC should seriously look at itself and hinting that its funding would suffer if it did not improve. We are told that Mr Hawke and the Foreign Minister, Mr Hayden, strongly attacked the ABC at a meeting of the parliamentary Labor Party and that Mr Hayden said it was a second-class organisation compared with the commercial stations. We are also told that the Prime Minister has said that people in the community are asking why we are funding an organisation like this, and that if this sort of feeling builds up it should be reflected in a number of ways. That report in the Age is consistent with what was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald and the Australian. Some interesting additional comments are reported, with Mr Hawke saying, according to the Australian, 'Freedom of the Press is freedom to lie, I suppose'.

We are concerned that in this public attack made by senior members of the Australian Labor Party on the ABC there is a threat to the independence of that extremely important organisation. But it goes beyond the ABC. There is no shortage of people in the present Government who lash out at the media when the media behave in a way they do not like. All sections of the media are subject to some government influence. The Government through the appropriate statutory bodies controls the broadcasting industry. It has considerable powers in this area. Obviously the goodwill of the Government is important whether in the granting of concessions in respect of some of the gambling games that are given government monopoly or in the licencing arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not by us.

—No, but I am referring to government generally. Around Australia we have more than our fair share of Labor governments. It would be dishonest and facile to suggest that there are not plenty of opportunities for governments to put pressure on the media, if that is what they wish to do, particularly if governments believe that the media do not have an appropriate role to play in criticising government when they see it as being wrong. I am not referring to some vague concern dreamed up by the Opposition as a point of political attack on the Government. It was interesting that Mr Robert Haupt, who is an independent commentator in newspapers and on television, interpreted what had been released in very much the way I have put forward. Mr Haupt said on television this morning:

SPEECH.PARA: I think his attack on the ABC was in some ways more menacing. I think Brian Toohey can look after himself, quite frankly. But the Prime Minister specifically raised in the caucus room funding of the ABC. Now the caucus room these days is a semi public forum. The Prime Minister must have known that that was a message to the ABC and a message to every journalist working for it. I don 't think you do that sort of thing lightly. When the Prime Minister raises funding he is browbeating the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I think that is very significant.

That is very much in the spirit of the Opposition's concern in this matter but the Government, as the occasional recipient of Press criticism, lashes out and makes threatening noises when some of that criticism comes from the ABC. Indeed, the Government has lashed out in a similar way at other sections of the media.

The seriousness of the position is underlined by the political context in which the attack has occurred. It is no secret that the Government, which is led in this place by Senator Button, and led generally by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, is at an allegedly record level of popularity. We have a government which is not oppressed by the fact that it has slipped in the opinion polls. According to the most recent Morgan polls, it is a government that is recording an approval rate of 57 per cent, and a Prime Minister who is recording approval of 74 per cent. That has been the culmination of a gradual rise in the polls for the Government. Nobody would deny that over the 12 months or so that the Government has been in office it has received a good Press, and by that I mean good, positive coverage from most sections of the media, both print and electronic. One wonders what the response of the Government will be when, as Premier Cain found when his Government slipped some 20 points in a relatively short time, it, too, comes under criticism and when its popularity is at a lower point. I regard this morning's media reports as incredible, yet I believe they occurred for no other reason than the Government's extraordinary positive publicity ever since the election. Probably the present Government has had the most extended media honeymoon in Australia's political history.

If this were a one-off problem, if this were the first time this had occurred, one might wonder whether it was some temporary mental aberration on the part of the Prime Minister. But the fact is that Senator Button led the charge in this area when the Government first took office. It was Senator Button who first caused concern in this chamber with his rather loose criticisms of the then chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, Dame Leonie Kramer. Most honourable senators will remember that occasion in May last year, less than a year ago, when Senator Button, no doubt speaking on behalf of the Government, said that it was his regret that the then chairman, Dame Leonie Kramer, had not always adopted the attitude of being without fear or favour. I do not want to traverse all that ground again, but leading the Government in this place is Senator Button, who had a high reputation for his interest in the media. It was thought that he had a great deal of sympathy with the ABC. But we know that over a period of some days when that matter was controversial he maintained the view that prior to the election the ABC had not been without fear or favour with respect to the Labor Party. I doubt whether there was a single impartial political observer who would have agreed with Senator Button on that. Surely it highlights the great danger when politicians choose to make judgments in this area, judgments which could be inimical to the interests of bodies which in the ultimate the Government controls.

Senator Button is alleged to be one of the most liberal members of the present Government, yet he was the one who initially challenged the impartiality of Dame Leonie Kramer. One might say what does that matter as all politicians are prone to make the odd loose statement. The Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, says that everybody makes all sorts of strange statements in the privacy of their telephone conversations, and perhaps strange statements are made here in the Senate as well. We all know what happened to Dame Leonie Kramer. She disappeared from view in relation to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Although the Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy, said he would be very surprised if her name did not go forward for consideration for the post, the fact is that that respected woman who was in charge of the Commission was not reappointed when the new corporation was established. I believe there is some message in that. Dame Leonie got her warning through the mouth of Senator Button . I suggest that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation has now got its warning through the mouths of Mr Hawke and Mr Hayden.

There are many other examples of great sensitivity on the part of members of this Government to the most minor newspaper criticism. Senator Gareth Evans is a man who has a quote for all seasons and for all arguments. I suspect that it would be hard for this place to discuss a motion of public importance without being able to provoke some loose comment from Senator Gareth Evans in support. Most honourable senators will remember the way he has talked about the National Times and a reporter called Mary Ann Wilkinson who dared to expose some of the dirt and trouble that affect this country, and who wrote articles that ultimately had their place in leading to the resignation of Mr Jackson. It was the sort of journalism that once might have been admired by Labor members, by people such as Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Button. But on 30 March in the Senate the Attorney-General talked of the National Times in these terms: 'It would appear that the National Times is as illiterate as it is amoral'. That is a nice illustration of the attitude of members of the present Government to those sections of the media which have dared to give them some criticism. One finds, for example, that Senator Gareth Evans in exactly the same way talked of the Age newspaper in quite deprecatory terms because of its role in daring to publish the tapes which have led to the establishment by the Attorney-General of a police task force and the appointment of a special prosecutor. The Attorney- General's reference to that matter on 28 February was:

I think it needs to be said, finally, that the role of the Age newspaper in this whole affair has not been a very proud one, particularly for a paper so prone to suggest its moral and intellectual leadership of the profession of journalism in this country . . .

There are plenty of senior members in the present Government, such as the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, the Foreign Minister, Mr Hayden, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, and the Attorney-General, showing an extraordinary sensitivity to criticism. It appears they are prepared to put down those sections of the media which dare to criticise the Government.

I think that all of this is even stranger when one looks at the reputation which this Government has, and which I think it deservedly has, for a very high degree of media management, because what we have in this Government is a preparedness to tackle things on the basis that the way it will be perceived and dealt with in the media is extremely important.

There was a very interesting discussion in the program that I mentioned earlier , the national Today show, with Mr Haupt, about Mr Hawke's management of the media. Again the views of the Opposition on this matter might be suspect. It might be thought that we are simply playing politics, but I do not think even Senator Button is going to get up and suggest that Mr Haupt is playing politics in making his comments and doing other than putting forward an honest opinion on the matters on which he is commenting. Mr Haupt was asked to comment on the fact that the Leader of the Labor Party, the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, had not bothered to go or had not gone to the Victorian and Western Australian annual conferences. The questions were put to him: Was it not normal for Labor leaders to go? Why did Mr Hawke not attend the conference? Mr Haupt said:

I think it is a similar thing to why Prime Ministers don't debate Opposition leaders. There was going to be trouble at the conference and I think that Mr Hawke's handlers think that it is best to keep him as far as possible from trouble.
The questioner went on to ask what the response would have been to Gough Whitlam behaving in the same way:
Is this another example of careful media management?
The answer was:

Yes . . . Mr Whitlam would have been made to look as though he was on the defensive or running away from trouble. I think that Mr Hawke has got superb media managers. This was not raised as an issue and we seem to have accepted in the media that Mr Hawke is going to be treated differently to the way that his predecessors and particularly the way Mr Fraser was treated. I think it is a very good case of media management.

Mr Haupt went on to deal with the matter which I wish to deal with in closing my part of this debate, and that is, why it is important that the media not be browbeaten by the present Government in the way that it is obviously setting out to do, and why it is important that there should be some exposure of why it is that the Government is having the smooth run which it is presently having in a media sense. I do not believe it is because Senator Button, after all his protestations against the previous Government's so-called management of the media through the Government Information Unit, and his Government have chosen to expand that Unit and to spend a great deal more of the taxpayers money on putting out the Government's message. The fact is that we have a government which has chosen to be a government of illusions and broken promises. Quite clearly it wants a compliant media in the lead-up to its planned, unjustified early election which the Prime Minister has been supposedly honest enough to tell us is going to occur probably later this year. What is quite clear is that the election strategy which is being followed by this Government is one of clearing the decks, of deferring hard decisions and simply not coming to grips with any of the issues which a government might be expected to come to grips with.

Let us just look at the attitude which has been adopted by the Government with respect to the major matters which might have been the subject of legislation in this place and which might have been the subject of debate and difference in this place as well as in the media. We find that the Government came forward with a proposal for an assets test. That was deferred at the request of the Opposition to give people a chance to make submissions. That assets test has now been put aside, sent off to a committee. I ask the Leader of the Government: Will we get an opportunity really to debate the Government's intentions in this matter before the next election? We had a deal of fuss about the prospect of a change to the taxation of lump sum superannuation payments. I ask him: 'What has happened to the legislation there? When will we get to grips with that issue? Will that be after the next election also?

We had the Attorney-General come in here the other day and say: 'The Bill of Rights is something we are putting aside until after the next election. That is something which we simply do not wish to debate in a pre-election atmosphere'. We have had the clear statement from the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that they are not going to muddy the pre-election waters with a capital gains tax debate. That is something to be dealt with after the next election. We had a promise from this Government that it was going to legislate nationally for land rights. I invite the Leader of the Government in the Senate to tell us whether there will be national legislation for land rights between now and the next election. I think I know the answer, but I would quite like to hear a government answer. We heard the Attorney-General come in here and postpone the referenda which, although they had a wide degree of support in this Parliament, were clearly going to be strongly opposed by some State parties. That was taken off the agenda because this Government is going to maintain its popularity by doing nothing and it is going to try to have a lead-up to the election in which no one in the media is going to deal with the negative issues which surround this Government. Any section of the media which tries to raise those matters will be subject to vilification and abuse. We have seen it here in the Senate. We know now that it has been going on in the Caucus.

We know, of course, that Senator Button's friend Mr Duffy was courageous enough to get up and defend the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and to try to get some balance into that argument. It will be interesting to see whether here, in this more public forum, Senator Button is prepared to show his principles-as I think he tried to do in answering my queston at Question Time today-to show whether he will give some support to the view that the media should remain independent and fearless in the face of a goverment which is petulant, mean- minded and threatening in the face of a very much smaller level of public criticism.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, that was a fine piece of rhetoric for a government in exile and, of course, the real sting in the tail is, I suppose, the allegation that the Government is maintaining its popularity by doing nothing. That comes strangely from the lips of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney). This Government is popular because it has done something. It has restored the economic health of this country after seven years of economic disaster under the Fraser Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators opposite can speculate on all those things, but the fact of the matter is that it is popular for that reason. Not only have its major economic decisions been applauded by the electorate, they have been applauded by the Opposition's Deputy Leader in the House of Representatives.
—What economic decisions?

—Many of the decisions made by this Government, such as the floating of the dollar-something which the Opposition did not have the guts to do-have been applauded by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. The decision on lump sum superannuation was a matter of some-
—Where is the legislation?

—I said that the decision on lump sum superannuation was applauded by some members of the Opposition. The decision to impose the means test on over 70-year-old pensioners was something which Senator Chaney, as Minister for Social Security, ran away from for years, and the Opposition knows it. There are a number of other decisions that fall within that category. I am sorry to stir the Opposition about these sorts of issues which are not relevant to the subject matter of this debate.
—You raised them.

—I raised them. I will continue to raise them if necessary, and I will probably do better at raising them than Senator Messner does at Question Time. But let me say this: The subject matter of this debate is something of a storm in a teacup and something of a perennial. Senator Chaney relies on information-I forget how he put it, it was a most unfortunate word he chose- which seeped out of a meeting of the parliamentary Labor Party yesterday. He alleges from that, on the basis of doing a Rorschach chart of the various newspapers on a bit of blotting paper or something, that as the reports are somewhat similar in various newspapers, they are accordingly all correct.

SPEECH.PARA: Now when I say this debate has something of a perennial flavour about it, let us look at what was said by one of my predecessors in the Senate, Senator Withers, who has now left the chamber but who, as leader of a government in the Senate had this to say on 24 March 1976:

Do not raise the Australian Broadcasting Commission. You blokes have been leaning on it for years. It is full of your supporters and has been pumping out your propaganda year in and year out. This is not a matter of opinion; it is a matter of notoriety. The sooner it is cleaned up the better as far as I am concerned.

A then senior Minister in the Fraser Government had that to say on the public record. He did not say it in any party room, he said it here in the Senate. If those words are not a threat to the independence of the ABC what is? Senator Chaney, in trying to make his case today, has relied on alleged comments by the Prime Minister, alleged comments by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden-

TALK.START.PARA: —You should correct the transcript.

—No, I will not correct the transcript. He has relied on comments by those two Ministers and, for the purposes of the debate, has elevated Mr Hayden to a status which even he would not claim in terms of the importance of the remarks which he made.
—Not yet.

—Hope springs eternal in the heart of Senator Lajovic. 'Not yet', he says. Let me say at the beginning that I affirm and agree with some of the points made by Senator Chaney. First of all, this is a very popular Government. I affirm and agree with that, and it is important to put it on the record right at the beginning. Secondly, I agree with the suggestions made by Senator Chaney about the importance of the independence of the media, particularly the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. I assert the right of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to make, within the law, what programs it wants to make . Indeed, this morning it had Senator Chaney on a program called Politicians and Their Music. During that program it was revealed by the Leader of the Opposition that he used to practise hand jiving while listening to the Darktown Strutters Ball, and it was further revealed by the Leader of the Opposition that he so loved the film The Graduate that he now drives an Alfa Romeo Spyder, as did Dustin Hoffman in the movie. I wonder whether the Leader of the Opposition shares the other fantasies of Dustin Hoffman in the film The Graduate. That was not revealed in the program. It is very important that the people know the views and fantasies of the Leader of the Opposition as revealed on that Australian Broadcasting Corporation program. I assert strongly the right of that sort of program to be made even if the views expressed may be reprehensible to people of my degree of propriety in these matters; even if I may find some of Senator Chaney's habits and tastes slightly distasteful.

SPEECH.PARA: The subject of this matter of public importance is faintly ironic. Let me be frank about this: There has been a long history of politicians from both sides of the Parliament, during times when each side has been in government-the coalition happens to have been in government for longer than we have-attacking or criticising the Australian Broadcasting Commission and the media. We are criticised for the alleged competence of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in handling the media; of course the last Prime Minister had his own competencies in that regard too. He was the inventor of the doorstop interview as a means of communicating with the electorate. At the heart of this whole topic, brought forward allegedly as a matter of public importance, is the suggestion that the Government is somehow threatening the independence of the media. That is just an absurd overreaction to the stories which Senator Chaney alleges have seeped out of the Caucus.

Let me look at what has actually happened. Certain members of the Government are reported in today's media as having criticised individual Australian Broadcasting Corporation programs and certain newspaper articles. That happened; there is no doubt about that at all. Indeed, in respect of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation program which I understand was the subject of criticism yesterday, Senator Sir John Carrick asked a very proper question the other day which by implication-I do not say this in any critical way of the honourable senator-

TALK.START.PARA: —There was no criticism at all; it was seeking to see whether an objective job had been done.
—I am not seeking to criticise the honourable senator in any way. All I am saying is that his question carried with it the implication that perhaps there were some inaccuracies in that program.
—On a very complex matter.

—It was on a very complex matter, and certainly that was the subject of discussion in the Parliamentary Labor Party. There was criticism by some members of the Party in respect of the contents of the program.
—That is a very different sort of criticism.

—And a very important one. There was an expression of disagreement with the views expressed in some of those programs and indeed with the views in some articles in the National Times. Those opinions hardly amount to a threat by the Government to the independence of the media. That is the issue with which I want to deal. If the Opposition seriously asserts-I do not believe Senator Chaney did-that no-one in parliament, in government or opposition, has a right to question or comment on programs or newspaper articles , that is absurd.
—I specifically dealt with that.
—I said that I do not believe the honourable senator was saying that.
—Before you came in I specifically dealt with that.

—All right; Senator Chaney specifically dealt with that. I accept his assurance. Of course members of parliament have a right to criticise programs and articles in the media and in so claiming that right they, in my view, by implication assert the right of others to make those criticisms. I think that is the essential point in this debate. As I was saying, the truth is that everybody in the community has a right to criticise the media just as they have a right to criticise those of us who are engaged in politics. I would have thought they exercised that right in an atmosphere of great freedom. If I might say so, I believe they exercise that right with some exuberance and at times, indeed, flamboyance. That is something from which we all suffer in the particular occupation we have.

SPEECH.PARA: So there is no truth in the suggestion that the Government would in any way seek to circumscribe the independence of the media. If the Opposition wants to know what the Government's policy is in relation to the independence of the media, particularly the ABC, it has to have a calm look at the facts. There is no confusion about them. The Government's view of the independence of the ABC is evidenced by the new ABC legislation which this Government introduced and which ensures the independence and integrity of that organisation. That is very different from saying that the ABC or any other form of media is immune from criticism of any kind, as I said earlier. There has been no attack on the integrity and institutions of the media. Certainly quite forceful comments have been made about programs, and I see nothing exceptional in that.

If one looks first of all at what the Government has done and at the legislation which was passed last year in relation to the ABC one sees that the legislation places the responsibility for maintaining the independence and integrity of the new Corporation on the Board of the Corporation. There can be nothing clearer than that. I go back a step further and say that the Government' s attitude to the independence of all forms of media is laid out in the Federal platform of the Australian Labor Party. While the uranium policy might be open to different interpretations, this section of the platform is not. I quote that section of the platform:

Information and comment by all forms of media should be governed by fair and democratic principles, and not by ministerial or other political interference, nor by any sectional or private interest, including that arising through monopoly control.

With respect to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation which is the principal body concerned in this little bit of brouhaha going on here today, it was spelt out by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) in his second reading speech in these terms:
. . . this Government is committed to maintaining a strong and independent ABC, able to meet the broadcasting needs of the Australian people.

I contrast that attitude to the establishment of the independence of the ABC by legislation last year with the attitude of the previous Government. The coalition, when it was in government, concocted an elaborate commissioner of complaints structure whereas the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission recommended only an ABC appointed community affairs officer to receive complaints. If ever there were an overreaction by a government it was that absurd commissioner of complaints proposal. This commissioner of complaints proposition, which was in the ABC legislation of the previous Government, which fortunately as a result of the election never saw the light of day in Parliament, provided for an outside fully fledged statutory officer appointed by the Government who would have the function of dealing with complaints and imposing penalties, if you please, in respect of complaints.

That immediately raised the question of whether that sort of procedure was applicable to ordinary broadcasters. It was a threat and it compromised and confused the role of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and its Board. That Board, not an outside body appointed by government, is supposed under the present legislation to be responsible for the Corporation's performance. That sort of proposal compromised totally investigative journalism if we consider the complaints procedure put forward by the Fraser Government. The Complaints Commissioner would have investigated 'unfairness, bias and defensiveness' not just in relation to individuals but generally. Thus if ever there was a vehicle trundled forward by a government for muzzling serious criticism in this country that was it; it was the classic sort of Trojan horse of 1982 in the hands of the Fraser Government. The then Chairman of the British Broadcasting Corporation had this to say about the Fraser Government's proposal:
the whole package of legislation is so bad and so discriminatory that if I were a member of the ABC I would say let's down tools and walk off in protest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote that?

—That was Mr George Howard, the former chairman of the BBC, the man who owned that fine house in that excellent serial, Brideshead Revisited. They are strong words indeed from the then Chairman of the British Broadcasting Corporation. They were made here in this country in late 1982 as a comment on the Fraser Government's proposals for the Australian Broadcasting Commission. They are strong words indeed in terms of the Opposition's over- reaction to reported remarks made yesterday. No criticism like that has ever been levelled at the performance of this Government in relation to independence of the media. The then Government, of course, was forced to abandon that legislation and was tipped out of office before it could be passed. By abandoning that legislation it acknowledged its errors; so the case is proven against it. This is not the first time that the Opposition has tried to stir up unfounded criticism over allegations of political interference. I will come to that in a minute. I just want to deal with one other very important question relating to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. The Board of the Corporation is appointed by government. For the first time in the history of the Corporation this Government adopted a policy of submitting to a joint party committee names for the Board of the Corporation.
—How many names?
—Seven to be chosen from nine?
—I am not sure of the exact number.
—That was a rort.

—Senator Chaney regards it as a rort; he would not have done it in a fit. Under his Government his Minister used to come to me and tell me the names he proposed to put forward for the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I would approve the names as being fine and independent and the then Minister would put them up. Those names all got knocked over. Some of them were knocked over because in 1975 they signed letters objecting to the course which the later Fraser Government took. That is what Senator Chaney's Minister did. We submitted names and it does not matter how many names we submitted for the purpose of starting this process of bipartisan consultation. The Opposition's representatives on that body fully accepted and congratulated us on the process, not only at the meeting, but also here in the Senate. Senator Sir John Carrick can mumble about it now but that is what Senator Peter Baume said in the Senate. The members of the Opposition on that committee approved the names that were submitted by the Government. I hope that that process will be able to be expanded because it is another important step in securing the independence from government of the ABC.

SPEECH.PARA: I said that this is not the first time that the Opposition has stirred up unfounded criticisms. Only last year, on 18 October, the now departed Mr Anthony alleged in Parliament that the Australian Labor Party Government had leaned on the ABC over election time in Queensland. These allegations were totally baseless. As a result of that the Minister for Communications began defamation proceedings against Mr Anthony. These sorts of things have happened over a long period. These things, like the allegations by Mr Anthony, debase the process of politics in this country. Likewise, this MPI has been stirred up on the basis of loose Press reports and a great reading into those Press reports of all sorts of suggestions. Like the allegations stirred up by Mr Anthony and the threats made to the ABC by Senator Withers in 1976, these unfortunately are the perennials of Australian politics. They are contrived just as is this MPI.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The subject of the matter of public importance today relates to allegations of criticism of the media by the current Government. In response to this Senator Button raised a distinction, on which he relied for most of his speech, between criticism of particular programs and criticism of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation or other sections of the media in general. I do not believe that anybody in this chamber would cavil at the proposition that every honourable senator or every member of the community has a right to criticise particular programs for whatever reason, whether because of factual error or biased presentation. But that is not in fact the substance of the propositions that appear in today's media reports.

SPEECH.PARA: The basic allegation in those reports is that Mr Hawke told the Caucus yesterday that the Government had enemies in the media. He was not talking about a particular program. He was talking about the enemies of the government in the media. Is it not extraordinary that a government with a 20 per cent lead over the Opposition according to the latest gallup poll, a Prime Minister who is beloved of 78 per cent of the electorate and a government that extols the virtues of consensus and a need for national reconciliation, should start to develop a siege mentality at this stage of its innings? The Hawke Government may be popular but surely this does not give it any absolute monopoly on truth or virtue. There are credible alternative views within a community which must and should be put forward. Mr Hawke has made great play also recently out of labelling all those who raise the issue of corruption as using McCarthyist tactics. Mr Hawke now surely is demonstrating a McCarthyist mentality when he sees his enemies behind every paper or television program which criticises this Government.

Let us consider a couple of examples to which Mr Hawke referred. As the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) mentioned, the National Times is one of those newspapers singled out for particular criticism because on a couple of occasions recently it has published allegedly secret government documents, the Austeo Papers and the 'Strategic Basis of Australia's Defence Policy'. The Government even went to the High Court of Australia on the first occasion to try to stop publication; finally, by agreement, a sanitised version was allowed for publication. The Government has refused either to confirm or deny the second paper. That has not stopped it from criticising the National Times and accusing it of telling lies. I do not think the Government can have it both ways. It cannot accuse the newspaper of telling lies and then refuse to confirm or deny whether the issue on which the paper based its comments is true or false. I think one draws from that that the Government is saying that the document is false. That then leads us into great difficulties with prominent members of the community who are in a position to know and have said openly that those leaked documents are true.

I turn to the last paper on the list. The Australian Democrats, on behalf of a large group of people in the community, expressed concern about whether the Government was contemplating the development of nuclear weapons in Australia. The Government has denied that it has made a decision along those lines. That is fine, but other elements of equal importance in that paper have not been denied by the Government. I believe they are legitimate matters for discussion by the news media and matters for public discussion and complaint. The issues that have probably raised more ire from the Government than any others were those raised in recent times by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in a couple of its programs.
