What probably started the whole thing off was the Four Corners 'Big League' program that led to the establishment of the royal commission that investigated matters concerning the former Chief Stipendiary Magistrate of New South Wales, Mr Murray Farquhar. The second was the Four Corners program on nuclear safeguards. That is an issue of topical interest. Surely that must be one of the criteria that the news media apply when determining the types of programs that they wish to run.

The Four Corners program was seeking to bring forward what Senator Sir John Carrick described today by way of interjection as an extremely complex issue. It is an extremely complex issue. It is one that I believe our citizens have a right to be informed about, and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, as an organisation supported by public funds, ought to be willing to tackle such issues. Indeed, I believe that the ABC should be broadcasting programs and comments that are critical of government policy, of whatever political persuasion that government happens to be. From our point of view, there does not seem to have been terribly much change from the policies followed in the past with the coming to office of the Hawke Government. Attention has been drawn to that fact by many media programs. That is the role of the media in the community . I do not think it is fair or reasonable to attack the media for putting forward the sorts of programs that they do. The media must raise controversial issues and present minority viewpoints. They ought to present viewpoints opposed to government policy, because government policy often has a monopoly on the attention of the media. As I just said, the change of government has not changed the attacks made on the ABC. Let me list some of the attacks that have been made on previous occasions. An article that appeared in the Hobart Mercury on 7 March 1980 reads:
A women's radio program broadcast by the Australian Broadcasting Commission has been described as 'unprofessional' and 'crude'.
Senator Walters told the committee that 'Coming Out 80' was unacceptable to the average listening audience.

In an article that appeared in the Northern Territory News on 14 June 1980 entitled 'Complaint on documentaries' Senator Kilgariff is reported to have said that it had been indicated to the ABC that the Country-Liberal Party Government would not take part in future documentary filming unless it was assured of a fair coverage. Senator Kilgariff was making noises similar to those we have heard in the last couple of days. Senator Kilgariff was reported to have said:

. . . Nationwide last week was a most malicious production. Recognising that all organisations can only be judged by their lowest and weakest link I can only deplore the level to which the ABC has sunk . . .

I turn to an article that appeared in the Sydney Daily Telegraph of 10 April 1981 entitled 'Claim of ALP ''mole'' in the ABC'. That is a good title. I was rather gleeful when I found that article but its contents did not live up to the sensational title. The article reveals that Mr Sinclair, the Leader of the National Party, said that a senior ABC reporter had maintained an open-line contact with a Labor Party official during the last election campaign. No substantive evidence was provided. An article dealing with the Dix report in the Bulletin of 8 December 1981 reads:

Sinclair and some other Ministers, including the Prime Minister, are said to wonder whether an ABC, more concerned with news and current affairs and less with cricket and situation comedies, would be even more of a problem than the present organisation which is seen as being too often irresponsible and biased to the Left.

Since Senator Button has been attacked, I think I should draw attention to the celebrated headline that appeared in the Australian of Monday, 22 February 1982: 'Decline of the ABC: Kramer versus Fraser'. In that article Dame Leonie Kramer is reported to have said:
I have no intention of presiding over the decline of the ABC.
The article went on to say:

That is encouraging, for there are those within the ABC who firmly believe that Mr Fraser's Government is determined to squeeze the commission to the point where it can no longer act as an alternative to commercial television and radio.

So it goes on. The last article to which I wish to refer is under the heading ' Left-Wing Bias seen by Court'. That refers to Sir Charles Court, the former Premier of Western Australia. That article brings us back to the present situation. In that article Sir Charles Court is reported to have said:
In my experience there have always been a number of interviews against my side of politics and there left-wing bias has come through in the way they've presented the story.

It is always interesting to note that when a group of people in the media attack one, one always sees that as resulting from the bias of the journalists. Politicians are prone never to look at their own policies if they are attacked, but rather to attack back. That might be a characteristic of the species, but sometimes it is a pity that that happens because critical comment about one's policies ought, I believe, to be met in the first instance with an examination of whether there is any substance to the criticism. If no substance can be found presumably another course of action will follow. At the end of the article an even more interesting comment is attributed to Mr John Knight, the Executive Director in Perth of the ABC current affairs program Nationwide. Mr Knight is reported to have said this about Sir Charles Court:
His idea of a fair go was to have as long as possible to put his point of view unchallenged.

The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) has been making the same complaint about the Four Corners program. One cannot expect to have included in any television program everything that one says. One would have a legitimate complaint if one considered that the parts of the interview used were not representative of the overall views that were put. However, having viewed the Four Corners program and read the transcript, one is led to the conclusion that certain questions were dealt with in full. The question is put and the answer is there. I am quite sure that many questions that were asked and answers that were given were not televised. Any person who has had a television interview would know that that is the case. One cannot expect all the questions and answers to be included. If a comment is included, surely it cannot be said that much of the interview was left out. The concern rather should be whether the part that was included in the broadcast was edited in such a way as not to represent the views that were expressed. I hope that in the course of this debate we might have clarified the concern that was felt about the particular segment of the program. In the article to which I have just referred, Mr Knight is reported to have said further:
It's in the nature of politicians to complain and attempt to get as good a deal for themselves as possible.

I do not know whether that is symptomatic of politicians; it seems to me to be symptomatic of human beings. Politicians would not be human beings if they did not try to get as much coverage as they possibly could of their point of view. Presumably if they hold a view firmly they believe it to be correct. I believe that the essence of criticism in a community such as ours ought to be directed at the factual content of the program, not the continuous allegations that we hear that there is some type of underlying running bias and conspiracy afoot. As I have shown by referring to the various articles, allegations of conspiracies are easily generated by people in government and, as anyone who knows anything about the law will realise, such conspiracies are difficult to prove. I think that it is far better and far healthier to try to pinpoint precisely where that program has made a mistake in a factual presentation of a selection of material which does not adequately represent the viewpoint that was put or whatever else the actual complaint is rather than the generalised blanketing operation of condemnation of media services. As politicians, whether we like it or not, the views of politics, the information we put forward, will be carried to the community via some media service. It is important for us, as it is for the media , to try to make sure that those views, when they are carried, are as accurate and as clearly representative of the various positions in political life as possible. I do not believe that is assisted by the types of comments that have been made in recent times by members of the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The threat to the independence of the media posed by the Government's absurd over-reaction to any critical comment.

I stress that this debate does not concern the right of any person here or in the community to make criticism of any part of the media. We do not criticise Government members for valid criticisms of the media. What this debate is about is the reaction of the Government, including the three or four most senior Government members, one of whom is the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), which can only be construed as menacing, threatening, bludgeoning and as trying to wipe out any right of the media to criticise the Government. This debate is about the Government's over-reaction by way of threat. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) did not direct himself in the whole of his 20-minute speech to any point on that. In fact, he deliberately talked around it. He said that members did make criticisms of various programs in Caucus. The abysmal silence on his part was that he did not deny what the Prime Minister is reported to have said. The hub of this in terms of immediacy is a report published today in the Age newspaper over the byline of one of the most senior and respected journalists in Australia and indeed in the Press gallery, Michelle Grattan. She wrote:
The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, declared yesterday that the ABC should 'seriously look at itself', and hinted that its funding could suffer if it did not improve.

In the knowledge that that has been reported, the Leader of the Government in the Senate has made no denial at all. The Prime Minister is reported as saying- no denial has come forward-that if the Australian Broadcasting Corporation does not stop its criticisms the Government will cut its funds. That is an outrage. That is what this debate is all about. Michelle Grattan went on to say:
Responding to a backbencher's question, Mr Hawke claimed the ABC was 'running a consistent line against the Government'.

'People in the community are asking why we're funding an organisation like this ,' he told Caucus members. 'If this sort of feeling builds up, it should be reflected in a number of ways.' The Prime Minister did not specify the ways.

It is quite sinister to say 'it should be reflected in a number of ways'. What has happened is that the Prime Minister is on record in the Press as threatening the media, specifically the ABC and saying it would reduce its funds if criticisms did not stop. There has been no rebuttal of this. There is nothing new in this at all. One will recall that in the unedifying situation of Senator Button's attack on Professor Kramer, a great Australian, it appeared that Mr Hawke had telephoned the ABC and used threatening tactics. I quote from a transcript of the program Nationwide of 6 May 1983. Richard Carleton asked Professor Kramer:
Would you give a broader account of the tone of that conversation? Was Mr Hawke rude to you? Did he threaten you?
Was it a raised voice he used at you?
Professor Kramer is a mild, mature person. Her reply was:
Yes, oh yes.
Richard Carleton asked:
And was he telling you what you had to do? In his view?
Professor Kramer replied:
Well he was very insistent and expecially in the matter of my having to get back to Senator Button within 24 hours.

What kind of a dictatorship, a standover of the ABC, was that? A member of the Australian Labor Party telephoned the ABC and, in a threatening tone, sought to order the Chairman that something had to happen within 24 hours.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was in opposition.

—Yes, he was in opposition. The man has not changed his spots on this. So we have a pattern of yesterday and the past. Thank God for the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and for Australia that there are people of courage such as Dame Leonie Kramer who refused to be bludgeoned. If this were just another situation, a rare occurrence, one would wonder. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) is on record as saying, on 18 May, that the ABC was 'so anti-Labor it would exploit any situation at all'. He went on to the ugly inference, a revolting inference, that because the Hawke Government intended to reorganise and restructure the ABC the ABC brought forward the Four Corners program. Could there be any nastier assertion? Could there be any more foul an assertion than that? On the AM program the Deputy Prime Minister was asked whether he was 'getting in the way' of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden. Mr Lionel Bowen said:

SPEECH.PARA: Honestly, what's wrong with the ABC these days is it's so anti-Labor.
The transcript of the interview went on:
Clearly irritated earlier in the interview, he said: 'The tragedy of the ABC is it is so selective in its broadcasting.

Where do we go from here? It is one thing after the other. Honourable senators will remember that the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, attacked Professor Kramer and then tried to force her to release the letter he had written to her. Why did he do that? He was trying to put the onus on her. In the end, we have had to force the publication of the information which revealed a grossly unedifying attempt by Senator Button to use duress. Indeed, the action taken by Senator Button was not supported by the Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy, in another place. So there is a long record of attempts at intimidation. Senator Button said today that he had been fair and that nothing could be fairer than the way the Government had approached the reconstruction of the ABC; had it not offered the Opposition a choice of the members of the panel? My goodness, I wonder whether the two Ministers concerned, the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications, Senator Button, and the Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy, remember these words now. On 6 May, when Senator Button was asked about the new Board he is quoted as saying of Professor Kramer:
In my view her name should certainly go forward for consideration, now, on the new Board of the Corporation.

Mr Duffy did better than that. He said that he would be 'surprised if Dame Leonie's name was not on the list going to Cabinet for appointment to the new Board'. He said that the names were in his head. The names went forward and not one included Professor Kramer. In fact, not one included any member of the former Australian Broadcasting Commission. It was sheer humbug for Senator Button to say: 'We gave the Opposition a choice'. The Government came forward with a panel of nine from which the Opposition had to choose seven. What kind of choice?

Let us get to the nub of this matter because these are the elements mentioned today. Senator Button's main speech was directed, because he wanted to avoid the thrust of the weakness of his Prime Minister in this, to the legislation that the former Government, the Fraser Government, brought forward to reorganise the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Everybody knows that in fact most of it was based upon the report of the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I recall what Senator Button said today, that in fact for the most part the legislation brought in by the Hawke Government was an adoption of the Fraser Government's legislation and of the Dix Committee recommendations.

Today he said what an outrage it was that there was an attempt to put into the legislation an independent complaints commissioner and that the Chairman or former office bearer of the British Broadcasting Corporation had said that it was an outrage. What a short memory Senator Button has. The BBC has an independent complaints commissioner. So much so did the BBC consider it an outrage to have somebody there appointed by the Government, who did it appoint as the first independent complaints commissioner? It was the former Lord Chief Justice. So indeed was it wrong to suggest a complaints commissioner? Was it wrong to suggest that one should have somebody like that?

What happened today was an attempt by Senator Button that must fail. He attempted to turn the whole of the argument away from the Prime Minister's reported statements. He did not deny that those statements were made. He has failed to remember what he has said in attacks on the ABC and what Mr Hawke said during the election campaign. What are the facts? The facts are that the Chairman of the ABC, Professor Kramer, came out of that unedifying effort of Senator Button's as a person, a great Australian, with great courage, with great objectivity and a total unwillingness to be pushed around by Mr Hawke or Senator Button. The world approved her stand. Her penalty for that was that she was sacked and so were her colleagues.

What happened? The Labor Party is annoyed that the ABC had the courage to show a Four Corners program on the New South Wales Rugby League. What was wrong with exposing corruption which a royal commission in the end acted upon and found the allegations proven? Indeed, one person has been the subject of conviction and another person is up for trial. What outrage is it that Government members find something wrong with a media expose of something which revealed a tragic miscarriage of justice and, indeed, perversion of the magistracy?

Mr Hawke got indignant because a young woman named Jane Singleton dared to ask him some personal questions. Government members have not been indignant when over the years people have asked many more personal questions, many more close to the bone than that. But no, the Prime Minister was in high dudgeon. Nobody is to touch the narcissus ego, the egocentric image of this Prime Minister. If they ask him a difficult question, what does he do? He gets in high dudgeon, gets on his horse and rides out of the studio.

Then what happened? Now there are all sorts of attacks upon the National Times because it published a document which it was implied here was wrong. The Attorney-General kept implying that it could not be right. But yesterday no less a person than the Chief of Defence Force Staff, Air Chief Marshal Sir Neville McNamara, said that the document was right. Is it not an outrage that the Government was caught out, that the left wing now can see what the right wing of the Labor Party is doing? It is not a question of principle. It is that it was caught out. It is irked because, remarkably, so many of the people in the media who are reporting these things with honesty are people who have been active members of the Labor Party in the past, are active members of their branches and are reporting with honesty.

The purpose of this debate is to focus upon the threatening and menacing nature of the speeches by the Prime Minister and others. Let anybody say that Michelle Grattan was reporting wrongly. Why has that not been done? It would be a bit late to do it now. The time to say that it was wrong was when Senator Button spoke. But what happened was that Senator Button, deliberately, with eloquent silence, moved away from anything of the report on Mr Hawke and talked about people talking about issues. It had nothing to do with this debate. The debate is about the threatening nature of Mr Hawke and others to the ABC that they will cut off their funds if they do not stop criticising.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If anything is absurd, to use the word from the matter of public importance raised by the Opposition, it is the matter of public importance itself. I am amazed at the effrontery of the Opposition raising this matter, based on a beat-up of a Caucus discussion in passing yesterday. Just because Michelle Grattan, for whom I have great respect, writes something, it does not make it always correct. She has been known to be wrong at odd times in the past. Senator Sir John Carrick asks for a denial of some of these things that the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, is alleged to have said. I can deny them. I do not remember many of those things being said in the debate yesterday. The Opposition argument is based on whether those reports are true. All I can say is that it is a pity that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation has not had the support of the other side of this chamber before this.

SPEECH.PARA: In passing, before I go on to other matters, I want specifically to answer Senator Sir John Carrick's point about the British Broacasting Corporation complaints commissioner. The arrangement that the BBC has is nothing like the proposal from the Liberal Party of Australia in its original Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill of 1982.

Senator Chaney took on a degree of being incredible when he said: 'I find these allegations of what is reported to have been said incredible'. Then, of course, he realised what he had said and said: 'However, I believe them'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Typical.

—It may well be typical, as Senator Ryan says. We have a matter of public importance based on several newspaper reports alleging certain statements attributed to the Prime Minister. However, we have to deal with these issues and, because they have been raised by the Opposition, I will attempt to do so. I will deal with the ABC, the National Times, and the media generally. Everyone knows that it is the Australian Labor Party and this Government which can proudly claim to support the ABC and its independence. It has a record of doing so over the years. It is in our platform and it is our policy. Our record over the years can be pointed to. We still support it. We still have to defend the ABC against attacks from the present Opposition. Members of the Opposition still flay it for being full of Marxists, a term occasionally used by members of the Opposition. A few minutes ago Senator Sir John Carrick referred to some of the people in the ABC being members of the Australian Labor Party. I suppose there may be some, but I always presume that they give much higher credence to their ethics as journalists than to any membership of the ALP in the same way as would those in that organisation who are members of other political parties, such as Senator John Carrick's own party.
—And the National Party.

—And the National Party of Australia in particular. Of course, the Opposition wants continually to criticise the ABC because it is basically opposed to its existence. It is opposed to public corporations generally. It would rather sell it off to the private sector. I suggest that the Opposition's defence of the ABC is full of hypocrisy. It is hollow for the Opposition at this stage to support ABC independence. It is the Opposition-especially the National Party part of it-which year after year has attempted to intimidate the ABC. It was the Fraser Government which ran down the ABC's funds, which led to its currently being not as good an organisation overall as many of us would like it to be. This Government wants to improve the ABC and get it back on its feet as an organisation of which we can all be proud.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course there are times when reports are inaccurate in the ABC, in the newspapers and in other parts of the media. Sometimes it is due to error and sometimes it is due to incompetence. We all admit that. Most journalists try hard to do the difficult jobs that they are given, but that does not stop them from occasionally getting things wrong. That is only a matter of great regret if that activity is consistent and if a correction is not allowed. Of course, most of the time a correction is allowed. Of course some reports are seen to be one- sided. That is part of what the media are all about. They put a point of view and represent it. We all get upset about media reports which we think do not properly represent the facts as we see them or which do not support our opinions . That applies to the ABC and to the private media. Nobody is suggesting that there is any sort of ABC conspiracy against the Government. Of course, we have to admit that the Government comes under more fire than the Opposition at times because the Government is actually doing things. The Government, and especially a reformist government like this one, is being criticised because it raises issues and because it tries to introduce new measures of change for society. All we hope is that when politicians are criticised-we are fair game after all-that criticism, if unfair, is so judged by the public.

The matter of the Jane Singleton interview on the ABC was raised as one thing that Mr Hawke might have been upset about. I did not hear the interview; I read a transcript of part of it. All I can say about that interview is that it was a good try by that journalist. She had the right to try to needle the Prime Minister, but it was also reasonable for Mr Hawke to be angry in response because he wanted to talk about policy and not about peripheral matters.

The Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy, has a record of which he can be proud. He introduced the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill in about May of last year. It included a guarantee of independence for the ABC. Section 8 of the Act states:
It is the duty of the Board-
. . . . (b) to maintain the independence and integrity of the Corporation;
(c) to ensure that the gathering and presentation by the Corporation of news and information is accurate and impartial according to the recognised standards of objective journalism;

As I said, this Government supports the independence of the ABC. That is indicated by our putting provisions relating to its independence in the Act. When the Minister introduced the Bill last year he asserted that this Government was committed to maintaining a strong and independent ABC which would be able to meet the broadcasting needs of the Australian people. This Government believes that Australia's only national broadcaster, the ABC, has served and must be able to continue to serve in the forefront of Australian broadcasting. We are proud of the ABC. We also put into the Act statutory recognition of the ABC's independent news service.

The Minister has been accused, on barely one or two occasions, of interference in the ABC. On each occasion he has, quite satisfactorily, been able to answer those accusations. They are ideas dreamed up by the Opposition. For example, Mr Lloyd, as reported at page 86 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 3 May, asked the Minister:

Was the Minister or any member of his staff approached or contacted by anyone suggesting that he intervene either to weaken the content of the Four Corners program alleging political interference by the Premier of New South Wales in the course of justice in that State or to prevent the segment being televised?
Mr Duffy said:
I thank the honourable member for his question. The answer is no.

On 5 May in the House of Representatives the Minister was asked about the litigation involving the ABC and whether there might be interference. As reported at page 245 of the House of Representatives Hansard he said:
. . . there has been no interference in respect of litigation. That has been answered. There will be in fact no interference by this Government in respect of any litigation against the ABC.

He went on to say that there would not be any interference. The former Leader of the National Party of Australia alleged that there had been an attempt to change the coverage of an election campaign on 18 October. Once again that was quite satisfactorily answered by the Minister, Mr Duffy, who believes in and supports the independence of the ABC.

I turn now to the article in the National Times. It was said that this Government was unhappy with that journal. All I can say in response to the Opposition is that I think it is healthy that papers like the National Times occasionally publish what they do and have done over the years. It might make some of us uncomfortable, but we are here to be made uncomfortable at times. We are not here only to be comfortable. We should be put on a spot when that is appropriate. When it is not appropriate we hope that the public will be able so to judge. The National Times may have been less than responsible in its editing of the extracts it used, but I was quite pleased that some of the shallow thinking and writing of the people who wrote the paper concerned was exposed. I do not see that the Australian Labor Party should be the only party to have to defend the articles. A lot of the thinking in the paper is that of the Opposition, which appointed some of those people in the first place. Certainly, I think the National Times has been consistent. It has had a consistent line to expose the defence and security establishment. I think that as long as it is fair about it and about the way it publishes it, it is legitimate. If it becomes a vendetta without being fair it is not legitimate and it is fair enough for people to criticise it in response. I think that has been accepted by both sides in this debate. Criticism of programs is quite legitimate. However, that is not interference in the independence of the ABC, the National Times or anybody else.

I turn now to the media generally. I think it is amazing to try to suggest that the Government is in a position to threaten the independence of the media. Of course, it is independent of the Government. It is privately owned. The ALP more than any other group has, over the years, suffered from newspapers generally which are opposed to its ideologies and its policies. We have not been able to do anything about that except to react and criticise in return. However, that is not interference in its independence. In any case, the attitude of particular papers can vary over the years. The Australian strongly supported Labor in 1972. By 1975 it was our most vociferous opponent. There was a continual tirade of abuse by that newspaper. Mr Murdoch even published a book proudly presenting the front pages of 1975 and related that to what he saw as the downfall of the Whitlam Government.

The Age newspaper is an establishment newspaper. It always has been and it still is. I acknowledge that in recent years it has taken a more reasonable line on many issues, has a more balanced news coverage and allows for a variety of opinions to be published. We, as politicians, have to grin and bear it when we are criticised. We can be angry and grin and bear it. The Hobart Mercury has been mostly against us. We have thought that there has often been unfair criticism. However, one can now point to a much fairer attitude by that journal. I have been pleased, in recent weeks, to see a more balanced editorial attitude. In any case, none of us should be free from criticism. The media itself should also not be free from our criticism.

If there is a threat to the independence of the media it is the threat from commercial interests. One can raise the possibility of a lack of independence because, for instance, of the effect that the tobacco advertising lobby has on newspapers. The problem that I see sometimes with the ABC, not in terms of its news coverage so much but in terms of its general programming, is the habit of the Corporation to go after ratings by having people such as Bruce Bond in its programs and being involved in promotions in which free passes to cinemas are given away in return for what is effectively the advertising of those commercial organisations.

In conclusion, one can say that if this or any other government threatens the media such a threat will rebound on it in that the media in unison will react badly to that government. So I can say that there is no basis for this matter of public importance. There is no threat. The Government is not in a position to threaten the media, and especially the ABC which will remain independent. It will do so with the wholehearted support of me and the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance which was ably brought forward by the Leader of the Opposition , Senator Chaney. The matter of public importance reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The threat to the independence of the media posed by the Government's absurd over-reaction to any critical comment.

This matter has arisen as a result of remarkably uniform publicity which appeared in today's newspapers. The stories which appear today in various newspapers right across the nation bear a very great resemblance to one another. Those newspapers contain reports of the Australian Labor Party Caucus meeting which was held in Canberra yesterday. The newspapers commented upon certain statements made by both the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, other Ministers and other members of the Parliament with regard to the effectiveness or otherwise of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

I would like to make the point that Senator Coates, who has just finished his speech, acknowledged the very point that we are making and the points that were made in today's newspaper articles. Clearly, Senator Coates stood up here today and defended the independence of the ABC and other Press organisations to put down a critical view of the Government. That point, of course, has been clearly acknowledged. It is the basis of our matter of public importance today. We are very glad that Senator Coates has seen fit to support the Opposition on this matter. I hope that he has a great deal of satisfaction in addressing that matter to the Prime Minister. No doubt he will seek to make that point in the course of debate in the Caucus when the next occasion arises.

The point clearly has to be made that the Government, through the Prime Minister, apparently as a result of the articles which appear in the Press, is clearly trying to browbeat the Press and the independent media in this country. I do not have to put forward those words on my own behalf. I need only quote what was said by that very significant, independent and very well respected political reporter, Robert Haupt, when interviewed today in Canberra on the Channel 7 Today show. He said that that was exactly the objective of the Prime Minister yesterday-to browbeat the media into accepting the line which the Government wants to put down. He drew the attention of the public to this very significant attempt to muzzle the independent media which, of course, is the funnel for dissenting views in this country.

I think it is very obvious that, if one follows the course of events in recent times that the Prime Minister has taken, one can see that he appears to be so brittle when under attack. The fact is that he so easily falls apart at the seams when asked questions about his personal life of matters affecting his policies which are not accepted at face value by the media or others. These are the occasions on which this kind of attack commences. We have seen this a number of times not only from the Prime Minister but also from leading members of the Government. We recall Senator Button's outrageous attacks on Professor Dame Leonie Kramer last year. All of us will remember that particular episode which brought degradation to Senator Button's reputation. Of course, this attack was very ably handled by the Chairman of the ABC who as a result, of course, was fired from her job.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?

—The Government, of course, will deny that. Obviously that is a very clear statement in the light of the events that occurred at that time. Then , of course, there was the famous Rugby League issue that the Four Corners program had the temerity to bring forward. It was claimed that leading members of the Australian Labor Party were involved and they were referred to. There were inferences in connection with certain activities on the part of leading members of the Labor Party.
—Oh, rubbish.

—Well, why was the Government so sensitive about it? Why did the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) get up at that time and deny that point so clearly? Why did he criticise and attack the ABC for having the temerity to get up and say these things in public? They were not the only cases that have occurred in recent times. In the last few months we have seen attacks on the National Times and in particular the Age newspapers by Senator Evans, the Attorney-General. The first law officer of the country, who is a champion of civil rights, has been attacking the independent media. But again he has used the power of his position and that of the Government to browbeat the media into submission to the Government's particular viewpoint. We saw this only in the last few days in regard to the National Times articles about defence leaks. Consequently and obviously the sensitivity of this Government knows no bounds. Senator Coates and his colleagues have made pathetic attempts to defend the Government's point of view. Indeed, they have fallen for the trap of admitting the problem and supporting the Opposition and as a result indirectly criticising the Prime Minister. I would like to reiterate an earlier point that I made, and that is that there is a remarkable consistency in the articles which appeared in the newspaper today.
—That proves that they are right, does it?

—Whether the honourable senator claims they are right or wrong is beside the point. It appears to me that someone in the Government has a very clear objective in mind because the leak was quite obviously released in such a way that one can see that the Government is out to damage the media generally. It appears to me that this is a determined and deliberate attempt to muzzle the media in these circumstances. Why else would these reports read in such a consistent manner? Every newspaper, every reporter appears to have been given the same story. This is quite clearly the way in which this exercise has been undertaken. This Government stands absolutely condemned in the eyes of the public for its attempt to deny independence to the media which, is, of course, its basic right.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the reasons why the Government perhaps has chosen to do this at this time. For the last several months we have been warmed up to the idea that we should have an election this year. The Prime Minister has very coyly hinted at an election either in the latter part of this year or in the early part of next year. The story about elections, of course, is well known. Every time a Prime Minister, especially a Labor Prime Minister, seeks to go to the polls such a step must be clearly to his advantage. Therefore, we are being exercised towards a point of view which accepts that an election this year is good for the nation, just as everything else that the Government claims to do is good for the nation. The timing of that election is critical to the fortunes of the Government. It is the Prime Minister's intention to ensure that there is no election next year. We must ask: Why does he want an election this year? The answer is obvious. He knows that he cannot win an election next year because of the collapsing policies of his Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is ludicrous. Don't you read the newspapers?

—I can read the gallup polls as well as the Minister for Education can. However, those polls do not tell the whole story, and she knows it. She knows that the Government wants an election this year so that it can confuse the people in putting back the present Government on the basis of false promises and false premises. The policies of this Government that were announced before the election last year have either not been put into place or have been totally denied. One has only to quote the assets test as an example. The Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, in his remarks dealt with the lump sum superannuation tax. I remind the Government that it is now 10 months since that announcement was made, and still we have seen no legislation on that topic. Is the Government running scared? Indeed it is. It does not want that legislation in the Parliament while it is thinking of an early election. So it is the case with the assets test and many other matters.

SPEECH.PARA: One has only to examine the Senate Notice Paper to realise how little legislation the Government is bringing forward for discussion. For all the business the Government has put on the Notice Paper we could easily pack up here tonight and go home. The Government is hoodwinking the people of Australia on the basis that it wants to be elected this year. It has not got the guts to go to the people next year when the result, as it knows, will be entirely different . This is at the base of the Government's attacks on the media and the way it has undertaken those attacks in an orchestrated way in the last few days. Those matters are at the core of the Government's intention and lie clearly before us all as an obvious attempt to pull wool over the people's eyes.

The activity in the last day or two is not the first attempt-and it will not be the last-by the Government to try to confuse people through control of the media . Before the last election great concern was expressed by Senator Button, who criticised the former Government for its activities carried out through the Government Information Unit. Yet this country has seen established the greatest example of thought police in this country's history through the establishment of the National Media Liaison Service, which is spending more than one million dollars a year. Today senators had put on their desks another edition of a wonderful document which claims that the Unit is putting the Government's activities in focus. It is doing it in such a way that one can see nothing else in the photograph but the Government and its so-called achievements. There is not a mention of the issues which it has avoided. No publicity is given to the Opposition and its views; merely favourable news is presented in a biased way in the document. It presents no balance, even though the Government claims to have a monopoly in such matters. The document is an absolute disgrace.
It is an attempt to issue pure propaganda to the public over the name of and printed by the Government Printer. It is outrageous that the Government has undertaken that kind of activity.

The point has been well and truly made in this debate that this Government is deliberately setting out on a campaign of muzzling the media in an election year . It knows that it will be going to the people this year, preferably before the Budget, when it has to disclose the size of the Budget deficit and when it has to admit that it cannot offer the tax cuts it claimed it would give to the people. Already the present Government has laid the groundwork for that kind of proposition. Consequently, the Government will continue its obvious activities to hoodwink the people of Australia. Let the Government, in all the honesty over which it claims to have a monopoly, examine the activities of the National Media Liaison Service. I challenge Senator Coates to examine what is going on in that bureau in Tasmania. If he can satisfy himself as to the honesty of its activity, that it is providing a genuine service for all parliamentarians, I will withdraw my remarks, but I guarantee he will find the opposite to be true. If the Government wants to prove the honesty of its position, let it challenge the National Media Liaison Service now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to close this debate-a debate which has been the greatest waste of time in this place ever inflicted by the Opposition on the Government. We have many problems in the area of manufacturing industry. We have problems of poverty and remaining problems of discrimination. Those are all matters which this Government believes should be debated in a constructive fashion in this place. But what does the Opposition bring before the Senate today? An absolute non-event which it claims is a matter of public importance; namely, a complaint that as a result of some media reporting of some views that were supposed to be expressed by some members of Caucus yesterday somehow the Government is threatening the independence of the media. What an absurd accusation, and what a waste of time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition today has reached the nadir of its parliamentary performance. I cannot think of anything sillier than that at a time when we all admit we have serious economic, social and other problems in our society, all the Opposition can do is to read the newspaper, see a little bit of garbled reporting about what may or may not have been said in the Caucus room yesterday, and try to blow it up into some kind of issue relating to the independence of the media. It is pathetic and displays yet again the total lack of capacity in the Opposition for any kind of analytical approach to the serious problems facing our economy. In a sense, the media are the only opposition in this country. There is no opposition on the benches opposite. The Opposition has no idea how to present views on the serious problems facing our society. If it were not for the media in this country I do not think anything of public importance would ever be raised. The Opposition is clearly incapable of deciding for itself that something is important. Opposition members merely examine the morning papers, pick on the most trivial aspects of reportage and then bring them into the Senate in order to waste everybody's time debating them.

I find it particularly ironical that we suddenly have an Opposition composed of the conservative elements in this place accusing a Labor Government of attempting to interfere with the independence of the media, in particular the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. I came into this place first in 1976. During my first few years in this place I, in common with my colleagues Senator Sibraa and Senator Colston who joined me at that time, sat in this place day after day listening to abuse, attacks and accusation about the ABC. Scarcely a day passed without conservative members of the then Government attacking the ABC for political bias and all sorts of Marxist plots. It was a pathetic performance . Not only did members of the then Government attack the ABC for its alleged bias; they made practical attacks and undermined the capacity of the ABC to be this country's major public broadcasting organisation. I can remember a few of them because I sat here day after day and had to listen to them. There were funding cuts.

Have a look at what happened to the budget of the ABC, a matter now of such new and sudden enthusiasm of Opposition members. Honourable senators should have a look at what that Government did to the funding of the ABC during its seven years in government. Have a look at what it did to the staffing of the ABC during its seven years of government. It ran them both down to the stage where we inherited a ramshackle broadcasting organisation in the place of what had once been one of Australia's finest public institutions. Honourable senators should have a look at the talent drain that occurred from the ABC during the period of the Fraser Administration. Journalist after journalist, current affairs analyst after current affairs analyst, left the ABC because they could no longer work in such a run-down organisation, because they could no longer tolerate the political attacks that were being made on them by the Government. There was an exodus of talent from the ABC during that time which greatly weakened its capacity to fulfil its statutory responsibilities to the Australian people. There was almost a cessation of training of new, young talent. Look at any area in the ABC now-the technical, production, journalism, drama and cultural areas-and honourable senators will find that virtually now new young talent has been trained over the last few years; again one of the reasons for the fact that we inherited such a chaotic and ramshackle organisation.

Honourable senators should look at the discriminatory employment practices which prevailed within the ABC during the Fraser administration, documented discriminatory practices-(Quorum formed) It is just further evidence of the absolute poverty of the Opposition's approach to what it alleges today to be a serious topic that Senator Jessop walks in and the only intelligent contribution he can make to the debate is to call a quorum and thus cut short the time allowed for the debate.

I was pointing out that the present Opposition has an appalling record with regard to the ABC. As a result of that when we came into government a year ago we inherited an organisation which had deteriorated drastically from what it had been in its heyday. There was a time when the ABC was one of Australia's finest public institutions in terms of current affairs, dissemination of information, development of Australia's cultural life, education and in bringing services to regional and remote areas. It had an outstanding record. But all of that was virtually destroyed during the period of the Fraser administration.

Now what have we done? My colleague, the Leader in this place, Senator Button, pointed out that we approached the business of restoring the capacity of the ABC to its central role in our democracy in a very open-minded and bipartisan fashion. What have we done to the ABC? We have given it a new board, which was appointed with the consultation and agreement of Opposition members, a land-mark in a bipartisan approach to the ABC. We have given the ABC more money. We have given it a new charter, enormous freedom in its employment and management practices, and the board has appointed a new manager. We hope that it will in time regain the central and constructive place it had in Australian social and political life.

As yet I have not seen a great deal of evidence that many changes have taken place. In fact I feel, I guess along with a lot of honourable senators in this place, a little disappointed that we have not seen more improvements implemented more rapidly in the last 12 months. But being reasonable-and we on this side of the chamber are reasonable-we must recognise that we cannot undo the damage of seven years of attacks, demoralisation and political interference, all of which have been documented in the debate today, in a one year period. So we still have very high aspirations that the ABC will be able to improve its performance, and we look forward very much to that happening, not because we are worried about the occasional criticism or the occasional negative item on the ABC concerning the Government, but because of our deep philosophical commitment to the idea of a publicly funded independent broadcasting corporation which can reflect at the highest possible standards comment, consideration and information on all the major economic, social and cultural issues of our time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you tell the Prime Minister that yesterday?

—They are our aspirations for the ABC. Senator Chaney has just joined the debate. Quite clearly our aspirations have not yet been realised. Obviously a year has not been enough time. I believe that there are still areas of the ABC where the standard of program delivery is poor. I say that without attempting to undermine our aspirations for what the ABC should be. The Opposition, with its incapacity to analyse anything accurately, seems to be unable to distinguish between the criticism that might fairly and justly be made of a particular item or, indeed, of a particular journalist or program, with a fundamental attack on the institution itself. We, in the Australian Labor Party and now the Labor Government, have been the historical, traditional defenders of the ABC, and we continue to be that. Now that does not mean that we must turn a blind eye or must pretend that every item, every program and every journalist is performing or is presented at the highest possible standard. Quite clearly that is not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many defects in the performance of the ABC, defects which have their roots in the attacks on it made by the Fraser Government. Obviously members of our Government criticise individual items on the ABC, and the ABC criticises us for criticising it. What is new in that? I am really glad Senator Chaney has come in because he has inflicted this debate on us, he has pretended that there is something novel and shocking in an individual politician being critical of an individual item or even an individual journalist. I think that politicians and journalists are engaged in a natural adversary situation and will continue to criticise each other for as long as we have a democracy in this country. For the Opposition to pretend there is something shocking--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The honourable senator is totally misrepresenting my case and the case of the Opposition, which specifically said that we were not talking about that sort of complaint.
—The honourable senator is making a point and not a point of order.

—That is another pathetic attempt by the Leader of the Opposition ( Senator Chaney) to dissuade the listening public from the fact that the Opposition is absolutely impoverished of ideas, absolutely impoverished of any constructive approach to any issue of public importance at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to pass briefly to the other dreadful attack we are accused of making, on the National Times. Frankly, I am very disappointed in the National Times because it seems to me that the National Times misses many opportunities. This country, this society, really needs a high quality weekly journal that makes critical, informed comment about economic, social and cultural issues and so on. DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts I present a progress report on the Committee's reference: The development and implementation of a co-ordinated language policy for Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Honourable senators will recall that the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts has before it the following reference: 'The development and implementation of a co-ordinated language policy for Australia'. This matter was originally referred to the Standing Committee by the Senate on 25 May 1982 but lapsed with the double dissolution of the Parliament on 4 February last year. On 10 May 1983 I informed the Senate that the new Committee had decided to continue the reference. On that occasion I referred to the wide scope of the reference. The Committee has identified 12 separate areas of inquiry. These range from the role of English and the learning of modern languages, to the educational use of Aboriginal languages.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I am making a report to the Senate on the Committee's progress on the reference. Public hearings on the reference began in Canberra on 24 September 1982 when the Committee took evidence from the Commonwealth Department of Education and Youth Affairs and Professor Einar Haugen, Emeritus Professor of Harvard University and a world renowned socio-linguist. Public hearings concluded, again in Canberra, on 31 October 1983 when the Committee took evidence of a supplementary nature from, amongst others, Commonwealth departments and instrumentalities concerned with language issues.

The Committee's public hearings were held not only in Canberra but also in all State capitals, in Darwin and in Alice Springs. The Committee received 240 submissions and 179 documents, and took evidence from 94 witnesses. One of the submissions was written in Walmajarri, an Aboriginal language of the north east of Western Australia. The evidence taken by the Committee related to matters as diverse as Aboriginal broadcasting and the provision of library material for the handicapped. The transcript of proceedings of the Committee's 21 public hearings totalled 2,393 pages.

During the course of the inquiry the Committee visited two schools-the North Ainslie Primary School in the Australian Capital Territory, which teaches Modern Greek, and St Therese's School on Bathurst Island, which conducts bilingual schooling in English and Tiwi. The Committee also visited the Midway Migrant Centre at Maribyrnong in Victoria to observe the teaching of English as a second language to refugee adults and children.

The Committee wishes to thank all those who gave of their time, knowledge and experience in preparing submissions for the inquiry. It also wishes to thank all those who appeared before it to give evidence. As well, thanks are extended to the teachers and administrators at the education institutions which were visited . The Committee assures all who provided submissions that matters raised in their submissions will be taken into consideration in its final report.

The Committee's work on the reference has suffered two interruptions. Firstly, on 1 October 1982, the Senate referred to Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill 1982 to the Committee for inquiry and report by 16 November 1982. Secondly, as I mentioned earlier, the Committee ceased to exist with the dissolution of the Parliament on 4 February 1983 and work on the inquiry did not recommence until 5 May 1983. Despite these interruptions, the Committee has completed its public hearings and is now drafting its final report. Owing to the complexity and wide scope of the reference, the drafting will require considerable time. The Committee has, however, set itself the task of finalising a report for tabling as early as practicable in the 1984 Budget session of the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson, Senator Georges and I were members of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts which looked at the matter of the Australian War Memorial. The War Memorial was originally the subject of the Committee's 196th report which was tabled in April 1982. That report looked at the curatorial and conservation functions of the Memorial. Those problems were the subject of a response from the Department of Finance through the standard procedure of a Finance minute. During 1983 the outstanding matters which were raised by the Public Accounts Committee in respect of the War Memorial were finalised by the Finance minute procedure; that is, the response from the Department is in fact the subject of this report we are discussing today; the 221st Report of the Public Accounts Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Originally the report looked only at the War Memorial itself, but during the inquiry it became evident to all members that there were problems in other institutions and the report was widened to look at Australia's entire national collection. I am pleased to say that some of the original Public Accounts Committee Australian War Memorial recommendations have now been implemented. For example, there has been, as recommended, an expansion of staff ceilings at the Memorial. There has been the creation of a number of permanent positions of curator and approval has been given by the Government for a position of registrar of collections. I am pleased to note that the Government has given approval for an $11m modernisation and renovation building program at the Memorial. That will enable an enlarged aircraft hall to be constructed. At present a number of aircraft are being kept in very unsatisfactory conditions.

The original problems at the Memorial were identified by the Auditor-General during a comprehensive audit in 1979-80. He found inadequate control of items, security problems, inadequate stocktaking, and general problems with the assessment of the collection. There were gaps in catalogues and there was nothing in the way of maintenance or restoration programs. As a response to those problems being identified the Australian War Memorial put a response before the Public Accounts Committee. In that response it was very interestingly pointed out that it held some four million items in the Australian War Memorial and a value of over $100m was put on the collection. In responding, the Memorial saw that staff shortages were the major problem in maintaining the collection. The Australian War Memorial conceded most of the points made by the Auditor- General as to the inadequacies of the organisation.

The Public Accounts Committee, in carrying out its investigations, said that the problems at the Memorial were not unique within the national collection. It went on to examine a number of other elements of our national collection. It looked at the National Library of Australia, the Australian National Gallery and the Australian Archives. The Public Accounts Committee came down with the unfortunate conclusion that Australia's national collection was at a crisis stage following years of neglect and lack of recognition of its worth. It is interesting to note in that connection that the Memorial itself indicated that something like 450-man years of work was required just to overcome the conservation backlog; that was basically just to overcome the most pressing problems.

The Public Accounts Committee saw a need for a more equitable and co-ordinated allocation of resources within the national collection. It saw the need for a review from the national viewpoint as to the value of the national collection and the price the nation was prepared to pay for its being maintained. As a result of the investigations by the Public Accounts Committee, in 1982 we saw the establishment of the Advisory Committee on National Collections which includes representatives of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment which chairs the Committee, the National Library, the Australian Archives, the Australian War Memorial, the National Gallery and provisionally the Museum of Australia. The functions of ACNC will be to advise the Minister and to report on such matters as the scope for increased co-operation and the sharing of resources between the various institutions in the national collection such as conservation staff and to prepare a study of ways and means of improving conservation in this country.

In relation to the Australian War Memorial, the Public Accounts Committee specifically recommended that a corporate plan be adopted by that body. I am pleased to say that that recommendation was adopted. The institution now has a plan for the period to 1987. The Committee also recommended that all institutions within the national collection make staff aware of the need for preventative conservation and that appropriate storage conditions be provided for in handling and care of documents. Those matters are now being looked at. Even matters that many people would believe are mundane, such as the quality of paper on which records are prepared, are now being examined. Suitable paper for storage of Australian Government records and so forth for future years is being provided.

The Public Accounts Committee also recommended that early action be taken to house the existing collection, to ensure that that occurred in an organised and effective manner and to catalogue fully all items of the collection. In respect of the Museum of Australia, the new store is to be completed this year. I believe that some of the national ethnographic collection will be kept in that store. The Public Accounts Committee also recommended in respect of the Australian War Memorial that there be a more formalised approach to staff training, development and research activities and said that action was needed if the Memorial were to perform its museum role. During 1983 in response to that recommendation a survey was done at the Memorial of staff training needs. Certainly there is momentum in that area.

The Public Accounts Committee also recommended a program of management for conservation be implemented by the Memorial as a priority matter. The Committee has been informed in the minute of the Department of Finance that over the next five years there is to be a systematic conservation stocktake of all collections within the national collection. The proposal for the Museum of Australia is proceeding. One element of that proposal is for a national maritime museum. I have taken note of the excellent and comprehensive study put forward by the State Government in South Australia for a maritime museum to be located in that State.

In conclusion, I think the Public Accounts Committee can take some credit for being the catalyst which identified the conservation crisis in Australia's national collections. I certainly acknowledge that thanks should go to the Department of Home Affairs and Environment and the various agencies in the national collection for their positive response to the Public Accounts Committee report. Overall, the Committee is pleased that the main thrust of its recommendations in relation to the national collection has been accepted and implemented. In fact, the Committee is more than satisfied with the responses it received, and I think that is an unusual result to achieve in an inquiry. It shows what can be achieved by parliamentary committees. It is vital that our national collection be maintained and restored to a high standard. After all, it forms a key part of our national heritage. It is hoped that much will have been done in time for the bicentenary year celebrations. In the period leading up to the bicentenary I believe that we can show that the effects of the past neglect of our national collection can be rectified. I seek leave to continue my remarks .
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

CLASSIFICATION OF PUBLICATIONS ORDINANCE]
