SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the continuation of a debate commenced this morning when Senator Mason and Senator Harradine moved for the disallowance of regulations and ordinances concerned with the new Commonwealth censorship procedures adopted in relation to publications. The regulations and ordinances brought down by the Government have created a complete shemozzle in the States. A meeting of Attorneys-General last year agreed that there ought to be some uniformity throughout Australia in the application of censorship procedures to pornographic material. However, the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in his usual fashion brought down regulations and ordinances that were meant to be substantiated by the States. Of course, that has not occurred. The States have not yet put in place regulations and ordinances; they have not yet passed the necessary legislation to make the censorship procedures uniform throughout Australia. The Attorney-General thought it a good idea at the time-he could not resist it-to put in place the legislation enacting those regulations and ordinances even though the States have not yet put in place complementary legislation. The situation now is that the States find it difficult to do anything about dealing with the literature and publications-that includes videotapes-entering those States. The Attorney-General, in a paper in which he sought to explain the new procedures, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The barriers to the importation of hardcore pornography have been lifted. There are some exceptions other than child pornography-publications which incite terrorism and publications containing extreme violence and/or sexual violence.

The Attorney-General said that, apart from those sorts of publications, the barriers to the importation of pornography have been lifted. He went on to assure us that this step is being taken because the Government believes that adult persons are entitled to read and view what they wish. The Attorney-General assured the Senate today that, apart from Senator Harradine and me and a few other extreme people, all Australians support the action he has taken. I ask the Attorney-General whether he has any evidence at all that suggests that the Australian people support the expansion of the range of hardcore pornography available in this country. The range has been expanded to include X rated or Category 2 material. The guidelines laid down by the Attorney-General-I will come to this matter later-are extreme from anyone's viewpoint.

TALK.START.PARA: —The biggest obscenity of all is war and you never say anything about that.

—I pay Senator Gietzelt the compliment of believing that he would not be very interested in Category 2 stuff. No matter how extreme Senator Gietzelt is, I do not really believe that he would relish watching that sort of stuff. Senator Gietzelt may not have even looked at the guidelines and therefore may not even know what they contain. We are told that the Commonwealth, which up to date has supposedly had complete legislative control over the sort of pornography imported into Australia, will now wash its hands of that control and the the Film Censorship Board is to be told that all it can do is say whether material should be prohibited from import. The guidelines are very explicit. Indeed, Senator Evans says very clearly that publications prohibited from importation will include child pornography involving minors under 16 years of age, publications that promote, incite or encourage terrorism, and those that gratuitously depict extreme cruelty, particularly when combined with a sexual element. He makes it clear that the Film Censorship Board and those who censor publications will be able to prohibit the importation of material that comes into those three categories only. All other material will be able to be registered. The States must make their own arrangements. Of course, he ignores the fact that the States have not yet made their own arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General has said that at the State level distributors will not be compelled to seek to have videotapes classified, that the seeking of a classification will be completely voluntary. It will be up to the distributors whether they have classified the video tapes they send out. I have received many complaints from people who live in the Australian Capital Territory. Yet the Territory has the necessary legislation in place. Residents of the Australian Capital Territory have complained that when they have gone to a video shop to find something for young family viewing over the weekend they have found that the videotapes available contain no classification. The tapes do not show whether they are suitable for general viewing or whether parental guidance is recommended. People do not know what sort of video they might be buying. They are obliged to ask the proprietor whether a particular video will be suitable for viewing by 7 and 8-year-olds.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would be pretty dim, wouldn't you?
—Senator Robertson can laugh but he should look at the situation in the Australian Capital Territory.
—I have. You are talking a lot of nonsense.

—If Senator Robertson questions what I am saying, obviously he has not looked at the situation in the Australian Capital Territory. He is interested only in the Northern Territory. The Commonwealth Government enacts legislation that affects the Australian Capital Territory. The situation is that parents in the Australian Capital Territory have no indication at all whether the videotapes are suitable for viewing by 7 or 8-year-olds. They are obliged to ask the individual proprietor whether he believes a particular videotape is suitable for a 7-year-old to look at. Obviously a system under which the distributors are able to seek a classification on a voluntary basis will not work. Belatedly the Attorney-General has said that he can see some sense in such a suggestion and that perhaps such a system will not work. Perhaps the system of seeking classification has to be a compulsory one. Perhaps the distributors will have to be made to go through the censorship procedures and have video tapes classified.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 19 of the ordinance sets out in quite a bit of detail the classifications for printed work. The Attorney-General's Department has laid down quite clear guidelines as to what material is likely to be contained in Category 1 and Category 2 publications, those being the restricted publications. Category 2, which is the new classification, is quite incredible. I ask the Attorney whether he has brought to the attention of honourable senators opposite the guidelines that he has set down, because when I read them through I did not know what they meant. I got out a dictionary and could not find all the words in the guidelines in it. Honourable senators opposite might be very sophisticated in this area, but I have not found one member of our side of the Parliament who knows what all of them mean. Perhaps honourable senators opposite deal more with this sort of thing and know about it in some detail, because through interjections they claim that there is something wrong with me that I do not understand all the words. Perhaps they are more au fait with the subject.

I invite the Attorney-General to tell me, by way of interjection, whether there are similar guidelines for videotapes as there are for printed publications with pictorial material. I am very keen to find out whether that is the case. I did ask the Attorney-General's office whether it could ascertain for me whether there were clear guidelines regarding videotapes. I was told that there might be ; the office did not know but it would try to find out for me. I have applied several times and have been told that the office still does not know and, up to this time, it is still trying to find out for me. I ask the Attorney-General again whether there are any set guidelines.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator should direct her questions through the Chair.

—Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask the Attorney- General whether there are similar guidelines for videos. Have similar guidelines been put out in relation to the classification of videos as there have been in relation to categories 1 and 2 of printed material with pictorial matter?
—Yes. As I told you through my staff, there are draft guidelines in existence prepared by the Chief Censor which are to be debated and discussed by the ministerial council on Friday.
—Are we entitled to see them?
—No more than you are entitled to see the first lot.

—I am not quite sure why. I was told by the Attorney-General's Department that they could be confidential. This really worries me. We are being asked to consider and vote on whether the Attorney-General's guidelines should be brought down and I have been told that I am not entitled to see them. What sort of a position are we put in? I have in my hand the guidelines relating to printed publications with pictorials. I do not have the guidelines concerning videos. I asked the Attorney whether he would give me the guidelines for the videos and he told me that they are confidential and that there is no way I am entitled to see them. Senator Harradine has just given me a copy. Yes, I see that they are the same as those applying to printed material.
—Read them out.

—Senator Chipp has asked me to read them out. There is no way I will read them out. He can read them himself. The Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly has already had second thoughts about these regulations and ordinances. It passed them but on 27 March it unanimously decided to have a rethink. The House of Assembly sent the whole lot to its Standing Committee on Education and Community Affairs. The amendment that was unanimously agreed to by the House of Assembly stated that the Standing Committee on Education and Community Affairs should urgently consider the implications of the changed Customs regulations and their relation to the Classification of Publications Ordinance. Mrs Cains said she moved the amendment because she believed the Committee had not understood the situation previously. Obviously she was correct because Ms Walmsley joined her-those women do not usually see eye to eye-and said:

SPEECH.PARA: I share her concern that the current regulations to the Customs Ordinance do enable material to come into Australia which clearly are exploitation of women.

So it went on. Everyone who took part in the debate agreed and the motion was passed unanimously. The House of Assembly is certainly having second thoughts and is taking action to overcome the problem. I fail to understand one thing: The feminists opposite would normally join me on this issue, I should have thought, yet there is complete silence from the Labor women opposite. Normally they would say they believed the exploitation of women was abhorrent. I do not believe any women in Australia would be party to passing this sort or rubbish. I do not believe any women would agree with it. Yet Labor women opposite kowtow, do not put up a fight and pass this sort of stuff. Perhaps at the meeting on Friday the Attorneys-General will be more aware of the feelings in this place. Senator Evans has said that he wants us to put off debate until after the meeting of Attorneys-General and that he will convey our feelings to the Attorneys-General. He does not want a vote to be taken. I can assure the Attorney-General that nothing will impress the Attorneys-General more than this place saying: 'We will not go along with those regulations and ordinances'. There was not complete agreement at the last Attorneys-General meeting. Tasmania and Queensland did not agree to this action. Both Tasmania and Queensland want compulsory certifications. The Attorney-General has attempted to put forward that the Attorneys-General were in close agreement. There was no close agreement at all.

Let us consider what is happening in Sweden. I do not know how many people saw the film Not a Love Story which was screened in Canberra. Sweden was one of the countries which originally opened the doors to pornography. The film Not a Love Story depicts exactly what is happening in Sweden at the moment. Sweden is now seeking more controls on pornography. The film pointed out that the reason Sweden is moving back to more controls is that, when the gates were opened, a certain standard of hard core pornography, which was pretty low, appeared. Over the years it became worse and worse until now it is so bad that the powers that be in Sweden are saying: 'We have had enough; it is sickening. We are moving back'. Let us look at what happened.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the nature of pornography; the devotees are never satisfied.
—Let us look at 1971 when Senator Chipp was Minister for Customs and Excise.
—I never let pornography in. Are you saying I did?

—Senator Chipp should listen. I am saying that we should look at 1971 when he was Minister. At that time, in February 1971, a debate was on about censorship. At that time both parties had a free debate. It was not a party debate. It was a conscience issue. I believe that is what should be happening here. Again, I ask the Attorney-General whether he will allow his party a free vote on this.
—No, of course not. Don't be absurd.

—It is absolutely incredible. He says: 'No. I have got them caucused. There is no way I would give them a free vote'. I asked him whether he would give them a free vote and he said: 'No, not on your life'. He has got them caucused. What more does he want?
—I wish it was up to me, but I don't have any say in it.

—He did not say it was not up to him. He just said: 'No, I will not give them a free vote'. There was an agreement in 1971-I am sure Senator Chipp will remember-between the States and the Commonwealth Ministers. The State and Commonwealth Ministers then introduced an R rating. This present agreement between the States and the Federal Government is not new. It has been done before. In 1971 Senator Chipp stated that there was agreement between the State and Commonwealth Ministers on an R certificate rating. At that time he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is my fond hope that by the middle of this year the R certificate system will be in operation throughout Australia despite the vigorous and spirited opposition that is being conducted by people in certain quarters.
So for the first time we had an R rating. He went on to say-he may well laugh at this:

That is all I have to say, except that I wish to give an example of material covered by some of my last remarks. I am being criticised rather extensively for the prohibition of 'Playboy'. This comes under the heading of taking account of the limited availability of some works. Only 2 issues of 'Playboy' have been banned since the beginning of 1969 and I would regard-
get a load of this; this is Senator Chipp-
the standards of this magazine as a bench mark beyond which we will not go in permissiveness as far as sex is concerned.

That was not so very long ago, 1971. In 1971 we moved to an R rating and, according to the Minister at that time, Senator Chipp, he would not allow anything more permissive than Playboy. Ten years later we moved to an X rating. What will happen in the next 10 years? What will happen by 1991? Will we then think it is all right to have child pornography too?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—We are now told 'no' by the Government but in 1971 we were told by Senator Chipp that we would not move from Playboy, that it would not get any worse than that under his Ministry. We have had this gradual erosion, to which Senator Chipp alluded earlier, of standards. Senator Gareth Evans has said that no State government-it was a play with words-has objected outright to the Federal Government's procedures. He could have said that only one State Government, South Australia, has complementary legislation. But he did not put it that way. He did not put it that only one State Government has already got complementary legislation. He said that no State government has objected outright to the Federal procedures. Perhaps we will find that out on Friday. It depends on what impression one wants to make. About half an hour or so ago I received a letter from the video industry; boy, is it putting on the hard word.
—Ha, ha!

—It depends on one's mind, Senator Grimes. Members of that industry are lobbying very hard and saying: 'For heaven's sake, do not disallow it'. I wonder why they are saying that. It would not be a bob or two to them, would it? The letter states-it is completely dishonest:

SPEECH.PARA: If the ordinance is disallowed those X rated video movies may be available without restriction-
At least they have the honesty to say 'may' be available without restriction. The letter continues:
including to children. This would cause some concern and I am sure it is not the intention of the Senate to create such a state of confusion.

What absolute rubbish! It is not the truth. I hope those in the video industry who have any sort of regard for their credibility will take the author of this thing to task when they read Hansard, if they are interested enough to read it. All that will occur if the regulations are disallowed is that the Government will be able to enforce the present legislation, the law as it is now, that states that a person shall not sell or otherwise publish for gain an objectionable publication. All the Government has to do is enforce the law. There will be no need for the X rated videos to be available without restriction , as the industry tries to tell us will happen, nor are the videos likely to get into the hands of children, as the industry would like us to believe, if we dare try to stop it being able to sell this sort of stuff.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is untruthful blackmail.

—It is complete blackmail and I am surprised that the industry would do that. But no doubt other members of the industry will indeed take the author to task about it. As I said earlier, the barriers for importation of hard pornography, according to the Attorney-General, have been lifted. We are now faced with the situation of the Commonwealth washing its hands of its responsibility. I am not liable to wash my hands of that responsibility, nor is the Opposition nor, evidently, the Australian Democrats or Senator Harradine. We will see what the Attorney-General can accomplish on Friday. I have much pleasure in supporting both the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine in their motions for the disallowance of those regulations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address the important considerations raised by these motions, not so much the administration, et cetera of the regulations and so on alluded to but more the underlying philosophical questions addressed by these motions. Firstly, the question that has to be addressed is how much importance we place on civil liberties. I have heard Senator Mason argue that this society takes decisions to deny individual civil liberties, for example, the case of road rules. I know also from my medical experience that our society quite clearly supported the mandatory requirement for smallpox vaccination until very recently when the world was declared free of smallpox. No individual could insist his or her right to go without a smallpox vaccination on returning to Australia without submitting to some numbers of weeks in quarantine.

SPEECH.PARA: In both of those cases there was a clear denial of individual civil liberties on behalf of the common good. In both of those cases common sense prevailed, that is, the good sense that balances community good against individual needs or preferences. However, I believe that they are not good analogies for the question we are addressing here. In both of those illustrations there is clear evidence and a clear understanding of the balance of community good against the loss of individual civil liberty. In this debate, the civil liberty issue is whether or not we judge that adults in Australia are entitled to read, hear and see what they wish, in private. We do not have any solid evidence to suggest that that happening in this community leads to a considerable loss of the common good of the community. There are claims of evidence to support that view. But I believe that view is not widely held or widely substantiated. By that I do not mean to necessarily justify that there are not some people who are ill-affected by their freedom to watch, read or see such material. But in terms of the analogy proposed by Senator Mason, I do not believe there is any evidence to substantiate the common good versus individual liberties in this case as in the previous mentioned cases.

I want to address the way this debate has been shaped or taken up recently by a number of women, in particular, by a group calling itself WAVE, Women Against Violence and Exploitation. This group has focused its concern on the proposed X rating classification for videos and the corresponding State legislation to legalise the sale of hard core porn videos. The X rating classification has the support of many groups which have sought consumer guidance; that is, some information about the content of videos so that people can make informed or appropriate choices depending on their preference. A number of honourable senators have alluded to the fact that some people, when they have gone to borrow or buy videos, have found, at the end of an acceptable family film or G rated movie, that they have been submitted to trailers about movies of a quite different sort, sometimes trailers about M or even X rated movies. I think there has been total agreement in this chamber that that sort of thing must be stopped . People who, in good faith, accept a G rated film do not wish to find that they have an X rated attachment at the end of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what I raised this morning.

—Indeed, the honourable senator did. To my surprise I find myself in agreement with him. In fact, I think I could also say that it is pleasant to find Senator Harradine in agreement with me on this matter. There is no doubt that these are just the sorts of things that the classification proposals are attempting to address.

SPEECH.PARA: It was for these and other reasons that there was an attempt to classify the material. The attempt was sought and welcomed by many people in the community. If people are to make reasoned choices they can properly do so only if they have the necessary information, the consumer protection, that they need so as to make that informed choice that provides them, if you like, with the necessary information. People have to address that problem. I think the community has done so and I think this Government is attempting to do so in its classification scale. For people to make proper choices they need to have the necessary and the appropriate information. One way of doing that in terms of the video films that are available in our society is to make a classification of them.

My concern is that the Women Against Violence and Exploitation arguments may replace one set of exploitation with another, that is, the exploitation of censorship that has been used against women in the past. In the past women have been denied information about contraception. If ever there was a very destructive form of censorship it was that. I refer to the aforementioned article by Adele Horin which appeared in the National Times on 30 March 1984. Although I know that part of this article has been incorporated in Hansard, I would like to read another part of it. It states:

In the US, where the First Amendment to the Constitution guarantees free speech , the Women Against Pornography are more cognisant of the dangers of censorship than their Australian sisters. 'We do not advocate censorship. We respect the First Amendment stricture against imposition of prior restraint on any form of speech,' their leaflets state.
Feminists here--
'here' meaning in America-
concede that banning pornography will not even begin to attack the reasons why so many men hate and oppress women. And they work on many other fronts to end sexism and violence against women. Yet--
and in Australia perhaps-
they still appeal, as the puritans have always appealed, to the censor.

What we need to make clear is where we will draw the censorship line. There has been complete agreement in this chamber about those things that are beyond classification-such matters as child pornography, violence and terrorism and snuff movies are not even to be considered as part of the classification. It is those films and those items that are listed as eligible for X rating that are the problem for some of the women.

The women argue that the pornography in the X rating classification films continues to encourage the exploitation of women. It encourages the attitude of women as sex objects, as nothing more than possessions to be used by men as men will and as people who are dependent on what men will do to them or would want of them. I argue that that attitude of women is depicted in a much wider context in our society than just in X rated movies. Perhaps the way it is presented in X rated movies is more explicit and more horrific. But that kind of attitude of women as sex objects very widely pervades our society. One only has to open newspapers each day, read most of the magazines or follow the advertising on television or in films. The attitude that regards women as sex objects continues , very broadly, in our society.

To effect the changes of attitudes in our society that women want, and rightly so, it would seem more effective to insist that the recommendations of the 'Fair Exposure' booklet launched late last year by this Government-it was jointly launched by Mr Macphee and Senator Susan Ryan-be applied to all those magazines, newspapers, films, advertisements, et cetera. Those guidelines and the accompanying use of non-sexist language would meet the requirements to change attitudes in our society much more widely and much more effectively than censorship on X rated movies with the incumbent limited scope and the inherent dangers of extending the limits of censorship.

I will now go sideways, partly for my own edification. I can tell Senator Walters that I too went to the dictionary but I looked up different words. Unfortunately, I have to confess to knowing the meaning of every one of the words listed in the guidelines, but that may be the advantage of a medical education. I first looked up 'Eros'. Eros means: 'Love, god of love, Cupid'. I might say that I am dependent here on the Concise Oxford Dictionary, a reasonable volume. I then moved to 'erotic', which means 'Of love, amatory' and then to 'eroticism', which moved away from love, and which means 'sexual desire or excitement'. I then looked up the word 'pornography'. To my shock and horror I discovered that pornography derives from a Greek word 'porne' meaning harlot. So pornography means 'description of manners et cetera of harlots, treatment of obscene subjects in literature, inflammatory literature' et cetera. But I am appalled and once again reminded that when our society wishes to put a nasty connotation or a mean interpretation on something so often it turns to words that derive from women. I found it shocking to discover the origin of the word ' pornography'.

Another word that I looked up was 'libertarian'. In the Concise Oxford Dictionary it means 'Believer, believing in free will, advocate of liberty'. From there I went to 'libertine', which means 'Free-thinker on religion; licentious (man); free thinking, person allowed to do as he pleases'. I think what has happened of recent times is that 'libertarian' has become confused with 'libertine'. I would not like us to see our society encouraging that kind of shift. Perhaps it has already happened but maybe we can halt the process. I found the origins of these words informative for this debate, at least in the back of my head. Until we understand what those words mean, where they derive from and what they can be used to say I think we can be slightly wrong in the emphasis we place on this argument.

To Senator Walters's surprise, I am sure, I would like to say on record in this Senate chamber that I am certainly perturbed at much of the pornographic material and the view of women portrayed therein. I am absolutely sure that I speak for all women in this chamber. Certainly I know that I speak for Labor women both in this chamber and in the House of Representatives who also are totally opposed to the exploitation of women, particularly as portrayed in pornographic material. What I say that distinguishes Senator Walters from me is what I am prepared to do in response to that and what I judge to be the better way to address the problem. I prefer education and information to banning and an increase in censorship. I would include in that information the classification of videos so that people can more freely choose to reject that material. As Senator Chipp said earlier in this debate, there is no law that requires people to watch this material. People are quite free to reject it.

The word 'feminist' has been bandied around somewhat and somewhat loosely too. I guess we need to define what we mean by 'feminist'. Again, the Concise Oxford Dictionary defines a feminist as any person who works for the betterment of women, that is, men as well as women can be, and very often are, good feminists. But not all feminists hold the view expounded by the WAVE women. While there is sympathy for the opposition to the revolting way women are often represented and exploited, there is a considerable difference of feminist response to how best to solve the problem. It is important to keep in mind the longer view of what we aim for. If we are looking to a society that holds all men and women as worthy of equal regard the process of achieving that is the critical question. I would emphasise the word 'process'.

I stress again that my preference is for education and information rather than banning and an increase of censorship. I think the proposals in the legislation as put by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in this place today go some way to attempting to provide the information via classification so that people, in the process of being better informed and having better consumer protection, are better able to make the choices that they prefer and in particular are better able to oppose the exploitation of women rather than resort to the heavy hand of censorship to do it for them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motions of Senator Mason and Senator Harradine for the disallowance of regulations and ordinances in respect of video material. By making a change in the Customs regulations the Government has allowed into Australia a considerable amount of material such as hard core pornography which previously was not available. I have a paper from the Attorney-General's Department which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Barriers to the importation of hard core pornography-other than child pornography, publications which incite terrorism and publications containing extreme violence and/or sexual violence-have been lifted.

I understand that video material is virtually the same as the items listed in that paper. I repeat that the paper says that barriers to the importation of hard core pornography have been lifted. I feel that the Senate, by supporting the motion today, will be seen as doing away with the degradation of women firstly in the Australian Capital Territory and then throughout Australia. I wish to refer to a letter written by Mrs Esther Doyle, State President of the Catholic Women's League of New South Wales, which appeared in the Australian today. She made the following points about the importation and distribution of pornographic material:
1. Material promoting the degradation and exploitation of women should be refused classification.
2. All pornography should be banned. Reason: Classifying it gives it legality.
3. The views that adults should be entitled to indulge in pornography, or that it should not be permitted only if it offends reasonable adult persons, are naive and irresponsible.
I agree with Mrs Doyle when she states:
. . . There is no way that such material can be prevented from getting into the hands of those not able to cope with it.
It is very difficult to stop children viewing material such as this which comes into a home. She maintains in her letter:

In the past decade existing laws have not been suitably enforced. It is imperative that these laws be enforced and that more precise wording be introduced into further legislation to deal with technological developments such as video discs.

No one could be so unrealistic as to believe that television and films have no effect on their viewers. Our legislators must face the fact that the young, the unbalanced and the perverted will be affected by viewing horror, violence, sadism, sexual deviation, etcetera, and many will perform criminal acts as a result.

I consider that the action of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) was premature in making a change to the Customs regulations that could result in a flood of hard core pornography into Australia. In fact, the industry has felt that it has been given a green light for video sex. Unfortunately, when the change was made to the Customs regulations the State governments did not have their legislation in place to censor X rated hard core pornographic video material, although I understand that South Australia has now got complementary legislation in place. I am pleased to see that the Queensland Government is doing something about this matter. I note that the Queensland Government made a statement this week that it will bring forward new legislation on video censorship which will, I understand, mean the banning from our State of all video films with X censorship classification.

It is said from time to time that Queensland is a bit of a stuffy State because of its censorship laws. However, it seems, when one reads an article in one of Queensland's daily newspapers, that although Queensland has censorship laws one store in that State produced a collection of sex movies which an attendant said could not be put on the shelves. This could be the result of the new censorship procedures which came into operation in February. The newspaper article continued:
The movies were brought out with no hesitation and the attendant offered them for hire.
Although one of the films is banned from cinemas, no law can ban a video of the same movie.

I feel that that is an important point. The article pointed out that the manager of the television rental company said that his libraries had a standing order banning people under the age of 18 hiring videos. The article continued:
But he said there should be strict guidelines on what videos could and could not be hired.

These are important facts. However, there is a time lapse between bringing in the legislation and putting the legislation in place. Therefore, I feel it is necessary to pass the disallowance motion to give all States time to put their legislation in place. I believe that this Government cannot legislate to treat the Australian Capital Territory as an island. If all the other States decide that they will go ahead and put legislation in place, I think it is very important that we do it together. The New South Wales Women's Advisory Council in a report to the Premier of New South Wales on hard core pornography said:

Sexually explicit subordination of women, graphically depicted in pictures or words including the showing of women as things, commodities or objects or where women are injured, degraded, abused, tortured et cetera is not the sort of material that any women want to be available in Australia.
That is something of which the Senate should take note when examining this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right. X rated videos will be some of those.

—Yes, I agree with Senator Harradine. In common with other senators, I have had much correspondence about the need to disallow the regulations and ordinances on video material. An article in the Queensland Courier-Mail on 20 March stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Lack of censorship of video movies could have a major effect on society by allowing children to view sex and violence at home, according to police.
They are concerned unrestrictive viewing of videos in the home could have undesirable influences on juveniles.
Police say videos distributed for home viewing in Queensland need censorship control, but admit it is almost impossible to monitor what people watch privately.

Another senior police officer said the problem had arisen because no clear censorship guidelines had been set for videos, when compared with present restrictions on cinema films, television and reading material.
He said sex and violence seemed to be becoming noticeable in the Australian way of life and this was reflected in juveniles.
'If they are exposed to pornography and violence, it must have an effect on them'.

That is why it is necessary for the Senate to support this disallowance motion. If it is supported, then most certainly the Government will be able to enforce the law as it is now. The Censorship Board will be able to make judgments, as in the past, in relation to material as well as on films for public viewing. I certainly support the disallowance motions moved by Senators Mason and Harradine .

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to correct a few words I said in my speech. I said I had the pleasure of joining Senators Harradine and Mason in their move to disallow the regulations and ordinances. I now find that the Australian Democrats have decided not to support the motion. The Attorney- General, Senator Gareth Evans has, as he said in his speech, been able to buy their lousy vote.
—Order! I would ask the honourable senator to choose other words.

—Senator, I am quoting what Senator Gareth Evans said. I am not using those words but am quoting him. It was his comment that he was able to buy their lousy vote. The Democrats have fallen for that and have changed their minds. Their vote has been bought and they no longer intend to support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion for disallowance of these regulations. Unfortunately, as I was engaged on other matters I did not hear all the debate. Therefore, I have not followed all the twists and turns which have occurred in connection with the attitudes of some of the other parties on this topic. But I desire to put on record my view, and also to make some comment on the regulations and the position as I see it. We are considering the disallowance of a number of regulations and what has happened, as I look at the statement prepared by the Attorney-General's Department, a statement which has been made fairly public, I note it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Officers of the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Department will be empowered to classify publications under the Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983. These classifications will apply in the Australian Capital Territory and some States.
The document goes on to state:

Barriers to the importation of hard core pornography-other than child pornography, publications which incite terrorism and publications containing extreme violence and/or sexual violence-have been lifted.

I am somewhat concerned at the lifting of those bans. My view on censorship is, I believe, the same view that is adopted by most liberals. It is that, in general, people should be able to hear and see those things that they want, purchase what they want to, and not be hampered in what they do in their own homes. However, there are exceptions, and always must be, in regard to a number of areas. I refer to matters that affect children and other people who are worried by these matters, particularly women, who deserve our support. It was interesting to see that there is a wide degree of support in this matter by women of different political views in respect of rights and liberties. On this matter they seem to take a common view that this new venture by the Commonwealth should be reconsidered and not allowed to go ahead at this stage.

In the course of considering the disallowance, it has been suggested by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) that there would be difficulties if the disallowance goes ahead with problems being caused through the revival of existing regulations. There is also the point that under section 49 of the Acts Interpretation Act there may be difficulty in putting in a new regulation to cover the same ground. I realise that some of these points may have already been made in the debate by other speakers, but I feel it is important to ensure that these things are said and understood. Under section 49 of that Act if we disallow regulations, then no regulation being the same in substance as the regulations so disallowed or deemed to be disallowed can be made within six months of the date of disallowance. It is clear that if the Senate in its majority is of the opinion that this is an unsuitable form of regulation, then the one that appears will not be one that gives the same substance. It will indeed be substantially different in substance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister can introduce the legislation.

—Yes, the Minister can introduce legislation, or under clause 49 we can rescind the resolution if something better comes forward, or we can also by resolution approve the making of a regulation. We do not even have to have legislation. The clause contains adequate provisions for dealing with the position. I heard the Attorney-General's remarks before lunch, and they had initial persuasive effect so that one was led to take the view that if things were held over for a few weeks-there are meetings to be held on Friday-all would be well. But in the meantime I suggest there could be importation of goods, films and videos.
—What a gutsy libertarian performance!

—I am glad to see the Attorney-General back in the chamber, trading his usual insults. I hope he will keep it up because every time he does so, it does wonders for me back in my home State of Victoria-his State of Victoria, too. Any insult he feels like indulging in is all right.
—It was not an insult but a statement of fact.

—It was the tone of voice used by the Minister. I still regard myself as a better civil libertarian. The Minister may well say that I have not had the testing that he has had in the last year. He may have fallen by the wayside, and I feel sorry for him.
—You are about as good a civil libertarian as you were a defender of the Constitution in 1975. You are always standing up but never for quite long enough to be counted.

—I have often had tests. The Attorney-General has made that comment on other occasions. I hope he will think of something new to say. He is becoming dull and repetitious as well as being insulting. I do not forgive him for that. Let us get back to the subject. In my belief these regulations are grossly defective. Perhaps I may deal with the import of videos and films, and I agree substantially with the arguments advanced by Senator Mason this morning. Having heard Senator Mason's speech this morning, I must say I agree substantially with the argument he was advancing, but I think I would take it one step further. He was concerned with the fact that what were not to be allowed were those publications which, according to the wording, 'gratuitously depict in pictorial form extreme violence or cruelty, especially when combined with any sexual element to the extent that they should not be imported'. I do not see why we should be restricting only extreme violence. It seems to me that grossly excessive violence is being shown in this community. I have no doubt that it is having a considerable effect on children and on our society and evidence of this is coming forward. I think a considerable amount of violence, not just coupled with a sexual element, is something that should be greatly restricted. I draw the attention of honourable senators also to the fact that that passage does not cover just depictions of gratuitous extreme violence, only that which should not be imported. So it would be possible to import material showing extreme violence if somebody makes a decision that it is not sufficiently bad not to import it. Who makes the judgment? On what criteria is the judgment made? I do not know. But it seems to me that that may be a point which has not been made, and it is another defect in these provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: So far as the opinion of the community is concerned, I am impressed with what the members of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly have said to the Senate in this matter. In the letter we received from Mrs Bev Cains, we are told that the House of Assembly unanimously supported her proposition that ' these amendments and Ordinances do not seriously attempt to curb the flow of hard core pornographic material'. I break in to say that the statement of the Attorney-General says that the Government is lifting the restrictions on this. Mrs Cain said: 'Please note the debate from the House of Assembly'. I have certainly done that. She further said:
I believe you, as legislators, have a serious duty to uphold the dignity of all people. You recently considered at length the Sex Discrimination Act.
I hope you will objectively attempt to make the matters before you address the serious matter of the degradation of women.

I speak not from any great experience of pornography-I would find it extremely boring and I certainly have made no attempt to make myself an expert in that area-but I have no doubt from what I have read and heard that many productions are made which are degrading and offensive to women. So we found in the debate in the Assembly women of very considerably different views agreeing that this is degrading. They were very worried at the continuance of the application of these regulations in the Australian Capital Territory.

It seems to me that we must take a responsibility in this Parliament. I hope we will not hold the matter over from today so that in the next few weeks, when Parliament is not sitting, there can be a flood of imports of videos and other material to this country which will, of course, then spread and will probably keep the industry, such as it is, alive for a year or two, making use of the opportunity which it has while the regulations are still on foot.

I believe that the actual importation of this material, much of which is filth, is the most important area. By coming into this country it will help to degrade the standards of this community. I know it is not for us to impose our standards on the community. At the same time we must hold some line in regard to the material which is available; material which we know will come into the possession of or be seen by children, which will be shown in homes and which will lead in due course to a further lowering of moral standards in this community. For these reasons I believe these regulations ought to be disallowed. Certainly then there ought to be some effort made to find a better and more restricted means of imposing proper controls on this industry, if I may call it that, so that we do not find our people subjected to a great mass of unsatisfactory imported material. For these reasons I support the motions for disallowance and hope that the regulations and the Ordinance will be disallowed today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this debate which has centred on the disallowance of Customs regulations in respect of prohibited imports of cinematographic films and the Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance. It is with a certain degree of sorrow that I have to follow Senator Missen because in his contribution this afternoon he managed to dispel, at least in my mind, the reputation that he had of being an alert civil libertarian. Of course he did make the concession for himself that he had not been involved in the debate during the day and as a consequence missed some of the manoeuvrings. Had he been here he would have realised that one point that he made had, in fact, been accommodated by the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans)-the point on extreme violence which was raised by Senator Mason. The Government has indicated an inclination towards accommodating the point made by the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Missen would have also realised that that was not the only point on which the Attorney had indicated a willingness to move. He would also have realised that with those movements today, together with the meeting planned for Friday of this week with State Attorneys-General, there could very well have been an opportunity for a uniform approach to be rekindled in this area, an approach which is vital if we are to look at an orderly system of regulating this area.

At the moment the Senate is presented with a disallowance of regulations, with utter confusion following therefrom, or an adjournment for approximately a month , at which stage the Government can come up with a set of revised ordinances and regulations. It is not a major concession to ask the Opposition to be reasonable in this matter. It is claiming that the floodgates will open in the space of a month or so and we will be flooded with pornographic and objectionable video material. It also claims that the material is here at the moment, so where is the consistency in its argument? The material is here. The regulations and the laws have not been proven to be adequate to accommodate the particular problem that the community highlights. It is for this reason that the Attorney has taken the approach to trying to organise uniform legislation to cover both areas of responsibility-that of the Commonwealth and that of the States.

The actual regulations embody the Government's policy in this area-a policy of allowing adults an entitlement to read, hear and see what they wish subject to a number of qualifications. It is subject to the qualification that there is protection of those who can be easily exploited, especially children, subject to protection against persons having unsolicited material which is offensive to them thrust upon them; and subject to the viewing of such material being in private.

We have had much thrown at us in respect of pornography and much of it has been pursued by the normal forces of darkness in this place-the Senator Harradines and the Senator Walters. They are the ones who are claiming that community standards are such and so on. But I for one would resent and object to my standards, my sense of morality and the morality of many others in this community being controlled by the morality of those who have spoken before me. What is offensive to some of them is not necessarily offensive to me, and what is offensive to me is obviously, in many instances, not offensive to some of them. One thing that the Opposition should recognise in this respect is that bad laws cannot be enforced. It is impossible to lay down a legislative framework to enforce private morality. We have a responsibility to go to a certain extent, but we also have a responsibility to protect the interests of individuals.

As I have said, bad laws lead to avoidance. In this instance they lead to uncontrolled black markets. They lead to breach of copyright where people with video taping facilities available to them can produce whatever they like on their own. It is bad laws that have no respect in the community and it is those laws that we are talking about enforcing at the moment. What the Government is on about is a system of effective regulation. It is on about a realistic approach to a particular problem about which the Opposition is obviously concerned. As I said earlier this evening, it is an approach that fits within the constitutional framework that we have to take into consideration.

Under our federalist system the Commonwealth has certain areas of control, as do the States. The Commonwealth's area of control is in respect of the importation of films, videos and literature. The States' area of control is that of the exhibition of films or the advertising, displaying or selling of publications and videos whether they are produced locally or imported. This breakdown of powers and functions was recognised by earlier speakers, and I am glad to say was recognised by the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Durack. Speakers on both sides have recognised that the problem is such that it may best be met in the area of sale and distribution rather than in the area of importation. That has been one important aspect of the debate today. As I said, the Government's proposals implement a certain framework. They are based on a system whereby Customs officers have the initial detection role and from there on the Attorney-General's Department, with the relevant censorship tribunals, has the responsibility of deciding what is and what is not a prohibited import.

In respect of printed matter, the proposals advocate four sets of classifications-unrestricted, restricted (category 1), restricted (category 2) and denied classification. The Attorney-General has made the restrictions clear but I think those listening to the debate should be alerted to the fact that in respect of category 1 restrictions there should be no sale to minors, and there should be other restrictions on the conduct of sale. Category 2 provides even further protection for those who do not wish to have such material imposed on them. In respect of the fourth category, denied classification, the Government is concerned to ensure that totally unacceptable erotica or pornography, be it child pornography or pornography that is extremely degrading, is prohibited from sale, display or hire. This framework is not a charter for open slather on these publications. The Government recognises that there should be control and prohibition of sale in certain areas, and we are moving towards adopting those sorts of principles.

I turn now to videos, which have attracted wide debate this afternoon. We are proposing a system that is almost identical to that currently applying for cinema. We have the classifications of general, parental guidance, mature audiences only and restricted. However, we recognise the need for a further video classification-the X rating. X rated material will attract prohibition against cinema showing. We also recognise, once again, that there are problem areas with child pornography and with other material of an extremely gross nature. That will not be allowed to be sold. Sale of restricted and X classification material will be allowed on special conditions but this framework does not allow for the legal sale or propagation of extremely gross pornography or child pornography. As I have said, we have embodied these princples in the regulations. This framework prohibits pictorial child pornography, incitement to terrorism and, also, as the regulations stand at the moment, gratuitous, extreme pictorial violence and sexual violence. As I indicated earlier, the Attorney- General has shown flexibility in accommodating the points made by the Australian Democrats in respect of their request to delete 'extreme' from the criterion of extreme political violence.

As has been indicated already today, even though the video classification system is one of voluntary classification, there are penalties when the conditions of the system are not met. Even more importantly, where an importer, distributor or other person does not apply for classification they will risk prosecution under State obscenity laws and under the laws of the Commonwealth. So, in effect, the Government has come up with a system which will accommodate the particular problem that we have in Australia.

Over recent years a number of people have come to my office with problems concerning Customs. They have come from other countries and have brought with them films which may be family films-in this respect I do not refer to pornography, but to legitimate videos of families back in Greece, Italy or wherever-or foreign language films. These people have said to me: 'Look, I came back to Australia after a visit overseas three months ago and I am still waiting for a video to be approved and checked by the relevant government department.' On inquiry I have discovered that there is a massive backlog because we do not have the facilities to check, especially foreign language films. That is one aspect of the backlog that already exists. If we do not approach the particular problem we have now with a sane, rational approach, with one that is selective in that it attacks the problem area and in doing so allows exemption for the legitimate areas-for example for the educational and entertainment areas-we will find that this backlog will increase and the resources will be even more inadequate. As a consequence, the enforcement authorities will be missing out on the detection of the illegal material that we do not want spread through the community. That is the problem that exists at the moment. If we were to pursue the approach of the Opposition, we would find that problem accentuated even more .

I refer briefly to one of the points Senator Harradine made. He claims that the Government shows naivety and that, as a Party, we have shown naivety for over 10 years. Senator Harradine's Press statement of 2 April 1984 indicates that the naivety of which we on this side are supposed to be guilty is more adequately sheeted home to Senator Harradine. He made this rather amazing statement:
By introducing a new 'X' rating the package will institutionalise the importation, production and traffic in hard core pornography.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—He may claim it is right but it is also right that hard core pornography now exists. Senator Harradine will not understand, in this debate or in many other debates on enforcing laws of morality, that unless the community holds sufficient respect for laws they cannot be enforced properly. In this particular case, unless we recognise the legitimate interests of a democracy, we will find there is no respect for the laws in question. He cannot and will not understand that unless they have sufficient respect in the community, they will not be enforced properly. That then leads to all sorts of other problems.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, we have the option of a deferral to allow a system, that I would have thought appealed to the Opposition and to Senator Harradine, that would allow further discussions with State Attorneys-General this week, that would allow a further clearing up of the regulations and that would cause absolutely no inconvenience to the Senate. We have 11 more sitting days in which we can discuss these regulations and make a decision. In that period the Attorney- General could very well come up with a revised framework which could be accepted by a majority of States. We ask why Senator Harradine and the Opposition are not prepared to do that, when the Opposition spokesman recognises that advances could be made on the particular proposals? Why cannot Senator Harradine carry his side to ensure an adjournment if for no other reason than in the interests of good government? All I can say is that once again we have an indication here of either Senate stubbornness or a massive degree of shortsightedness by conservative Opposition members of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a motion for the disallowance of certain Customs regulations. Those regulations relate to the regulating and classifying of video films. As the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) told us, the background is that the States and the Commonwealth had realised that measures relating to the classification of print media and ordinary films could not be applied to video; therefore, a new approach had to be made. It is fundamental for those who are debating this to understand that we are not debating or opposing the classifications of print media or of the ordinary cinematographic films. The motion for disallowance relates to regulations concerning video tapes which can be imported into Australia.
—But others are caught up as well in the regulations you are seeking to disallow.

—That is what I understood from the Attorney. As I understand it-I hope I have it right-the Attorney said that the meeting in July of the States and the Commonwealth reached certain agreements on videos which the Government now seeks to implement in these Customs regulations which apply--
—No, they did not reach agreement. There were reservations by Queensland and Tasmania.

—Senator Harradine is right, but I am repeating what the Attorney-General said. He said that they reached agreement and out of that agreement emerged these Customs regulations which will function in the Australian Capital Territory from 1 February. He said that the principles on which they should operate-I want to examine them because this must be a serious debate-are that as a starting point adults should be allowed to read, hear and see, in private, and indeed in public anything they want, subject to certain protections for them. There should be adequate protection of the interests of children. Consumer protection should be applied by way of giving guidance through classification and there should be a principle involving some four categories which would be excluded. I think that is a fair precis of what the Attorney said. I want it to be so because I do not want this debate to develop into a combative situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The important thing that the Attorney said was that this was being done in acknowledgment of the impossibility of import controls. So he had obviously looked at the possibility of import controls, that is, putting a classification on and denying the import of certain material; but he said: 'No, that can't be done'. If that is so and if the Commonwealth through its Customs and its police forces cannot enforce import bans on certain classifications, what hope has the Government of enforcing any kind of ban on those excluded materials that it now classifies and says ought not to be circulated at all to adults or others? If import controls are imposible, what kind of sanction does the Government hope for? In fact, the refused classifications, it says, can be policed by prosecution. But obviously if prosecution is effective in this, it ought to be effective in upholding import controls.

A number of people from the Labor side, from the Government side, in this debate have argued as though this is a matter concerning adults. It is not; it bears no relation at all to the question of cinematographic films or print media in which we can have classifications. The age of people can be checked at the entrance to such films and parents themselves can exert influence. A video tape is capable of manifest reproduction in as many copies as one likes. The video recorder today is part of the institution and in no way can it be said that under these regulations parents would have any ability to control whether their children are subjected to these kinds of tapes. So it is not an argument about whether adults should be given freedom. It is really an argument about what the parents of children in this community believe their children ought to see. It is not an argument of a paternalistic approach to adults. It is an argument that we all accept; everybody accepts a paternalistic approach to children. That is a very important point to make.

In our classifications of print media and films we recognise paternalism with respect to juveniles. We recognise that and we cater for it. In these Customs regulations we have done the very reverse. It is a strange thing that in one of the most important areas of debate in the very social manners and customs of our people we have never asked the people of Australia by way of public inquiry--

TALK.START.PARA: —He will not even give his own side a conscience vote on it.

—No. We have never set up an inquiry to ask parents what they as parents want their children to see. That is the standard. It is not for us to make a value judgment on this. It is for us to expose the problems and let the public see it. I repeat that there is a great danger whenever a question of censorhip comes up for people to be classified as either one of two things: Prudes if they feel that some kind of censorship is necessary, or permissive if they go the the other extreme. That is a nonsense argument and should be removed from this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Nobody in this Senate and nobody in the Government is arguing that there should not be some form of absolute exclusive censorship. Let us make that quite clear. Paternalism comes in from the very start. There are clearly defined and stated areas of exclusion. It has been decided that adults apparently are not adult enough to see them. That raises a very important question. Who should decide where we draw the line? Thus huge problems are being put to us in considering this subject. I concentrate for the moment on one thing. I will support disallowance because this is not a question of consenting adults in private; it is a question of what we as Australians want to do with regard to video tapes of all sorts of extremes in terms of pornography being exposed to our children.

What do we want to do to protect the community from a cottage industry of pornography for juveniles? That is not a sense of paternalism on my part. I have the strongest sense that we ought to create a community that is waterproofed as strongly as possible to make good, balanced judgments and to resist the world. But that is not the argument. The argument is: Here are video films on which the Government says it is impossible to enforce import controls-I reject that-but somehow it will make a classification and somehow it will rest upon parents being able to see that their children do not see these things. Every parent would know that the manifest existence of the video recorder means that children will have recourse to these throughout the whole of the community. So what is asked for is a second look at this. The need is to go back to the drawing board because the Attorney-General-and I am not in any sense combative in this-has put forward conflicting arguments. If he says it is impossible for import controls to regulate things, how is it possible for the excluded categories to be regulated?

TALK.START.PARA: —At point of sale, at point of hire.

—No. The point is that the point of sale could be the black market; adults and children could get even the excluded category. It is an admission of failure to say that that cannot be done at the point of import. In fact, this is an admission of defeat. The fact is that all through history men and women have argued about what ought to be the freedom of people. John Stuart Mill laid down some very real principles. Nobody has ever argued that there is absolute freedom. Absolute freedom is licence. Absolute freedom means that the libertine can do disastrous things. I have always understood that my freedom imposes a major responsibility on me. Freedom for the adult individual is a responsibility to see that the freedom and dignity of the other person are not tainted in any way.
—So to use mine that it does not injure thine.

—That is right. The fact is that we can assault not just by the force of the fist or a weapon but by words-words are the ugliest form of assault-and by graphic pictures. Assault is as abhorrent if it is by words or pictures as it is by the male fist. We in this community have a duty to understand that there are no absolute values except spiritual ones. In the society in which we elect to live, we elect to respect the relative values. We can wander in the journey of the freedom of the mind; that is one of our privileges. But we must then come to relative values by drawing upon our own spiritual, moral or ethical qualities, or those we understand the community believes in and supports.

SPEECH.PARA: So it is nonsense to talk about this idea that the community can be given anything at all. Absolute values are absolute anarchy; they cannot exist. Nor in fact are those who are arguing the opposite point of view saying that. They are saying that all the people who argue for some protection are wrong but as a postscript they say that there has to be an excluded category and that they are going to decide what the excluded category will be. That is an absolutely nonsensical situation. That value judgment cannot be made by an Attorney-General or a State Minister; it can be made only by a public that is asked what it in its heart of hearts believes it wants.

When dealing with the precious development of the character of the young, one must ask oneself what kinds of values one wants to develop in the young, what kinds of understandings one wants them to have of the human relationship. Human relationship is not some material thing that can be talked about in terms of simplistic anatomy or what I call plumbing. Human plumbing is the ugliest description of human relationship. Human relationship is a spiritual mystique. It is a precious thing. The only question in human relationship is the development of a consensus between people, a consensus in which at its best each person wants to give to the other so that he or she can widen the freedom of the other. In fact, in a strange way the freedom of the person who gives is widened. Therefore one has to understand that we are talking about a community that we want to build for the future, a community in which there is an understanding of this mystique of the human relationship, a respect for human dignity, a giving and not just a brutal receiving.

To reduce the human relationship in any way to a physical relationship is to fail to understand it. The physical relationship, at its optimum, is again a mystique. It is a creature of the giving of the mind and of the spirit and not, as I say, some plumbing. I have frequently said, and I repeat, that it is the poets and not the plumbers who describe the human relationship. What we are really facing at this moment is a situation in which children, through video tapes, will get a completely distorted view of what the human relationship is. They are not in a position to protect themselves. There is no way in which they can protect themselves. I believe that every parent wants to ensure that his or her children develop the best, the optimum understanding of the relationship of human beings, how society intermeshes, how we develop, and the qualities we want of love and affection and of human interrelationship. Is that to be achieved simply by an engorgement into the community of pornography?

As one who in his lifetime has seen his fair share of human brutality, I can only say that there is no gentle learning pattern in studying human brutality. To say that everybody should be exposed to every kind of activity that the human being can devise, to say that we should allow the greatest distortion on earth, is to fail to understand what we in this community are trying to do, namely, to get the message over as parents that we want the young to develop an understanding of what citizenship means and the importance of interrelationships . In the wider sense it is a good thing to throw open to the community, now that it has had a chance to look at the whole situation, the opportunity to decide what it wants. I wonder what would be said by the community at large if it were given the chance to choose at a referendum the values it wants. The community is not given that sort of opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would they say about capital punishment? What would they say about Asian immigration? Put these things to the test.
—I hope the community would say about capital punishment what I say about capital punishment, and that is that it is the degradation of human dignity.
—You know as well as I do the community would not.
—Order!

—Mr President, I acknowledge that I should address my remarks through the Chair, but let me say to the Attorney-General that capital punishment is as ugly a form of brutality as any other form, and I have said that time and again in this chamber.
—Majority rule is not always civilised rule, is it?

—We exist to try to find out what is the best. A parliament exists to create an environment, not to create an end in itself, not to create a society. It exists to create an environment by rules, in which the human personality, the human dignity and the human spirituality burgeons. We are hear not just to earn our bread and butter but to create that kind of environment. One has to ask oneself under what conditions that will be achieved. Time after time the Parliament creates laws restricting human beings. To say that it is wrong to restrict the human being is to ignore the 300 or 400 Bills that pass through the hands of the Attorney-General each year. The function of a law officer is to look into the legal restrictions imposed by the laws that are laid down and within the legal framework to ensure that those laws are observed and that people who do not observe them are punished.
